d: Contest won by deception general.
Contest won by magic.
r: India: Thompson-Balys; S. A. Indian (Chincha, Peru): Alexander Lat. Am.

d: Magic animal wins contest for man.
Magic bullock wins fight for master.
Animals help man in contest.
r: Type 1081; S. A. Indian (Chincha, Peru): Alexander Lat. Am.

d: Fortune to go to direction cat jumps.
a: King will give wealth to person toward whom the cat jumps. Clever woman has brought mouse along and thus entices the cat.

d: Substitute in contest.
r: Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; N. A. Indian (Seneca): Curtin-Hewitt RBAE XXXII 234 No. 46.

d: Relative substitutes in contest.
Young knight substitutes for old man in tournament.
Supernatural substitute in tournament for pious warrior.
Woman substitutes for husband in combat.
Wise man disguised as monk beats learned heretic in debate.
Contest with magician won by deception.
Athletic contest won by deception.
Race won by deception.
r: *Dh IV 46ff.; *BP III 339ff.; *Von den Steinen Zs. f. Vksk.

d: Man challenges devil to race.
a: Cheats him.

d: Race won by deception: relative helpers.
r: *Type 1074; *Dh I+V48; Chauvin III 32; *Parsons JAFL XXI 221 n. 2; BP III 340ff., *343. North Carolina: Brown Collection I 703; Finnish-Swedish: Hackman FFC VI No. 275*; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 92*; Spanish: Espinosa III 457f. India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Basset Contes Berbires 139; Japanese: Ikeda. Indonesia: *Dixon 192, 334 n. 18, DeVries's list No. 120; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 445, (Tinguian): Cole 198. N. A. Indian: *Boas BBAE LIX 307, (Oaxaca, Mexico): Boas JAFL XXV 214; S. A. Indian (Araucanian): Lehman-Nitsche Int. Americanists XIV 686, (Amazon): Alexander Lat Am. Africa (Cameroons): Mansfield 224, (Benga): Nassau 95 No. 5, (Kaffir): Kidd 239 No. 8, (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 390 No. 15, (Suk): Mervin The Suk 38, (Ibo, Nigeria): Basden 274, Thomas 153, (Vai): Ellis 199 No. 16; Bahama: Edwards MAFLS III 69; Cape Verde Islands: *Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 308 n. 1; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 261 No. 60, Jekyll 39ff.; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 86 No. 18, (Virginia): Parsons JAFL XXXV 271, (North Carolina): Backus JAFL XI 284, Parsons JAFL XXX 174, (South Carolina): Stewart JAFL XXXII 394, Parsons MAFLS XVI 79, (Florida): Parsons JAFL XXX 225f.
a: One of the contestants places his relatives (or others that resemble him) in the line of the race. The opponent always thinks the trickster is just ahead of him. (Told of animals or of men; often of the hare and the turtle.)

d: Race won by deception: riding on the back.
r: (Cf. +K25.1.) *Types 221, 250, 275; *Dh IV 72ff., 91, 160ff.; Wienert FFC LVI *54 (ET 139), 114 (ST 248); BP III 278, *339. Italian Novella: Rotunda; Chinese: Graham; Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia: DeVries's list Nos. 102, 121; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 441, (Kalispel): Curtis N. A. Indian VII iii, (Jicarilla Apache): Goddard PaAM VIII 236 No. 45; Africa (Vai): Ellis 189 No. 5, (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 155 No. 30; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 261 No. 60; American Negro (Virginia): Parsons JAFL XXXV 270f., (Pennsylvania): ibid.
a: One contestant rides on the other's back.

d: Hare and tortoise race: sleeping hare.
r: *Dh IV 66ff.; *BP III 341ff.; Jacobs Aesop 162 No. 68; Haupt Zs. Japanese: Ikeda; Ainu: Chamberlain, B. Aino Folktales (London, 1888) No. 14; N. A. Indian (Ojibwa): Schoolcraft Algic Researches 181, (Cherokee): Mooney RBAE XIX 290 No. 43; Africa (West Africa): Cronise and Ward Cunnie Rabbit, Mr. Spider and the Other Beef (London, 1903) 155f.; West Indies: Flowers 494; Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 102; American Negro (Pennsylvania): Parsons JAFL XXX 214, (North Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXX 174, (South Carolina): Parsons MAFLS XVI 79, (Florida): Parsons JAFL XXX 226.
a: In a race between the fast and the slow animal, the fast animal sleeps on the road and allows the slow animal to pass him.

d: Race won by deception: chariot disabled.
a: A rival in a chariot race inserts linchpins of wax instead of those of bronze in the hero's chariot. The latter is dragged to death.

d: Race won by deception: sham-sick trickster.
a: The trickster feigns lameness and receives a handicap in the race. He then returns and eats up the food which is the prize.

d: Race won by deception: rabbit as "little son" substitute.
a: A man challenged by an ogre to a running race persuades the ogre to race with his little son instead. By this he means a rabbit.

d: Race won by deception: blinding opponent by spitting pepper into face.
Race won by deception: bow and arrow.
a: Certain goal to be touched. Man shoots arrow and wins.

d: Obstacle race between deer and hare.
a: Hare accused of removing obstacles from his course.

d: Wrestling match won by deception.
r: **Hackman En Finldndsk-Svensk Saga av Tssteuropeiskt Ursprung (Brages Ersskrift IV, Helsingfors 1910); Icelandic: Boberg; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 314 n. 137a.

d: Wrestling match won by deception: where to throw the ogre.
a: The ogre squeezes the man so that his eyes bulge out. The ogre: "Why do you glare so?" "I am looking to see where to throw you." The ogre flees (Cf. +K18.1.)

d: Wrestling match won by deception: bear as "grandfather."
a: A man challenged by an ogre persuades the latter to wrestle with his old grandfather instead. By this he means a bear.

d: Wrestling match: Antaeus.
a: Giant invincible in wrestling because with each contact with earth his strength is renewed.

d: Wrestling match of man with fever.
a: Man places stone image at wrestling-place; fever enters image and shatters it.

d: Wrestling between porcupine and deer.
a: Deer defeated but always pleads illness.

d: Boxing match: fatal boxer defeated.
a: All comers are challenged and all are killed until the hero defeats the challenger. (Argonauts and Amycus.)

d: Rowing contest won by deception.
a: The boat is already sawed through.

d: Rowing contest won by deception: magic boat.
Climbing match won by deception.
r: *Hackman cf. +K12; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 314 n. 135.

d: Climbing match won by deception: squirrel as "child".
a: The ogre agrees to contest against the man's young one, i.e., a squirrel.

d: Diving match won by deception.
Diving match won by deception: breathing under brush.
a: Trickster comes up and breathes under some floating brush, where he is not detected.

d: Diving match: trickster eats food while dupe is under water.
r: Africa (Kaffir): Theal 101, (Angola): Chatelain 205; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 239; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 373 No. 67, (South Carolina): Stewart JAFL XXXII 394, Parsons MAFLS XVI 40.

d: Jumping contest won by deception.
r: Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 51; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 302 n. 104.

d: Contest: jumping into the ground.
a: A hole is already dug and covered with boughs.

d: Contest: who can go deepest into the earth?
a: Wren goes into mouse hole.

d: Contest in jumping from the church tower.
a: The devil is not to look behind him. The man runs downstairs (or otherwise cheats).

d: Contest in jumping into a trap.
Jumping frog contest.
r: Anonymous Historia de Pedro Urdemales (Yungay, Chile, 1885) No. 11.
a: Frog filled with shot.

d: Throwing contest won by deception.
r: *Fb "kaste" II 103a; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 21; Africa (Bankon): Ittman 88.

d: Throwing contest: trickster shouts.
a: He is trying to warn the people beyond the sea with his cry. The ogre is intimidated.

d: Throwing contest: trickster addresses Angel Gabriel.
r: N. A. Indian (Penobscot): Speck JAFL XXVIII 56.
a: Offers him the ogre's cane. The ogre is intimidated.

d: Throwing contest: trickster addresses Angel Gabriel or St. Peter,  warns him to get out of way of missile trickster is about to throw.
Throwing contest: golden club on the cloud.
a: Trickster shows the ogre the club he has thrown. (Really only a bright spot on the cloud.)

d: Throwing contest: bird substituted for stone.
r: *Type 1062; BP I 148; Lappish: Qvigstad Lappiske Eventyr II 237, 251; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 95; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 51; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 431ff., (Navaho): Matthews MAFLS V 84; Africa: Meinhof Afrikanische Mdrchen 178, (Jaunde): Nekes 252.
a: The ogre throws a stone; the hero a bird which flies out of sight.

d: Deceptive tug-of-war.
r: Africa (Mpongwe): Nassau 37 No. 5, (Ibo, Nigeria): Basden 277, Thomas 145, (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 377 No. 2; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 124 No. 26; Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 74 No. 34, Edwards MAFLS III 65; South American Negro: C. F. Hartt Amazonian Tortoise Myths (Rio de Janeiro, 1875) 20, Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 83 No. 27; West Indies: Flowers 495ff.
a: Small animal challenges two large animals to a tug-of-war. Arranges it so that they unwittingly pull against each other (or one end of rope is tied to a tree).

d: Deceptive shinny match.
r: N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 314 n. 141, (California): Gayton and Newman 74.

d: Deception in swinging contest.
Flying contest won by deception.
Flying contest won by deception: riding on the other.
a: Wren hides in eagle's wings.

d: Contest in flying with load.
a: One animal chooses cotton; the other, seeing that a rain is coming, chooses salt and wins.

d: Blowing contest won by deception.
Riding contest won by substitution.
Tournament won by deception on borrowed horse.
Hunting contest won by deception.
Shooting contest won by deception.
r: Philippine: Fansler MAFLS VII 137; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 314 n. 142.

d: Contest: shooting an unheard-of bird.
a: The man sends his wife on all fours in tar and feathers. The ogre has never heard of such a bird.

d: Shooting test won by deception: proof of good sight.
a: A man puts a dead hare under a tree and shows it to his dog. He tells people to look at the hare under the tree. At the distance no one can see it. He tells them that he will shoot it. He shoots and has his dog bring the hare.

d: Shooting contest won by deception: bird substituted for arrows.
Trapping contest won by deception.
r: N. A. Indian: Thompson Tales 328 n. 187.

d: Harpooning contest won by deception.
Labor contest won by deception.
Plowing contest.
Plowing contest won by deception: hare exchanged for horse.
a: God and the devil contest in plowing. The devil plows with a horse, God with a hare. While the devil is asleep, God takes the devil's horse and plows the field. When he wakes, the devil thinks the hare has plowed so much and gladly trades his horse for the hare.

d: Pig and dog as plowmen.
a: Pig plows while dog sleeps. Then dog runs back and forth in furrow to claim victory.

d: Harvesting contest.
Contest: harvesting the hay.
a: The man calls out, "The wolves are coming!" The ogre is intimidated.

d: Threshing contest.
r: Type 1089*; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1089*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1089.

d: Mowing contest won by trickery.
a: The man takes the center of the field. The ogre is given a dull sickle and mows around the outside of the field.

d: God cheats devil at mowing.
a: God mows with a chisel, the devil with a scythe. God deceives devil into changing scythe for chisel.

d: Deceptive contest in chopping.
Deceptive contest in chopping: iron in bamboo.
a: Hero challenged to cut down bundles of bamboo suspended in air but a strip of iron is treacherously inserted in each.

d: Tree-pulling contest.
Sewing contest won by deception.
Sewing contest won by deception: the long thread.
a: The ogre sews with the whole length of the thread. When he returns from the first stitch, the tailor has his task finished.

d: Contest in bridge-building won by deception.
Endurance contest won by deception.
Waking contest won by deception.
r: Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 25; cf. DeVries FFC LXXIII 400ff.

d: Waking contest won by giving opponent soporific.
Contest in seeing sunrise first.
Contest in seeing sunrise first: sun on the trees.
r: (Sometimes told with human actors.) *Type 120; Dh III 147ff., 150ff.; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 269; Irish: Jackson FL XLVII 285; Japanese: Ikeda. Cf. Harris Friends 3 No. 1.
a: The fox places himself on a hill facing the east; the hog in a lower place facing the high trees to the west. The sun shines on the top of the trees, and the hog wins.

d: Contest in seeing sunrise first: sleeper wins.
a: One keeps awake, the other sleeps. The first thinks that he sees the sun and cries out prematurely, thus waking the other, who wins.

d: Deceptive contest in fasting.
r: Irish myth: *Cross; Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 34ff.; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 133; Africa (Nigeria): Dayrell 153ff.; Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 97 No. 51; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 261f.

d: Absurd contest won by deception.
Contest in pushing hole in tree: hole prepared beforehand.
a: Hero and ogre to vie in pushing a hole in a tree with their heads.

d: Contest in squeezing water from a stone.
r: *Types 1060, 1640; *BP I 148; *Fb "sten" III 554a, "shst" II 763a; Danish: Kristensen Danske Sagn I (1892) 438; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 51; Caucasian: Dirr Kaukasische Mdrchen 7 No. 2; Malay: Hambruch Malaiische Mdrchen 109; Africa: Frobenius Atlantis IX 289; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 146 No. 30.
a: The ogre squeezes a stone; the trickster a cheese or egg.

d: Contest in biting a stone.
r: *Types 1061, 1640; BP I 68 n. 1, II 528; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 387 No. 13.
a: The ogre bites a stone; the man a nut.

d: Hero to eat iron grains.
a: Substitutes soft food.

d: Contest: pulling on steak with teeth.
a: Two men take an end of a steak in their teeth; each attempts to pull it away from the other. After each has a good hold, the Irishman says (with clenched teeth) "Noo're ready?" The Dutchman says, "Yah!" , loses the steak.

d: Dream contests.
Absurd contest won by deception miscellaneous.
Contest with magician in bringing grain out of closed bamboo: trickster brings culm-borers to make holes.
Contest in strength won by deception.
Deceptive contest in carrying a tree: riding.
r: *Type 1052; *BP I 149; Africa (Dzalamo): Meinhof ZsES XI 280. Cf. Type 1640.
a: The trickster has the dupe carry the branches of a tree while he carries the trunk. He rides on the trunk.

d: Deceptive contest in carrying a horse.
a: The ogre carries it on his back and soon tires; the man carries it between his legs (rides).

d: Deceptive contest in squeezing hands.
a: The man has an iron glove on.

d: Deceptive contest in pulling fingers.
a: The man has an iron finger.

d: Contests in other physical accomplishments won by deception.
Deceptive eating contest.
r: Koryak: Jochelson JE VI 128; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 314 n. 137b; Eskimo (West Hudson Bay): Boas BAM XV 313, (Greenland): Rink 108.

d: Deceptive eating contest: hole in bag.
r: (Cf. +K82.1.) *Type 1088; Saintyves Perrault 282; Krohn Tutkimuksia Suomalaisten Kansansatujen alalta 220ff.; Ktshler-Bolte I 86; *Fb "zhde" III 1139b. Icelandic: Flateyjarbuk I 211, MacCulloch Eddic 93, Boberg; Danish: Kristensen Danske Sagn I (1892) 439; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 21; India: Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 330 n. 191b; Africa: Frobenius Atlantis IX 368, XII 349.
a: The hero slips his food into a bag and makes the ogre believe that he is the greater eater. (In many versions the hero cuts open the bag; the ogre imitates and kills himself.)

d: Deceptive eating contest: relative helpers.
a: Trickster wins with the aid of substitutes.

d: Deceptive eating contest: inexhaustible food.
a: Hero can produce unlimited food which opponents must eat.

d: Contest: who will eat least.
a: Food secretly furnished one, but plan detected and foiled.

d: Deceptive drinking contest.
Deceptive drinking contest: hole for water.
r: (Cf. +K81.1.) *Type 1088; Icelandic: MacCulloch Eddic 93; Indonesia: DeVries's list Nos. 49, 94.
a: The trickster lets the water run out through a hole; the dupe drinks himself to death.

d: Deceptive drinking contest: rising and falling tide.
a: Buffalo and heron wager as to which can drink the sea until the water falls. The buffalo drinks as the tide is coming in; the heron drinks in the falling tide and wins.

d: Attempted intoxication avoided by boring a hole in the bottom of cup.
Deceptive drinking contest: relative helpers.
Deceptive contest in drinking whisky.
a: The man drinks water, the devil is given vinegar.

d: Deceptive drinking contest: pretended swallowing.
a: One bullock keeps mouth in water. Other drinks self to death.

d: Deceptive scratching contest.
Scratching contest: man's wife shows wounds.
a: The man sends his wife to meet the ogre with whom he is to have a scratching contest. She tells the ogre that her husband has gone to have his nails sharpened. She shows him deep wounds that her husband has scratched on her body (obscene). The ogre leaves in terror.

d: Scratching contest with devil: man's wife shows scratches in her oak table.
Contest in scratching skin off each other: covering self with several ox-hides.
Deceptive vocal contests.
Contest in shrieking or whistling.
Contest in seeing.
Contest in hearing.
Deceptive laughing contest.
Laughing contest: dead horse winner.
a: The ogre tries to laugh as long as the dead horse with a grinning mouth. Laughs till he dies.

d: Other contests won by deception.
Cursing contest.
a: Arrow sent as a curse.

d: Gambling contest won by deception.
Gambling contest: coin which attracts fly first to win.
a: Winning coin had been rubbed on a pear.

d: Game won with loaded dice.
Girl distracts opponent's attention so that gambling lover wins.
Finger-drying contest won by deception.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 14; U.S.: Baughman; North Carolina: Brown Collection I 701; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: Three daughters are to wet hands; the first to have hands dry is to be the first to marry. The youngest waves her hands, exclaiming, "I don't want a man!" She wins.

d: Duel won by deception.
Boar in duel with tiger cakes mud on body: defeats tiger.
Combat won by means of substituted weapons.
Beauty contest won by deception.
Beauty contest won by deception: other contestants covered with leaves.
Deceptive bargains.
Sale of pseudo-magic objects.
r: French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 23; Missouri French: Carriire.

d: Pseudo-magic treasure-producing objects sold.
Alleged gold-dropping animal sold.
r: *Type 1539; BP II 10ff.; Penzer V 5 13; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: Coster-Wijsman 26 No. 5.

d: Alleged bill-paying hat sold.
r: *Type 1539; BP II 10; *Fb "hat" IV 202b; India: Thompson-Balys; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 196, 443.

d: Pseudo-magic wealth-providing bag sold.
Pseudo-magic formula for making gold sold to king.
a: Gold required for its manufacture carried off by manufacturer.

d: Pseudo-magic food-producing object sold.
Alleged self-cooking kettle sold.
"Soup stone" sold.
a: It needs only the addition of a few vegetables and a bit of meat.

d: Alleged soup-making pot sold.
a: It already has the ingredients in it.

d: Sale of pseudo-magic cake tree.
Pseudo-magic resuscitating object sold.
r: *Type 1535, 1539; BP II 10; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 275.
a: Dupe kills his wife (mother) and is unable to resuscitate her.

d: Seven devils' wives imitate ritual of death and resuscitation done over hero;  not having the real water of life and death, the seven enemy devils are killed.
Alleged resuscitating bone sold.
Alleged resuscitating whistle sold.
r: (Cf. +D1225). *BP II 10; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 99; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 196; N. A. Indian: *Thompson CColl II 422ff.

d: Alleged resuscitating book sold.
Alleged resuscitating wand sold.
Alleged resuscitating fiddle sold.
Alleged resuscitating knife sold.
Alleged resuscitating horn sold.
Alleged resuscitating bugle sold.
Pseudo-magic oracular object sold.
Alleged oracular cow-hide sold.
Alleged oracular horse-hide sold.
Alleged oracular bird-skin sold.
Alleged oracular pill sold.
Virtue of oracular pill proved.
a: The dupe takes it. "It is dog's dung," he says and spits it out. The trickster says that he is telling the truth and demands pay.

d: Sale of alleged oracular bamboo cup.
Pseudo-magic healing objects sold.
Alleged healing letter sold.
a: Woman sold a letter to wear around her neck which will prevent eye trouble. It helps only so long as she believes in it.

d: Alleged healing letter (charm) sold: to aid in childbirth.
a: Actually works. When opened it contains nonsense.

d: Pseudo-magic letter is found to contain insulting remarks.
Pseudo-magic charm (letter): to ward off plague.
a: Obscene contents.

d: Pseudo-magic letter (charm): to aid in engendering offspring.
a: Obscene contents.

d: Alleged healing stone sold.
a: A sailor boy sells a seasick Jew "Babylon stones" as a cure. They are pieces of coal.

d: Pseudo-magic potion: to induce pregnancy.
a: Found to contain snake's eggs.

d: Alleged rejuvenating object sold.
Betrayal through pretended fountain of youth.
Alleged rejuvenating stick sold.
Alleged inexhaustible vessel sold.
Alleged inexhaustible bottle sold.
Sale of tree with alleged magic fruit.
Sale of tree alleged to produce clothes.
Sale of other pseudo-magic objects.
Alleged automatic object sold.
Fishing-rod alleged to take fish to fisherman's home.
Sale of reputed self-operating sickle.
Pseudo-magic acorns: to protect holder's pigs.
Sale of false treasure.
Lime (ashes) sold as gold.
Sale of gilded mudcakes.
Sale of gilded (plated) ware as gold or silver.
Trickster, as watchman, exchanges worthless bag for bag of gold at night.
Sale of worthless animals.
Animal sold as messenger.
Rabbit sold as letter-carrier.
r: *Type 1539; *BP II 10; Ktshler-Bolte I 323; *Herbert III 35; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: Alleged to be a swift deliverer of letters.

d: Alleged speaking hare sold as messenger.
Bird sold as messenger.
Wolf sold as a goat (sheep).
r: Types 1535, 1539; *BP II 10; Ktshler-Bolte I 323; Missouri French: Carriire.

d: Wild animal sold as watch-dog.
Wolf sold as watch-dog.
Bear sold as watch-dog.
Deceptive horse-sale.
Horse which will not go over trees.
r: Salesman tells buyer that he is selling the horse because it eats too much and will not climb trees. *Wesselski Bebel I 133 No. 33; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 112; England: Baughman; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *1631.

d: The horse swifter than the rain.
a: Caught in the rain, a trickster finds that his horse will not budge. He undresses, puts his clothes under the horse's belly and keeps them dry. When he reaches the king, he reports that his horse has run so fast that he has had no time to get wet. The king buys the horse.

d: Trickster grooms master's old mule and then sells him back without detection at huge profit.
Trickster in disguise regains possession of his own horse by trading with man whom he has duped once before.
Owner trades a blind horse.
a: He gives a description that is literally correct.

d: Selling or trading a balky horse.
Person trades a dead horse.
Trickster temporarily lames valuable horse and buys him for trifle.
Pseudo-magic animals sold.
Pseudo-magic dog (goat) sold.
Dog (goat) alleged to swallow cold.
a: Said to swallow up the cold so that if he is near, one may sleep comfortably in the cold.

d: Dog alleged to chase hare and bring it to hunter's home.
a: Dupe deceived.

d: Sale of dog supposed to excrete sweet dung: dupe deceived.
Sale of dead buffalo by making him seem alive.
Alleged speaking animal sold.
Two jars full of live black wasps sold as interpreters of foreign language.
Parrot knowing only two words sold as speaking foreign language.
Other worthless animals sold.
Animals made by magic exchanged for real ones.
a: The magic animals disappear.

d: Sale of other worthless objects.
Deceptive exchange: useless for magic object.
Sale of a sausage filled with blood.
Sale of worthless glass as diamond.
Sale of dung.
Pot of cow dung covered with cheese sold as cheese.
Exchange of alleged ghee (liquid butter) for goat (cow).
Pus from sore sold as ghee.
Earthen pot with rice water on top of which clarified butter had been poured sold as a pot of clarified butter.
Mud sold as fresh butter.
Worthless fruits (plants) sold.
Green plantains sold as matured plants.
Cheaters sell each other valueless articles.
Sale of worthless objects miscellaneous.
Trick exchange: basket of stones for one of bread; a few pieces of money shown through slit in basket-cover to dupe.
Sale of worthless services.
A beggar tells the bishop how to stay warm.
a: For a gulden he tells him that he should wear all his clothes when he goes horseback in winter.

d: Thief masked as devil bought off by frightened owner.
r: Type 1525; Scotch: Campbell-McKay No. 11; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3442, Legends Nos. 859f.

d: The backwards and forwards dance.
a: Dupe persuaded to pay for learning this dance (really moving toward and away from a fire).

d: Trickster feigns ability to influence the sun; sells services.
a: Sun to shine on fools' backs as they go to town in morning and return in afternoon.

d: Fraudulent permission sold.
Man collects toll fraudulently, stamps "Brass Gate" on receipts he gives.
a: People think this is some Government phrase.

d: Trickster persuades dupe to sacrifice animal and give it to him as payment for supposed services.
Deception through pseudo-simple bargain.
Deceptive partnership between man and ogre.
Deceptive division of profits.
Giant cheated in division of spoils of the chase.
Jackal cheats other animals of elephant they have killed together.
Deceptive crop division: above the ground, below the ground.
r: (Cf. +J242.8.) *Type 1030; *BP III 355, 363 n. 1; **J. Hackman "Sagan om sktsrdelningen" Folkloristika och etnografiska studier III 140ff.; *Krohn "Bar (Wolf) und Fuchs" JSFO VI 104ff.; W'nsche Teufel 70ff.; Taylor PMLA XXXVI 58 n. 34; *Ktshler-Bolte I 69; **Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 193a, 593b; *Fb "rshd". Danish: Kristensen Danske Sagn I (1892) 441, (1928) 271; Swiss: Jegerlehner Oberwallis 324 No. 161; Missouri French: Carriire; Spanish Exempla: Keller; India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda; West Indies: Flowers 497; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 441, 447ff.; American Negro: Parsons JAFL XXX 175.
a: Of root crops the ogre (stupid animal) chooses the tops; of other crops the roots.

d: Deceptive grain division: the corn and the chaff.
r: *Type 9B; *Dh IV 249ff.; *Krohn "Bar (Wolf) und Fuchs" JSFO VI 97ff.; Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 193b.
a: The bear chooses the chaff because of its greater bulk. At the mill the fox's grain makes a different sound from the bear's.

d: Deceptive nut and olive division: inside and outside.
a: The clever man chooses the kernel of the nuts and the outside of the olive.

d: Deceptive sacrifice of nuts and dates.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 80 (ET 456), 103 (ST 164); Halm Aesop No. 315.
a: Trickster sacrifices only the shells of the nuts and the inside of the dates.

d: Deceptive division of pigs: curly and straight tails.
a: All with curly tails belong to the trickster, others to the dupe.

d: Deceptive division of animals for shearing.
a: The trickster shears the sheep; the dupe the pig.

d: In dividing the fish, the dupe gets the bones.
Deceptive division of shared wife.
a: Evil takes lower half of wife, Good takes upper half. Child begotten by Evil not permitted to nurse the top half which belongs to Good.

d: The common cow and bull: one gets front of cow and back of bull.
Deceptive division of sheep.
a: Evil chooses lambs, leaving milk to Good. Lambs drink up all milk.

d: Barber's and jackal's common garden: jackal pretends that garden has not yielded any fruit at all.
Monkey cheats fox of his share of bananas.
a: Climbs on a tree and tosses peelings down upon fox.

d: Anger bargain.
r: *Types 650A, 1000; *BP II 293; *Fb "nzhse" II 716a, "vred" III 1195b; Ktshler-Bolte I 327; Irish myth: *Cross, Breton: Sibillot Incidents s.v. "domestique"; Missouri French: Carriire; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 240; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 433f.; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 113.
a: The trickster makes a bargain with his master that the first to become angry must submit to punishment. He thereupon heaps abuses on his master till the latter breaks out in anger and must take his punishment.

d: Anger bargain: may God give you a penny.
a: A servant and his mistress agree that when they are angry with each other they shall say, "May God give you a penny!" When the master says this, the servant says, "May he give you two!" They keep increasing the amount till those who hear wonder at the performance. The mistress tells them, "You don't know the coin."

d: Deceptive bargain: as much bread as he wants to eat.
a: The baker fixes his price at the rate for twenty loaves. The trickster eats thirty.

d: Deceptive bargain: a sack of corn as reward.
a: Trickster has an enormous sack made.

d: Deceptive bargain: as much grain as will go in a rope.
a: Trickster encloses whole crop.

d: Deceptive bargain: three wishes.
a: The ogre is to fulfill three wishes of the peasant. The latter wishes for all the tobacco and brandy in the world and then some more brandy in addition. The devil must admit failure.

d: Deceptive bargain: first to say "Good morning."
a: The first to give the greeting shall have the disputed property. The trickster is early on the scene and witnesses the other's adultery. He may keep the property without saying good morning.

d: First to greet the other in morning will lose beauty contest.
a: Dispute is to be settled thus.

d: Deceptive bargain: fasting together.
r: Danish: Kristensen Jyske Folkeminder VII No. 30; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1568A*.
a: The servant girl eats secretly; the miser starves.

d: Deceptive bargain: felling the tree.
a: The ogre and the trickster agree to fell a large tree. The trickster purposely dulls his axe on a stone and then asks the ogre to exchange. Rather than work with a dull axe, the ogre does all the work.

d: Deceptive bargain: a peck of grain for each stack.
a: The man who is to receive this share of the crop makes very small stacks.

d: Deceptive bargain: an ox for five pennies.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 462; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 188 No. 370; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *2449.
a: A woman who has been left the ox on condition that she give the proceeds to the poor offers it for five pennies, but it must be bought along with a cock at twelve florins. She gives the five pennies to the poor and keeps the twelve florins.

d: Small niche in house brings large price.
a: House sold reserving niche. This becomes such a nuisance that buyer pays heavily for it.

d: Deceptive bargain: the ogre and the copper coins.
a: Every time the copper coin is paid out, the ogre must make a new one. The man buys an extensive property and pays with a large number of copper coins. He threatens to buy another and the ogre goes back on his contract.

d: Deceptive land purchase.
a: (Dido.)

d: Deceptive land purchase: ox-hide measure.
r: *Type 2400; *Basset Revue d'ethnographie et des trad. Icelandic: Gering Islendsk Zhventyri (Halle, 1883) II 92ff., Herrmann Saxo II 656, Boberg; French: Sibillot France IV 111, 180, 214; Estonian: Loorits, Some Notes on the Repertoire of the Estonian Folk-Tale, Tartu 1937, 23ff.; Greek: Aly Volksmdrchen bei Herodot 114, 117; Egyptian: Legrain Louqsor sans les Pharaons (Paris, 1914) 64; N. A. Indian (Wyandot): Barbeau GSCan XI 271 No. 91.
a: As much land bought as can be surrounded by an ox-hide. The hide is cut into very small strips.

d: Deceptive land purchase: as much land as Vishnu can lie upon (or can step over in three steps).
a: His worshippers claim for him the whole earth.

d: Deceptive land purchase: boundary fixed by flight of a goose.
a: Subject given as much land as a goose can fly over without lighting. The man carries the goose with its wings extended over an enormous territory.

d: Deceptive land purchase: as much land as a shawl will cover.
r: Harou RTP XXIII 169; Java: Bezemer Fabelen en Legenden 216ff.
a: An immense shawl prepared.

d: Deceptive land purchase: as much land as can be covered by saint's hood.
a: Only by snatching up hood does seller prevent it from covering whole territory.

d: Land grant: as much land as can be covered by saint's mantle.
Deceptive land purchase: bounds fixed by a race.
a: One man has supernatural speed.

d: Deceptive land purchase: bounds fixed by throwing object (axe, spear).
a: Thrower has extraordinary strength.

d: Deceptive land purchase: as much land as can be surrounded in a certain time.
Land bargain: land surrounded by a horse (cow) in one day.
r: Fb "ride" III 52b; Harou RTP XIV 90; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Land bargain: land ridden around during a sermon.

Deceptive land purchase: king, as reward for help in winning battle, promises wounded chieftain as much land as his chariot can travel around;  bribes charioteer to turn back whenever chieftain faints from loss of blood.
Land purchase: as much as can be plowed (fenced) in a certain time.
r: *Fb "plove" II 850a, "ride" III 52b; cf. Olrik Danske Studier (1910) 4ff.; Icelandic: Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 446b nn.

d: Deceptive land purchase: fields that crackle when burnt are to be his.
a: He puts bamboo on the fields before they are burnt so that they crackle.

d: Deceptive land purchase: as much land as can be shadowed by a tree.
r: Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia: L. de Backer L'Archipel Indien (Paris, 1874) 334.
a: Bought just before sunset.

d: Deceptive land purchase: enough to raise certain plant.
r: Indonesia: Snouck Hurgronje De Atjihers (Leiden, 1893) II 84.
a: This is a rapidly spreading weed which overruns the country.

d: Deceptive land purchase: saint's enemy promised as much land as he can see from certain point.
a: Saint causes cloud to obstruct vision.

d: Land grant: as much land as can be seen on a clear day.
Land grant: as much land as can be seen from certain eminence.
Deceptive land bargain: saints agree that the one who casts his staff far enough to reach distant island shall be owner of land.
a: Staff of one contestant transformed to spear (or dart) and so alone reaches island. When saint touches weapon, it becomes staff again.

d: Land grant: as far as ox can be heard.
Deceptive bargain with ogre: buying trees.
a: Trees to be neither straight nor crooked.

d: Strokes shared.
r: *Type 1610; **Reinhard JAFL XXXVI 380; *BP I 62; *Basset 1001 Contes I 321; Ktshler-Bolte I 495; *Chauvin V 282 No. 166; *Wesselski Mdrchen 202 No. 13; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 614; Hibbard 80 n. 3; Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 161 No. 122. English: Wells 161 (Sir Cleges); Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: The boy promises the soldier what the king has promised to give him. The soldier receives a beating in place of the boy.

d: Stealing only a small amount.
r: Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 146 No. 1800A; West Indies: Flowers 498.
a: A man promises in confession to steal only a small amount. He steals a rope with a mare on the end of it.

d: Peace between sheep and wolves.
a: As hostages the dogs are handed over to the wolves; the young wolves to the sheep. The wolves then attack and kill the sheep.

d: The man helps the horse against the stag.
r: Wienert FFC LVI *71 (ET 356), 108 (ST 208); Halm Aesop No. 175; Herbert III 9; Crane Vitry 182 No. 110; Jacobs Aesop 208 No. 33.
a: The horse must agree to be saddled and bridled. The man then refuses to release him.

d: Deceptive bargain based on an unusual name.
"Old Saddle" granted by the king.
r: Anderson FFC XLII 360; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *925.
a: This is the name of an estate, which the king unwittingly gives away.

d: Bargain: if the sun reverses its course.
a: Because of an eclipse the sun is held to have done so, and Atreus becomes king.

d: A ribbon long enough to reach from ear to ear.
a: The rascal has had an ear cut off and this is in a distant city.

d: Selling by trickery: literal bargain.
Buying foxes "as they run".
a: Man sells three hundred foxes to buyer who agrees to "take them as they run": reds, silvers, crosses. He gets a large payment to bind the bargain, waves his hand at the woods: "I sold them as they run; and they're running."

d: The tall hog.
a: Man boasts of hog so big that a man could not reach its back if he holds his hand as high as possible. A stranger buys the hog, sight-unseen. The seller takes him to the hog, shows the buyer that the hog's back is much below his hand when he holds it as high as possible.

d: Trickster lends bamboo on condition that it is returned exactly as it is.
Until the log burns out: time given servant for Christmas holidays.
a: Soaks the log so that it burns a week.

d: Cheater is forced to eat excrements.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1533*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1529 I*; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 324f.
a: Gentleman agrees to exchange his good horse for the peasant's jade, provided the peasant will eat its excrements. The peasant finds no difficulty in the task, whereas the gentleman, put to the same condition when he wants to get back his horse, finds it impossible.

d: Other deceptive bargains.
Deceptive bargain: as much gold in reward as sticks to poet's hair when poured over him: he smears it with tar.
Deception in payment of debt.
Devil cheated of his promised soul.
r: Irish: Beal XXI 312f., O'Suilleabhain 34, 36; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3390, Legends Nos. 490f., 749f.; Missouri French: Carriire.
a: The man saves it through deceit.

d: Devil cheated by imposing an impossible task.
Devil is cheated by giving him task: counting the letters in the church Bible.
a: He is unable to read the holy words.

d: Devil cheated by being frightened.
r: *Type 1145 1154; Irish: Beal XXI 311, O'Suilleabhain 33; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Man whispers in devil's ear that his wife is approaching with her broom again.
Devil pounded in knapsack until he releases man.
Devil's magic power turned on himself.
a: The hero who is riding the devil as a horse receives supernatural strength from plucking a hair from the devil's mane. He then spurs the devil until he agrees to forego his bargain for the man's soul.

d: Devil cheated by pretended hanging.
a: The man has promised himself to the devil in return for money. He stuffs his clothes with straw and hangs them up. The devil thinks the man has hanged himself and is satisfied.

d: Devil to release man for performing seemingly impossible task.
a: The task is performed by trickery.

d: The evil woman in the glass case as the last commodity.
a: The man is to belong to the devil as soon as he has sold his goods. If he has any goods that no one will buy, he is to be free. The man puts an evil old woman in a glass case. When the devil sees her, he recognizes her. "Whoever knows her will refuse to buy her." The man goes free.

d: Bringing the devil an unknown animal.
r: *Type 1091; *BP I 411, III 358; *Fb "pige" II 816a, "kjende" II 140, "tjzhre" III 811a; Lithuanian: Balys Legends Nos. 755f.
a: The man sends his naked wife on all fours in tar and feathers. The devil has never seen such an animal.

d: Guessing name of devil's secret plant.
a: The man's wife in tar and feathers overhears the devil tell the secret name of the crop he has discovered (tobacco). The devil says to the supposed animal, "Get out of my tobacco!"

d: Not to sleep for three successive nights.
a: The sleepy man: "I am just thinking, that on earth there are more crooked trees than straight ones ... more hills than plains ... more water than land ..." The devil goes to ascertain these things, meanwhile the man sleeps. Unsuccessful imitation by another man.

d: Devil gets another soul instead of one bargained for.
a: The devil bargains with a man for his soul, but the man fulfills his contract and escapes. In envy two persons commit suicide. The devil rejoices that though he lost one he has gained two.

d: Devil cheated by religious or magic means.
Devil cheated by having priest draw a sacred circle about the intended victim.
r: Type 810; Irish: Beal XXI 309, O'Suilleabhain 30; Scotland: Baughman.

d: Devil cheated of his victim by boy having a bible under his arm.
Devil cheated when his victim becomes a priest.
r: *Type 811*; Lithuanian: Balys Legends No. 423; Russian: Andrejev No. 811.

d: Devil cheated of promised soul by intervention of Virgin Mary.
The picture of the Virgin Mary saves the priest.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3268, Legends No. 410ff.

d: Penance of priest saves him from devil.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3267, Legends Nos. 405 409.
a: The priest, who sold his soul to the devil, orders his servant to cut him (alive) up into pieces, to crucify him on a tree (and the like), thus saves his soul from the devils.

d: Devil is unable to take man contracted to him when friends pray over the corpse.
Other ways of cheating the devil of his promised soul.
Devil cheated of his promised soul by making the intended victim drunk.
a: The devil may punish the drunk man's body but has no power over his soul.

d: Devil cheated of his promised soul when the victim sells his to a comrade.
a: The latter says, "The devil can take only one soul from each person. I bought the soul so that when he comes I can give him one and still save my own."

d: God cheats the devil of his promised soul.
a: The devil is to fill a cask full of money. God knocks the bottom out of the cask.

d: Devil is to get soul of man whether he is buried "inside or outside of church, above or below ground."
a: The man has himself buried in the wall of the church, partly in and partly out of the ground.

d: Man cheats devil by giving him sole instead of soul.
Devil gets an animal in place of a human being.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3285, Legends Nos. 472, 489.

d: Devil gets a flea instead of man's soul.
Payment precluded by terms of the bargain.
Payment to be made at harvest of first crop.
r: *Type 1185; cf. 1184; Danish: Kristensen Danske Sagn III (1895) 382; German: Schambach und M'ller Niedersdchsische Sagen und Mdrchen No. 170.
a: The man plants acorns.

d: Payment to be made when last leaf falls.
r: *Type 1184; *BP III 14, 200; Dh I 179; *Krappe Balor 154ff.; *Fb "djzhvel" I 189a, "lshv" II 518; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 152 No. 79.
a: The last leaf never falls from the oak tree.

d: The level bushel.
a: The student is to come into the devil's power if at the end of a year he does not at least return for the heaping bushel of gold a level one. The student forthwith hands back the level bushel and keeps the surplus.

d: To owe sixteen florins.
a: Horse bought on condition that the buyer pay ten florins and owe sixteen. In court the buyer insists on the bargain and shows that if he pays the sixteen florins which he owes he will break the bargain, for then he would no longer owe.

d: The debt will be returned to the devil when the pigs walk instead of run home.
Other deceptions in the payment of debt.
Debtor refuses to pay his debt.
Refusal to perform part in mutual agreement.
Mutual agreement to sacrifice family members in famine.
r: Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 109; India: *Thompson-Balys; Africa: Meinhof 200, (Ekoi): Talbot 337, (Nigeria): Tremaine FL XXI 492, (Vandau): Curtis Songs and Tales from the Dark Continent (New York, 1920) 44; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 230ff.
a: Trickster refuses to carry out his part of the bargain.

d: Mutual agreement to divide food.
r: Christiansen FFC XXIV 46; India: *Thompson-Balys; West Indies: Flowers 501.
a: Trickster eats other's food and then refuses to divide his own.

d: The dog refuses to help the wolf.
a: A farmer plans to kill a faithful old dog. The wolf makes a plan to save the dog. The latter is to rescue the farmer's child from the wolf. The plan succeeds and the dog is rewarded. The wolf in return wants to steal the farmer's sheep. The dog refuses his assistance.

d: Reward for accomplishment of task deceptively withheld.
r: Irish myth: Cross; Greek: Fox 81, 94 (Herakles); India: Thompson-Balys; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G.

d: Dancers given one coin instead of ten and have this taken away.
a: Interpreter says they are complaining that the coin is bad.

d: Refusal to make sacrifice after need is past.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 78f. Bolte) No. 305; Spanish Exempla: Keller; India: *Thompson-Balys; West Indies: Flowers 501.
a: In distress a person promises a sacrifice to a god (saint) but disregards the promise when the danger passes.

d: Sailor offers saint a candle as large as a mast.
a: But he knows that after the storm he will not try to find such a candle.

d: Golden lamb promised to goddess.
a: Common lamb sacrificed.

d: The sacrifice of the cock is at last carried out.
a: Postponed until a hawk carries off the cock. Then the woman says, "O holy St. Martin, I have long owed you a living sacrifice. Take the cock as sacrifice, and may it be pleasing to you."

d: Horse withheld as sacrifice to a saint refuses to move.
a: The deceiver takes the horse to the church planning to remove him again, but the horse will not stir until a money equivalent has been paid.

d: Sick man offers deity 100 bulls for recovery.
a: When reminded that he does not own so many bulls he explains that he doesn't expect the deity to come to enforce payment.

d: Payment of money to the devil impossible, since debtor learns that the devil is dead.
Debt with worthless bond repudiated.
A man bonds his loyalty.
a: When the debt is due he offers the creditor his loyalty.

d: Hogs used as a mortgage collateral.
a: (Ground hogs.)

d: False offer to return goods in place of payment.
Milk bought on credit poured into one container.
a: The trickster buys it from various women. After it is all poured together he says that each may have her own back.

d: Order to put a small vessel of milk into huge container.
a: Shrewd group each by himself pours water thinking this will not be detected if the others pour milk.

d: Trickster gets strong drink by trickery in returning goods.
Trickster returns a bottle of water instead of the bottle of rum he has just purchased.
Trickster fills his gallon jug half full of water, then has it filled with rum at the store.
a: When seller refuses credit, he pours back half gallon of the liquid now half rum and half water. Sometimes trickster repeats operation, getting richer mixture with each transaction.

d: Debtor tells creditor that he has had his reward in the hope of payment.
Toad receives water from frog; refuses earth in return.
Servant refused payment because of single mistake.
Man refuses to pay murderer for killing and kills him.
Fish promised in return for bacon.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *1634; Russian: Andrejev No. *2104.
a: Later: "Drink up the river, you shall then have fish. All the fishes there are mine."

d: Debt to be paid "tomorrow".
a: Tomorrow never comes.

d: "Come tomorrow".
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1183*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1183*.
a: The devil keeps calling daily until the gate with the inscription rots. He then claims his debtor.

d: Agreement to leave sum of money on coffin of friend.
a: One puts on his share in cash; other makes out a check for the total amount and takes cash left by the other.

d: To pay beggar for standing in tank all night.
a: Beggar sees lights in temple. Payment refused since beggar has thus warmed himself.

d: Trickster cheats by pretending deafness.
a: Palm rat, when asked to throw down nuts according to bargain, replies that he is deaf when eating.

d: Refusal to return borrowed goods.
r: Africa (Ekoi): Talbot 68, 375, (Hottentot): Bleek 50 No. 24, (Benga): Nassau 198 No. 29; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 349 No. 61.

d: By using verse with double meaning man appropriates borrowed goods.
One day and one night: object borrowed for a day and a night retained.
Fairy (god?)
a: loses stronghold by consenting to lend it for "a day and a night."

d: Trickster escapes without paying.
Bird has new clothes made: flies away without paying.
r: Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 37 No. 244; India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda.

d: Drinkers argue about who is to pay.
a: They blindfold the bartender who is to catch one of them; the one who is caught will have to pay. While the bartender is blindfolded, the drinkers leave the tavern.

d: Boots made by two cobblers.
a: Trickster sends one of each pair back to be stretched, leaves town with pair of boots made up of the remaining boots.

d: Man orders a bottle of beer, then returns it and takes a loaf of bread instead.
a: He refuses to pay for the bread because he has returned the beer undrunk. He refuses to pay for the beer because he has not drunk it.

d: Jackal refuses payment for being carried.
Healer to take payment in satisfaction at patient's recovery.
Goods received on partial payment.
a: Buyer refuses to pay more.

d: Woman promises marriage for pair of earrings: she escapes with them.
Trickster summons all creditors at once, precipitates fight, and escapes payment.
King promises valuable dog to each of two powerful and mutually hostile tribes.
a: At feast prepared by king the two tribes get into fight and king escapes.

d: Creditor killed or driven away.
Fox is promised chickens: is driven off by dogs.
Husband promises a cow to tiger; wife frightens the tiger away.
Thor is to give his hammer in return for Freyja as wife.
r: *DeVries Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsche Taal- en Letterkunde XLVII 293ff.; Icelandic: Boberg.
a: He masks as a woman and kills the giant who is to receive the hammer.

d: Man cheats devil of reward: to have man if he gets him at first grasp.
a: Man holds cat which flies in devil's face.

d: Conquered warrior kills victor instead of paying.
Literal payment of debt (not real).
Fifty ships promised.
a: Forty-nine are moulded out of earth.

d: Drinking only after a bargain.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 306; Scala Celi 81a No. 463; *Crane Vitry 255 No. 277; Herbert III 24.
a: A woman having thus sworn keeps buying and selling the same mule many times a day.

d: Tribute paid in enchanted snow.
a: After payment, snow takes proper form.

d: Saint ransoms prince for much gold and silver.
a: Later all the money vanishes. Saint replies that since the money had been created from nothing, it had simply to return to that state.

d: Literal fulfillment of marriage contract.
a: Man to be released when earth is placed at his head (buried). Dies in grave.

d: Trickster disguises himself and escapes notice of creditors.
Deceptive respite in payment obtained.
Creditor to wait till debtor is shaved.
a: The debtor refuses to finish shaving.

d: Man who owes 1000 ducats has his creditor arrested for owing him ten.
a: Thus he hopes to postpone payment of his own debt.

d: Refusal to tell about the Rhine treasure, though condition demanded is fulfilled when the only one who knows where it is is killed.
The castration bargain: wife sent.
a: The trickster castrates the dupe and is to come the next day and be castrated himself. He sends his wife as substitute.

d: Creditor falsely reported insane when he demands money.
r: *Wesselski Arlotto II 225 No. 92; Gonnella 98 No. 2; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1525L*; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: King promises beggars new clothes: burns their old and gets much gold and silver.
a: Keeps it.

d: Death feigned to avoid paying debts.
Customer takes invitation to buy as invitation to receive the goods free.
Payment evaded by setting countertasks.
Deceptions in payment of debt miscellaneous.
Devil loses his grain and gets thistles.
a: God grants the devil one grain crop, which he can create by calling its name. The devil is tricked into forgetting the name and calling "Thistles". Hence his crop is of thistles.

d: Payment of the egg-white.
a: A man dreams of an egg hanging under his bed. An interpreter demands half of what he finds as his fee for interpreting the dream. The man finds that the egg is a silver cup filled with gold crowns. He gives the interpreter part of the cup but none of the gold. The interpreter says, "He gave me some of the egg-white but none of the yolk."

d: Pseudo-magic money-dropping ass beaten to death by buyer; cheat says: "Return my ass, I shall return your money."
Payment in worthless goods which are alleged to be valuable goods transformed.
Other deceptive bargains.
Deceptive damage claims.
The eaten grain and the cock as damages.
r: *Type 1655; *BP II 201; *DeVries Volksverhalen II 381 No. 145; India: Thompson-Balys; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 176 No. 24; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII *262 No. 63.
a: A trickster has only a grain of corn; this is eaten by a cock, which he demands and receives as damages. Likewise when a hog eats the cock and the ox eats the hog.

d: Trickster demands return of food guest has just eaten: gets damages.
Damages claimed for loss of a charm.
a: Princess lets trickster's fly (alleged to be a charm) escape.

d: Damages for supposedly lost horse.
a: Horse concealed by owner in loft of stable at inn.

d: Damages for accidentally broken water pot: to pay for elephant.
Payment to lame man who claims that man's father lamed him.
Selling oneself and escaping.
Deceptive sale of another as slave.
Profitable league made with both parties to a quarrel.
Goods misappropriated.
Dog as wolf's shoemaker eats up the materials.
a: Devours the cow, hog, etc. furnished him.

d: Trickster eats sacrifice offerings.
Exorbitant price demanded and received.
Charging thirty cakes for cooking twenty-five.
Crab demands seven patas as payment for four patas of paddy frog has borrowed.
Crow demands young swan in payment for helping swan find feed for its young.
Camel has offered one pound of flesh to jackal for help.
a: Camel's tongue demanded.

d: Deceptive wages.
Deceptive wages: as much rice as will go on a leaf.
a: Lotus leaf used.

d: Deceptive wages: two grains and land to plant them on.
a: Grain multiplies and takes up all of dupe's land.

d: Stolen property sold to its owner.
Trickster steals farmer's cow and then sells her to the farmer.
Merchant buys the same article several times from the same or different seller.
The price of a lump of gold.
a: A trickster asks a goldsmith what he would pay for a lump of gold of a certain size. Believing that the man has such a lump, the goldsmith pays him a large sum.

d: The price of mink skins.
a: Man asks peddler what he pays for mink skins. Peddler says he will pay ten dollars. The man tosses a skin into the cart, receives ten dollars. The next day the peddler protests that the man has sold him a cat skin. The man says that he had not said that the skin was a mink skin and that, anyway, the cat's name had been "Mink."

d: The priest made sick of his bargain: three words at the grave.
a: A poor man in return for a steer gets permission from the priest to speak three words at the burial of his enemy, the rich man. Priest: "From earth are you come." Man: "Now the steer is dead." Priest: "In earth shall you remain." Man: "Father, do you want the meat?" Priest: "I wish you were in hell!" etc.

d: Devil is made sick of his bargain.
a: Devil helps shepherd boy become a minister on condition that he mention Satan by name each time he enters pulpit. Boy consents but does so in such a way that devil begs to abolish the agreement.

d: Agreement not to scratch.
a: In talking the trickster makes gestures and scratches without detection.

d: Deceptive wager.
Deceptive wager: whose horse will jump highest.
a: The trickster has his worthless horse jump out the window. The duke will not let his run the risk.

d: Deceptive wager: cat to carry lantern into room.
a: (Has been specially trained.)

d: The fee used up before the main question is reached.
a: A man with an unsolved question seeks the help of a wit. The latter refuses to answer unless paid. He takes small fees for each easy question leading up to the principal question. Before reaching that point the fee is exhausted, and the question remains unanswered.

d: New bags for old!
r: *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 201 No. 393; Chauvin V 64 n. 1.
a: Recovery of the old bag (containing money or having magic power) which the stupid wife has given away. The husband exchanges a new bag for it.

d: Counting out pay.
a: Hole in the hat and hat over a pit.

d: Dupe denied food until hands are clean.
r: Africa (Zezuru): Posselt Fables of the Veld (London, 1929) 110 (Northern Rhodesia): Worthington The Little Wise One (London, 1930) 25ff., (Nyanja): Rattray Some Folk-Lore Stories ... in Chinyanja (London, 1907) 145f.
a: Grass burned around food makes continued washings unavailing.

d: Trickster sells what is not his to sell.
Man contracts for load of hay on the road (without making any payment), orders the seller to deliver it at a certain inn.
a: He then goes to the inn, sells the hay to the innkeeper, and pockets the money. The owner of the hay delivers it at the inn, tries to collect at the inn; the trickster absconds.

d: Trickster persuades girl to reveal hidden gold by promising to make it into ornaments.
To keep first thing touched.
a: Wealth (or woman) is on platform. First thing touched is ladder leading up.

d: Reduced prices but false weights.
Watered milk sold.
Thefts and cheats general.
Stolen cows cause a war.
Master thief.
r: *Type 1525; *BP III 379; *Fb "stjzhle" III 575b; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 850; Werner Zs. f. Vksk. Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; French Canadian: Sister Marie Ursule; Missouri French: Carriire; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Italian: Basile Pentamerone V No. 7; Greek: *Frazer Pausanias IV 192; India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia: DeVries Volksverhalen II 385 No. 157; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 71f.; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 349 51, 446f.; Africa: Weeks Jungle 43, (Duala): Lederbogen JAS IV 65, (Cameroon): Lederbogen 129f.
a: Man undertakes to steal various closely guarded things. Succeeds by cleverness.

d: Youth learns robbery as a trade: boasts of it.
r: *Type 1525; BP III 379ff.; Missouri French: Carriire; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Family of thieves.
Female master thief.
r: *BP III 36; Chauvin V 245 No. 147; Japanese: Ikeda.

d: Courtesan runs away with men's goods.
Nations of thieves.
Contest in stealing.
Thieving contest: first steals eggs from under bird; second meantime steals first's breeches.
Friends enter into stealing contest.
a: Steal from each other.

d: Youths execute a series of clever thefts.
Thieves steal from each other.
The stolen and restolen ham.
r: (Cf. +K341.7.1, +K362.4.) *Gering Islendzk Zhventyri (Halle, 1883) II 210ff.; *DeVries Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsche Taal; en Letterkunde XLV 213ff.
a: Two thieves steal a ham from a former companion who has married, have it stolen back, and resteal it.

d: Highjacking.
a: Thief robbed of his booty.

d: Man is robbed of gold chain while with prostitute.
a: He swallows her string of pearls in revenge.

d: Blind man steals from neighbor who in turn steals from him.
Thieves betray each other.
One thief hides in money bag; other carries it off.
One thief entrusted with other thieves' money cheats them.
Youngest brother surpasses elder as thief.
Means of entering house or treasury.
Thief in disguise.
r: French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 23; Missouri French: Carriire; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Thief dressed half white, half black.
a: His father's corpse is guarded by twenty knights in black and twenty in white. By disguising he steals back the corpse.

d: Thief disguised as corpse.
a: In the shroud of the supposed dead man is hidden another robber.

d: Sham dead man brought in sack by confederate.
a: Is killed by his intended victim.

d: Thief disguised as angel.
Thief disguises voice and is allowed access to goods (children).
r: Type 123, BP I 37ff.; Africa (Kaffir): Theal 118, (Zulu): Callaway 144, (Basuto): Jacottet 62ff.; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 236ff.

d: Thief becomes monk in order to rob monastery.
Thief disguised as yogi.
Thief disguised as demon.
Thief takes form of animal.
Robber disguised as bear is killed.
Man allows himself to be carried off by monkeys, who mistake him for cow: steals their magic cups.
Thief disguised as parrot.
Magician transforms self into crocodile to steal.
Thief disguised as pig.
Thieves disguised as interior decorators.
a: Steal hangings in palace.

d: Theft by disguise as son of owner.
Thief disguised as owner's wife.
Thief in disguise as long lost son-in-law.
Thief pretends to be girl's bridegroom and calls for her.
Thief in clothes of owner.
Theft by disguise as owner's grandmother.
Thieves disguised as fine gentlemen steal provost's purse.
a: Are admitted to court without question.

d: Theft by disguising as palace official.
Thieves disguised as musicians.
Thief disguised as menial.
Thief disguised as owner's cook.
Theft by disguise as woman servant.
Theft by disguise as barber.
Theft by disguise as merchant (or peddler).
Thief in disguise as god.
Thief disguised as girl.
Thief disguised as old woman.
Thief in the clothes of robbed bride kills bridegroom.
Thief disguised as beggar.
Thieves hidden in oil casks.
r: *Type 954; *Penzer I 133 n. 1; *Fb "kiste" II 134; Chauvin V 83 n. 3; *Basset 1001 Contes II 302; *Wesselski Archiv Orientblnn II 432; Missouri French: Carriire; Africa (Ekoi): Talbot 391.
a: In one cask is oil; in the others the robbers are hidden. The girl kills them.

d: Thief hidden in cage that is carried into house.
Entry by master thief into closely guarded city in wood-gatherer's basket.
Trickster feigns being pursued by drunken husband to obtain entrance.
Thief enters treasury through secret passage.
Underground passage gives entrance to closed chamber.
r: Italian: Basile Pentamerone I No. 2; Jewish: Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Thief enters treasury through passage made by him as architect of the building.
r: *Type 950; *BP III 394; Ktshler-Bolte I 200; *Chauvin VIII 186; **Huet RTP XXXIII 1, 109, 253; *Frazer Pausanias V 176ff.; Penzer V 245, *X 285; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Thief bores hole in house wall, then introduces blackened pot as a feeler.
Thieves enter palace through hole in wall and abduct new bride.
Theft through chimney.
Theft from giant by fishing through chimney.
Thief copies key by making wax impression.
r: Swiss: Jegerlehner Oberwallis 312 No. 68; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Thief enters by burning off locks.
Entrance into wine cellar by removing lock during absence of mother.
Watchdog enticed away.
a: Trickster brings rabbit under his coat. When the king's watchdog gives chase the trickster enters and robs.

d: Thief learns location of dupe's food supply by strewing ashes.
r: Africa (Benga): Nassau 155, 204 Nos. 19, 32, (Ekoi): Talbot 57, 62, (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 51 No. 6, 83 No. 13; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 248 No. 24; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 12ff.
a: Fills the dupe's bag with ashes and cuts a hole in the bag.

d: Girl made to carry shell from which ashes fall: she is thus followed.
Theft of gold hoard by spying on secret hiding place.
Thief pretends to return grass that has stuck to his clothes to ground where it belongs.
Theft by use of coat of invisibility.
Thief feigns illness to be taken in victim's house.
Means of hoodwinking the guardian or owner.
Man gulled into giving up his clothes.
r: N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 332 n. 199 (occurs in most versions).

d: Goods stolen while owner sleeps.
r: Missouri French: Carriire; India: Thompson-Balys; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 350; Cook Islands: Beckwith Myth 270; West Indies: Flowers 503.

d: Sleeping with open eyes.
a: The man claims to sleep thus and beguiles the ogre into sleeping, so as to rob him.

d: Owner put to sleep and goods stolen.
r: Dickson 63, 67 n. 13, 68 n. 15; Irish myth: Cross; Welsh: MacCulloch Celtic 107; Finnish: Kalevala rune 42; India: *Thompson-Balys; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G.
a: Magic or drugs.

d: Master thief puts watchers to sleep and cuts off their hair.
Theft after putting owner to sleep by lousing her.
Master thief puts guards to sleep and steals meat.
Guards fatigued by trickster so that they sleep while goods are stolen.
Worthless object (animal) substituted for valuable while owner sleeps.
Mouse's tail in mouth of sleeping owner causes him to cough up magic object.
r: India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Kordofan): Frobenius Atlantis IV 134ff.

d: Trickster steals magic doll while owner is asleep.
The foolishly concealed money: A man hangs a bag of money in the top of a high tree.
a: Servant sleeping with him steals it.

d: Thief lies down in the space between the king's and the queen's bed and steals jewelry from both.
Theft by making owner drunk.
r: *Type 1525A; BP III 379ff.; Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 850; Irish myth: Cross; India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda; Africa (Ekoi): Talbot 297.

d: Theft by giving narcotic to guardian of goods.
r: India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 225.

d: Theft from blind person.
r: India: *Thompson-Balys; Oceanic (New Zealand, Tahiti, Mangaia, Hawaii, Melanesia, Micronesia, Indonesia): Dixon 46, 59, 65; Maori: Clark 160; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 230; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (T-G.

d: Blind Dupe.
r: Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges; Eskimo (Greenland): Rasmussen III 78, 202; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 354 n. 278.
a: A blind man's arrow is aimed for him by his mother (or wife) who deceives him into thinking that he has missed his aim. She eats the slain game herself.

d: Theft from three old women who have but a single eye among them.
a: The hero seizes their eye.

d: Buzzard steals coyote's eyes, while he is throwing them up in the air.
r: N. A. Indian (Klikitat): Jacobs U Wash II 36.

d: Blind beggar overheard telling that his money is kept in a stick.
a: Thief exchanges sticks.

d: Theft by blinding with pepper.
Owner gives up goods through flattery.
The raven with cheese in his mouth.
r: *Type 57; *Basset RTP VI 244 n. 4; Crane Vitry 172 No. 91; Wienert FFC LVI 52 (ET 121), 97 (ST 115); Halm Aesop 204; *Chauvin III 76 No. 49; Jacobs Aesop 202 No. 8; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 17 No. 11. Spanish Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys; Korean: Zong in-Sob 29 No. 12.
a: The fox flatters him into singing, so that he drops the cheese.

d: Goat induces the camel to talk and meanwhile eats all the food.
Thief frightens owner from goods.
r: Type 1166**; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Graham; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 303 n. 109b; Africa (Ibo, Nigeria): Basden 278, (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 52 No. 6, (Wakweli): Bender 63; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 98 No. 20, Nights 61 No. 12.

d: Owner frightened from goods by report of approaching enemy.
Owners frightened away from goods by report of deadly epidemic.
a: Poor parson thus rids himself of unwelcome guests; they leave food they have brought.

d: Thieves steal pig and make it impersonate person with plague.
a: Owner and family flee.

d: Trickster quarrels with owner of goods, feigns death, and frightens owner away.
Owner frightened away from goods by a bluff.
Dupe, made to believe that trickster becomes a wolf when he yawns three times, flees and leaves his clothes behind him.
Porcupine, made to believe that rabbit's ears are horns, flees and leaves food behind.
r: Africa (Nuba): McDiarmid Sudan Notes and Records X 229f.

d: Owner frightened from goods by apparitions of the dead.
Thief places candles on crabs (bugs).
a: When they are turned loose in the churchyard the parson and the sexton think that they are the souls of the dead. Meanwhile the thief steals from them.

d: Thief frightens priest as the latter crosses cemetery.
a: Meanwhile a confederate steals his chickens.

d: Owner frightened from goods by trickster's ferocious animal.
r: Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 388 No. 14.
a: Pretended dog is really a lion.

d: Thief frightens away guards of his father's corpse by impersonating demons.
Town crier is frightened by the voice of a cleric robbing a grave.
Delivery boy is frightened into giving up his chickens.
a: Trickster upturns his eyelids and puts on boar's tusks.

d: Trickster lights torches and bluffs old woman into giving him money.
a: Torches alleged to belong to man coming to collect damages from her.

d: Servants frightened by ferocious actions of robbers;  give up masters' food.
Owner frightened away by thief disguised as devil.
Owner frightened from goods by trickster's summons of wild buffalo herd.
Robbers frightened from goods.
r: Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 211 No. 428, 215 No. 446; Missouri French: Carriire; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: Trickster steals the goods.

d: Frightened robber leaves his coat behind.
r: Chauvin II 83 No. 5; Bshdker Exempler 273 No. 6.

d: Object falls on robbers from tree.
a: They flee and leave money.

d: Door falls on robbers from tree.
r: *Types 1650, 1653; *BP I 520; *Ktshler-Bolte I 71, 99, 337, 341; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 182 No. 345; *Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 194; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 350; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 306; N. A. Indian (Malecite): Speck JAFL XXX 484.
a: They flee and leave money.

d: Cow-hide falls on robbers from tree.
a: They flee and leave money.

d: Person falls from tree on robbers.
a: They flee and leave money.

d: Robbers frightened from goods by the dead.
Corpse thrown among robbers frightens them from treasure.
Robbers frightened from goods by sham-dead man.
r: Type 1654**; DeVries Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsche Taal- en Letterkunde XLV 213; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 211 No. 429; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1654*, 1654A; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 1654*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1654*; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 130 No. 1532, 137 No. 1654*, 142 No. 1716*; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Graham.

d: Robbers frightened from goods by man's outcry.
a: Trickster hits a slain ox and cries out, "Those others did it!" The thieves flee and leave their treasure.

d: Animals climb on one another's backs and cry out; frighten robbers.
Animals cry out; frighten robbers.
Robber frightened from his goods by playing of bagpipe.
Robbers frightened from goods by hidden man.
Thieves steal chest containing hidden paramour.
a: Are frightened away by his outcry.

d: Robbers frightened from goods by Thumbling.
a: They can hear him but cannot see him.

d: The thief in the beehive.
a: Other thieves come to steal the bees, take the heaviest hive to the forest and make a fire under it. They flee when they hear a man screaming in the beehive.

d: Guardian beast overcome by hero's mirrors.
Robbers frightened from goods by man in tar and feathers.
Robbers coming to steal from stable frightened away by bear staying the night there with his keeper.
Robbers frightened by pretended cannibalism.
a: Tricksters threaten to cook a robber. All the robbers flee in terror, leaving them their booty.

d: Sons of thief frightened by threatening to bring the three strongest men to punish them.
Thieves frightened by ghosts who tie fruits to their hair, which they think are missiles thrown at them.
House filled with smoke so that owner gives trickster lodging.
Fire set to village so that robbers can steal goods.
Trickster fills house with smoke so that partner cannot see to eat.
Oversalting food of giant so that he must go outside for water.
a: Meantime his goods are stolen.

d: Thief sends owner for water in leaky basket.
r: N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 87.

d: Thief ties owner's hair while he escapes with goods.
Owner's interest distracted while goods are stolen.
r: Type 15*; Lithuanian: Balys Index Nos 1525J, 2425, 2436*; India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda.

d: Trickster reports lost money; searchers leave him in possession of premises.
r: *Wesselski Arlotto I 203 No. 34; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: Unable to find a place by the inn fire the trickster mentions that he has lost money on the road. One by one the guests slip out to search and leave him the fire.

d: Thief shams death and steals.
r: Types 1, 1*; India: Thompson-Balys; S. A. Indian (Apapoc'va-Guarani); Mitraux MAFLS XL 112.

d: Animal feigns death repeatedly and then entices owner from goods.
r: Japanese: Ikeda; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 72 No. 15; (North Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXX 172, (Virginia): Bacon and Parsons JAFL XXXV 275f.; Andros Islands, Bahamas: Parsons MAFLS XIII 10 No. 8.

d: Thief shams sickness and steals.
Man feigns sickness in order to go back to steal hidden gold.
Thief distracts attention by apparently hanging (stabbing) himself.
r: *Type 1525D; *BP III 391 n. 1; Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 850; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1525H*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1525CI*; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 129 No. 1525A.

d: Thief persuades owner of goods to dive for treasure.
a: Meantime robs him.

d: Owner persuaded to climb tree while goods are stolen.
Owner of horse climbs tree after thief, who drops down and rides off on owner's horse.
Owner enticed to chase game while goods are stolen.
Theft of horses (cattle) by letting loose a rabbit so that drivers join in the chase.
Partridge pretending to be wounded entices woman from food while jackal eats it.
Shoes dropped to distract owner's attention.
r: *Type 1525D; *BP III 390 n. 2; Missouri French: Carriire; India: *Thompson-Balys; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 160 No. 22; Andros Islands, Bahamas: Parsons MAFLS XIII 11 No. 9; Antigua, British West Indies: Johnson JAFL XXXIV 74 No. 33; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 86 No. 28.
a: The thief drops two shoes in different places and steals a ram while the shepherd goes after the shoes.

d: Animal's cry imitated to distract owner's attention from his goods.
a: Meantime rascal steals an animal.

d: Baby's cry imitated to distract owner's attention from his goods.
Cattle let loose so as to distract owner's attention from his goods.
Cat made to mew so as to distract owner's attention from his goods.
Golden deer sent to entice girl's guardians away, so she can be abducted.
Thief pretends to show how horse can be stolen; rides it off.
Trickster pretends to ride home for tools to perform tricks.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1532*; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 1528*; Rumanian: Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 1332*.
a: Rides away on horse.

d: Thief pretends to horse dealer that he wishes to buy a horse.
a: Dealer allows him to climb on horse to see how he rides; thief runs off with horse.

d: Thief shows knife-maker use of purse-cutting knife: cuts his purse and robs him.
King loses signet ring while endeavoring to learn from a thief the art of stealing.
Thief tells his pursuer that the thief has gone to heaven by way of a tree.
a: While the man lies on the ground and looks up, the thief steals his horse.

d: Thief persuades owner to take his place so he can go and catch thief: really steals owner's horse.
Trickster bribes guards to start a fight.
a: While the master goes to investigate, the trickster enters his bed with his wife.

d: Owner's attention distracted by man fishing in street.
a: Meanwhile the man's confederates rob the dupe.

d: Guard (owner) sent to see a cat which fishes for her master.
a: Goods stolen in his absence.

d: Trickster falsely announces marriage celebration and distracts owner's attention.
Tailor throws piece of cloth out of the window.
a: The stingy woman has the tailor come to her house to cut cloth. He throws a piece out of the window, "the devil's share". While the woman has gone after it he cuts off a piece for himself.

d: Master thief pretends to throw needle and thread in anger at his son.
a: But it contains stolen cloth.

d: Thief steals belongings of his wife's paramour while the latter is calling on her.
One thief distracts attention of owner while other steals.
Thief steals pastries while confederate makes a purchase.
Stone thrown to attract attention of shark guardians.
a: Man then slips in cave and steals lobsters.

d: Trickster entices children to dance and steals their food.
Thieves ask nurse maid to dance while they steal prince.
Helpful animal amuses princess with tricks and secures key to treasury.
Trickster poses as entertainer: steals meat while host assembles friends.
The story about theft.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1525J*; Russian: Andrejev 1525II*; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: One thief steals, the other relates the situation, in the form of a tale, to the gentleman who is being robbed.

d: The dance of the thief.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1629*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1525 II*.
a: While singing and dancing in the farmer's house, the thief gives hints to his friend in the loft, how to steal the bacon.

d: The supposed magic spell.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1629*; Italian Novella: Rotunda (+K341.16); India: Thompson-Balys.
a: The thief orders the farmer to crawl into a tub and to sit there quietly and not look about, while he makes a magic spell (cure him of childlessness). Meanwhile, he steals all the farmer's property.

d: Fire set in order to distract attention.
r: India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Duala): Lederbogen JAS IV 65.

d: Man stands on pillory to attract attention.
a: Confederate picks pockets of men who come to jeer.

d: Fox drops goldsmith's child to get him away from gold bench he is working on and thus steal gold.
Partridge plays hide-and-seek with girls while fox eats the curds they are taking to market.
Trickster starts argument and steals from arguers.
Miser enticed from his money by report of "money tree".
Man lures fox-husband of girl away by means of cock-decoy and runs away with the girl.
Thief as umpire in contest.
r: Chauvin V 91 No. 196, 212 No. 121; India: Thompson-Balys.
a: Three men are quarreling over the possession of a rescued girl. The umpire will give her to the one who soonest returns with the arrow he shoots. While they run, he takes the girl.

d: Thief advises owner to go away; meantime steals the goods.
r: Africa (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 69 No. 10.

d: Innkeeper deceived into going under the floor of the granary; meantime robbed.
Owner sent on errand and goods stolen.
r: Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 110; India: *Thompson-Balys; Africa (Fjort): Dennett 77 No. 17; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 77 No. 1, Nights 241 No. 41; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 251 No. 29, 255 No. 36; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 97; West Indies: Flowers 505.

d: Bread dropped in mud; messenger returns for more.
a: A youth poses as a rich man's servant and gets a sack of bread from a baker. The baker boy is to go along and collect. The rascal drops two loaves in the mud and sends the boy back for fresh ones. Meantime he runs off with the rest of the bread.

d: Theft by reporting relative's sickness.
a: Woman falsely told that her father is wounded leaves her water pot with jackal.

d: Thief advises that slaughtered meat be hung up over night.
r: Africa (Zulu): Callaway 6; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 123 No. 23.
a: Meantime he steals it.

d: The stingy parson and the slaughtered pig.
r: *Type 1792; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 790; Lee Decameron 257f.; Taylor MPh XV 226.
a: The stingy parson does not want to give any one a part of his pig, which he has just slaughtered. The sexton advises him to hang the pig up in the garden over night so as to make everyone think that it has been stolen. The sexton steals it himself.

d: Thief advises that new cloth be hung in the open overnight.
a: Steals it while owner sleeps.

d: Companion sent away so that rascal may steal common food supply.
r: India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Cameroon): Gantenbein 70; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 128 No. 24, 230 No. 39, 280 No. 47, Work JAFL XXXII 403, (Virginia): Smiley JAFL XXXII 368, (South Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXXIV 8, MAFLS XVI 31f.; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 109 No. 38.

d: Monkeys lure tortoise into a tree and carry away his load of salt.
Cheat induces dupe to go get food reported found and steals clothes as soon as they are left behind.
