Owner persuaded that his goods are spoiled.
r: (Cf. +K355.) Bshdker Exempler 292 No. 50; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 123 No. 23.

d: Trickster gives a woman a knife to cut him a slice of white bread.
a: He gets the whole loaf when he says that he has just cut a dog with the same knife.

d: The polluted fish.
a: Servant places his one fish with Brahmin's entire catch; receives all since Brahmin considers all polluted.

d: The "spoiled" anchovies.
a: Servant eats all of master's anchovies. When master asks for some, the servant brings in a covered dish, and tells him that the fish smell very bad. The master tells the servant to throw them away.

d: Trickster cuts up partridges with his knife.
a: He is given all of them when he tells his companions that he is an executioner.

d: Trickster puts filth in food.
a: May take it all.

d: Spoiling the rice-field with dung.
a: Dupe persuaded that the dung has spoiled the field. He gives the field to the trickster.

d: Son-in-law steals father-in-law's pants by making latter believe he has dirtied them.
Sympathetic helper robbed.
Sympathetic helper sent for remedy and robbed.
r: Africa (Benga): Nassau 86 No. 4, (Thonga): Junod 221, (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 386 No. 12.

d: Thief sent into well by trickster.
r: Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 346a n. 126; BP III 392f.; Wienert FFC LVI 84 (ET 502), 106 (ST 183); India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: A weeping boy tells a passing thief that he has lost a silver cup in a well. The thief takes off his clothes and goes after the cup, intending to keep it. He finds nothing. When he comes up, his clothes have been stolen.

d: Dupe left to care for child while his goods are stolen.
Antelope sends leopard for fire, eats game while leopard is gone.
r: Africa (Kiyansi): Van Whig Biblioteca Africana IV 52.

d: Thief trusted to guard goods.
r: Bshdker Exempler 279 No. 21; Spanish Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Wute): Sieber 191; West Indies: Flowers 505.

d: Thief guards his pursuer's horse while the latter follows a false trail.
r: *Type 1540; **Aarne FFC XXII 3-109; *BP II 440; Berber: Basset Contes Berbires (Paris, 1887) I 114; India: Thompson-Balys.
a: Steals the horse.

d: King persuaded to change clothes with thief disguised as old woman.
a: Thief rides king's horse away.

d: Herdsman slaughters animals entrusted to him.
Woman persuaded to go after her forgotten comb.
a: Goods stolen by guard.

d: Thief trusted to guard shawls during prayers.
a: Steals them.

d: Cloak as surety that owner will return.
a: Thief runs away with it.

d: Thief takes mistress's ornaments across river on pretense of keeping them safe, and then deserts her.
Cozening.
a: Trickster's claim of relationship causes owner to relax vigilance. Goods stolen.

d: Prostitute claims to be intended victim's daughter.
a: Robs him.

d: Trickster causes owner and another to fight over goods.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 48 (ET 71), 119 (ST 293); Halm Aesop No. 247; Panchatantra III 10 (tr.
a: Meantime he steals it.

d: Trickster permitted to try on clothes.
a: Goes away with them.

d: Trickster persuades tailor to leave his goods.
r: Nouvelles Ricriations No. 23; Pierre Faifeu No. 21; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: Makes him believe he will get order to clothe fifty poor. Trickster makes away with goods. (Or tries on boots and makes away with them.)

d: Thief borrows cloak so to carry food.
a: Disappears with it.

d: Trickster permitted to try on ornaments.
a: Goes off with them.

d: Theft by posing as doctor.
a: Trickster advises wife to slaughter pig and have the trickster eat it all.

d: Theft by posing as magician.
a: Trickster claims to be working magic spell over food and eats it.

d: Trickster asks hospitality: expels owner and appropriates house.
Crow asks hospitality of sparrow and gradually takes possession of nest and kills young.
a: (Often told of camel and tent.)

d: Trickster pollutes house so that he is left in possession.
r: American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 26 No. 6; Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 84, Edwards MAFLS III 74; West Indies: Flowers 504.
a: He is in upper room and throws filth on those below (Cf. +K344.)

d: Trickster pretends to have spit in wine accidentally.
a: Is allowed to drink it.

d: Tricksters feign death of their father.
a: Collect rent and flee.

d: Pickpockets strike man on leg so that he takes his hand off his purse.
Signal for theft given in foreign language.
Means of hoodwinking guardian or owner miscellaneous.
Theft by means of magic invisibility.
Thief beguiles guardian of goods by assuming equivocal name.
Thief of sweetmeats says his name is Fly.
a: Child shouts to father, "Fly is eating," etc. "Never mind the fly, guard against the cow."

d: Trickster dupes woman into putting him into basket.
a: He thus learns where food is kept.

d: Crow makes friends with pigeon so as to be able to steal food in household to which he belongs.
Objects stolen by means of magic impersonation.
Other means of theft.
Theft by disobeying orders: misappropriation.
Jackal ordered to take meat to lion's family takes it to his own.
Man calling self "her husband" abducts child.
Tricksters eat up food given them for bear.
a: Escape.

d: Man eats up food given him by tiger as bait for deer.
Monk entrusted with care of getting husband for girl, takes dowry himself.
Uncle entrusted with niece's patrimony slanders her so marriage will be broken off and he will not have to part with her money.
Covetous husband desiring wife's jewels tells her he has vowed to offer them to deity.
Theft by presenting false order to guardian.
r: *Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 126 No. 109; India: *Thompson-Balys; Africa (Ibo, Nigeria): Basden 274; West Indies: Flowers 506-8.

d: Unique weapon got by misrepresenting to guardian use to which it is to be put.
For the long winter.
r: *Type 1541; *Fb "tosse" III 832a, "pshlse" II 907b; BP I 521, 526; Christensen DF L 46; *Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 194 n. 3; Icelandic: Sveinsson FFC LXXXIII No. 1541.
a: The numskull has been told to keep the sausage "for the long winter". When the trickster hears this, he claims to be Long Winter and receives the sausage.

d: Ring to put on corpse's finger.
r: *Type 1525A; BP III 379; Missouri French: Carriire; Jewish: Neuman.
a: A thief holds a corpse up to a lord's window. The lord shoots the corpse and leaves to bury it. The thief goes to the lady and gets a sheet to bury the corpse in and a ring to put on his finger.

d: The cup to be repaired.
r: *Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 126 No. 109; Scala Celi 101a No. 543; Mensa Philosophica No. 56; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: A thief poses as a messenger from a husband to his wife asking that a certain silver cup be sent for repairs.

d: Stealing the platter for the intended gift.
a: Thief asks for silver platter saying that it is needed for an intended gift of confections. Servant carrying platter is told to wait until it is filled. Thief disappears with it.

d: Theft by posing as master of the house and learning where goods are hidden.
a: Wife deceived in the dark.

d: Hare in lion's skin gets meat from lioness.
Fox drinks the milk of a tiger's mate by giving her a misleading message.
r: S. A. Indian (Chiriguano): Mitraux RMLP XXXIII 180.

d: Deposit money secured by false order to banker's wife.
r: Jewish: Bin Gorion Born Judas II 245.
a: When banker refuses to redeliver deposit the owner presents false tokens to wife.

d: Theft by forgery: signature forged to obtain money.
Clerk mistranslates order given by master to maid, so that pie goes to clerks.
The hood for the robe.
a: Thief steals lawyer's scarlet robe. Later he returns and tells lawyer's wife that her husband had sent him for the hood for the robe. He obtains the hood and escapes.

d: Give him what he wants.
Hero reports to king that his ancestors (in heaven) want him rewarded with gold.
Partner misappropriates common goods.
Theft by confederate.
r: Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 130 No. 1525G*; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Benga): Nassau 160 No. 20; West Indies: Flowers 508.

d: Confederate allows self to be sold as slave.
The thieving guests.
a: Rent a room at an inn and empty the mattresses of feathers, take fire wood, etc. Throw goods out of the window where confederate picks it up.

d: Theft by wife's paramour.
a: Wife tells him secret of buried money.

d: Theft by trickster's trained animal.
Thief feeds stolen money in flour to animal, then asks for ass.
Thieving cow.
Cow makes a hundred-fold return.
r: *Type 1735; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 324; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 25; *Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 167 No. 129.
a: The trickster has a cow that leads the parson's cows to him. He thus tests the parson's text, "He who gives in God's name shall have it back a hundred-fold."

d: Cow enticed away by calf.
a: Brothers are given the choice of a cow or a calf. One chooses the cow and thinks that he has the best of the bargain. The cow longs for the calf and returns to it.

d: Self-returning cow.
a: A cow allows itself to be sold; then returns to its master.

d: Animal shams death and is sold.
a: Returns to master.

d: Cows turned into rice field.
a: Later made to disgorge rice.

d: Thieving bird.
Thieving ant.
Thieving dog.
Speaking goat swallows gold coins in temple and voids for master.
Thieving turtle.
Thieving butterflies.
Thieving octopus.
Trickster hides in food and eats it.
r: India: Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 57, Coster-Wijsman 35 No. 16; Africa (Thonga): Junod 209.

d: Trickster throws fish off the wagon.
r: *Type 1; BP II 116; Dh IV 225, 304; Krohn Bdr (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 46ff. Lappish: Qvigstad Lappiske Eventyr II 3, III 3; Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 115; Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 438; Africa (Hottentot): Bleek 16 No. 8; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 17 No. 4, 306 No. 52, (South Carolina): Parsons MAFLS XVI 39, Stewart JAFL XXXII 395, (Virginia): Parsons JAFL XXXV 276; Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 10.
a: The fox plays dead; a man throws him on the wagon of fish. The fox throws the fish off and carries them away.

d: Playing godfather.
r: *Type 15; BP I 9; Dh IV 241; *Krohn Bar (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 74ff.; *Fb "rzhv" III 113b, "bjshrn" IV 43b; *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 238. Lappish: Qvigstad Lappiske Eventyr III No. 3; French: Sibillot France III 63f.; Missouri French: Carriire; Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 19; New Mexican Spanish: Rael Hispania XX 231 4; Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 437; Africa: Frobenius Atlantis III 13, (Fjort): Dennett 90 No. 23; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 80 No. 17, Jones Negro Myths from the Georgia Coast (Cambridge, Mass., 1888) No. 24, (Virginia): Parsons JAFL XXXV 253 55, (North Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXX 192f., (South Carolina): Parsons MAFLS XVI 7 12, JAFL XXXII 394, XXXIV 3; Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 1; Bermuda: Parsons JAFL XXXVIII 240.
a: By pretending that he has been invited to be godfather, the trickster makes an opportunity to steal the provisions stored by him and the dupe for the winter. When he returns on successive occasions he reports the name of the child as "Just Begun," "Half Done," etc.

d: Trickster eats food left by tiger (his trapping partner) at snare.
a: Tiger accused of the theft.

d: "Owner has refused to accept it."
a: A rascal steals a priest's watch. He tells the priest that he has stolen a watch and offers it to him as a payment for a past favor. The priest refuses to accept stolen goods. Commands the thief to return the watch to the owner. "But the owner has refused to accept it." "Then you may keep it."

d: Trickster pretends to teach dance: flees with valuables.
Thieves steal chickens and have mock funeral to cover theft.
The thieving kiss.
a: Trickster kisses pile of money, taking some in his mouth with every kiss.

d: Fire stolen by swallowing it and then escaping.
Host robs guest.
Thief escapes detection.
Blame for theft fastened on dupe.
Thief accuses his companion of having stolen the gold they have both stolen.
Dupe's food eaten and then blame fastened on him.
r: *Type 15; India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 21; Africa (Angola): Chatelain 173, 177, 179, (Zulu): Callaway 164, (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 366 No. 17, (Hottentot): Bleek 18 No. 9, (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 48 No. 5, (Basuto): Jacottet 10 No. 1, (Benga): Nassau 93 No. 4, (Kaffir): Theal 95, 96, 114, Kidd The Essential Kaffir (London, 1904) 384, (Fang): Tessman 57; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 80 No. 17, Friends 147 No. 20, (South Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXXVIII 222; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 238. See all references to +K372.
a: Trickster eats the common food supply and then by smearing the mouth of the sleeping dupe with the food escapes the blame.

d: Trail of stolen goods made to lead to dupe.
r: *Penzer V 61 n. 3; Bshdker Exempler 287 No. 37; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: The crane in revenge for the loss of her young ones strews pieces of fish from the dwelling of the mongoose to that of the snake. The mongoose follows the trail and kills the snake.

d: Stolen goods taken to dupe's house so that he is accused.
r: Icelandic: Boberg; Bshdker Exempler 303 No. 74; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Greek: Frazer Apollodorus II 178 n. 1 (Palamedes); Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 100.

d: Crow causes serpent to try to swallow a stolen collar and thus be accused of the theft.
r: Chauvin II 87 No. 23; Penzer V 47 n. 3, 214, 226f.

d: Necklace dropped by crow into snake's hole leads men to kill snake which had eaten the crow's fledglings.
r: Bshdker Exempler 281 No. 25; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Surreptitious transfer of stolen object to innocent person's possession brings condemnation.
r: India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 349, 892.

d: Stolen goods left in suitor's room.
a: Impoverished lover falsely accused so as to be rid of him.

d: Thief makes believe that he has been robbed of money entrusted to him.
Thief successfully accuses owner of having stolen property he covets.
The lamb without a heart.
r: *Type 785; *BP II 149, 153; Wienert FFC LVI 40, 107; Oesterley No. 83; Herbert III 205; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 57; Penzer V 130 n. 1; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: Accused of eating the lamb's heart, the thief maintains that it had no heart.

d: The goose without a leg.
r: *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 229 No. 75; Boccaccio Decameron VI No. 4 (*Lee 177); Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2424*; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 191; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys; West Indies: Flowers 508.
a: Accused of eating the goose's leg, the thief maintains that it had no leg, and cleverly enforces his point by showing geese standing on one leg. (Usually the master confounds the rascal by frightening the geese so that they use both legs)

d: The bird without a tail.
a: Thief maintains that the bird had no tail.

d: The ass without a heart.
a: The ass as toll-gatherer is killed by the lion for asking for toll. The fox eats the ass's heart. When the lion asks for it, the fox replies that the ass could have had no heart since he was such a fool as to ask the lion for toll.

d: Thief claims to have been transformed into an ass.
r: *Type 1529; *BP III 9, 391 n. 3; Chauvin VII 137; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 229 No. 487; *Basset 1001 Contes I 492; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 150 No. 1852*; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 437.
a: While the owner sleeps the thief steals his horse, hitches himself to the wagon, and claims that he is the horse transformed into a man.

d: Thief escapes by leaving animal's severed tail and claiming that the animal has escaped and left his tail.
Tails in ground.
r: *Type 1004; BP III 392 n. 1; *Fb "hale" I 537, "svin" III 676a; Icelandic: Sveinsson FFC LXXXIII No. 1004; Missouri French: Carriire; Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 110 No. 2; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 241; Africa (Vai): Ellis 249 No. 41; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 98 No. 20, Nights 230 No. 39, 241 No. 41, (Virginia): Smiley JAFL XXXII 368, (South Carolina): Parsons MAFLS XVI 31f., JAFL XXXIV 8; Bahama: Cleare JAFL XXX 228; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 252 No. 29; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 109 n. 2, 113.
a: Thief steals animals and sticks severed tails into the ground, claiming that animals have escaped underground.

d: Ox's tail in another's mouth.
r: Type 1004; *BP III 392 n. 2; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1525G*; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 1525G*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1525G*.
a: The thief kills one ox and puts the tail in another ox's mouth: the owner thinks one ox has eaten the other.

d: Stolen sheep's tails severed and put in tree.
a: Owner made to believe that they have escaped through the air.

d: Thief successfully claims that stolen goods are his own.
Grain-thief's wagon falls into ditch: duped owner helps him.
a: The thief makes the owner believe that the grain belongs to the thief.

d: The stolen pot pawned with the real owner.
a: The thief gets a receipt from the owner and thus defends himself when accused of theft.

d: Thief successfully claims that stolen image has been given him by the saint himself.
Stolen animal disguised as person so that thief may escape detection.
Stolen sheep dressed as person sitting at helm of boat.
Stolen sheep dressed as baby in cradle, so that thief may escape detection.
r: Whiting Speculum VII 552; Fb "lam" II 370a, "hundehvalp" IV 228b; *Baugh MPh XV 729; *Smyser JAFL XLVII 378; *Stroup JAFL XLVII 380, Southern Folklore Q. III 5f.; *Cosbey Speculum X 310ff.; Middle English: Second Shepherd's Play; Irish myth: Cross (+K521.1.3); Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 144 No. 1735B*.
a: (Mak.)

d: Stolen animal magically transformed so that thief may escape detection.
Severed limb prevents detection.
Thief has his companion cut off his head so that he may escape detection.
r: *Type 950; BP III 395ff.; *Krappe "Trophonios and Agamedes" Archiv f'r Religionswissenschaft XXX 228-241; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Greek: Grote I 122; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Companion's arm allowed to be cut off so as to prevent detection.
r: *DeVries Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsche Taal- en Letterkunde XLV 213ff.
a: Thief has had his arm cut off as he enters a hole in a wall. He lets his companion also enter and have his severed.

d: Thief's confederate cuts off own arm to furnish alibi for family's grief.
a: (Previously he had severed father's or brother's head to escape detection.)

d: Elephant cuts piece from own leg and puts it on shelf, lest he be accused of stealing meat.
The stolen cow successively pawned.
a: In one night a thief pawns a cow four times, always stealing it immediately and finally delivering it back to its owner.

d: Thief presents alibi.
a: Plays all night for dance while confederate commits actual theft.

d: Thief shams illness as alibi.
r: Africa (Yoruba): Ellis 271 No. 6, (Nago): Basset Contes populaires d'Afrique 217ff.

d: Detection of theft of bull escaped by putting boots on bull.
Thieves stretch chain across road and evade pursuers.
Quartered thief's body sewed together to escape detection.
Marked culprit marks everyone else and escapes detection.
r: *Type 950; BP III 395ff.; *Schoepperle I 214 n. 3; Boccaccio Decameron III No. 2 (Lee 62); *Penzer V 274f., 284, VII 36, 217ff.; *Chauvin V 83 No. 24 n. 2; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2440*; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 435; Africa: Werner African 223.

d: Many persons admit theft so that it is impossible to find real thief.
Repentant thief pretends to have found stolen cow.
a: Upbraids owner for not guarding her better.

d: Thief pretends to have recovered stolen horse.
a: Returns it to owner after using it all he desires.

d: Thief swallows stolen goods to escape detection.
Flower thief eats flowers to escape detection.
The owner is duped by thief who gives him the task of solving a riddle about the theft just accomplished.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1635*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1545*.

d: Thief escapes detection miscellaneous.
Thief cannot remember whom he delivered the goods to.
a: Though he has eaten the food trusted to him, he claims to have delivered it, but cannot remember the person who opened the door.

d: Thief avoids detection by disguising as a woman.
Umpire awards his own stolen coat to thief.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1525K*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1525 I*.

d: Stolen bacon offered to the owner.
a: Making off with bacon, thief accidentally enters farmer's living-room. Boldly says: "Master, the devil from hell sends you bacon." The farmer: "Take yourself off to hell with the bacon."

d: Thief paints horse black on one side and leaves other side white.
a: Hoodwinked guardians make conflicting report of theft.

d: Husks replaced in granary so theft of grain is unnoticed.
Goldsmith as thief in king's treasury.
a: Makes golden human figure and says it is a corpse. Gets by guards.

d: Thieves escape detection by carrying woman on bier and drowning her outcries with wailing.
Blame for theft fastened on inanimate objects.
Blame for theft fastened on fairies.
Thief loses his goods or is detected.
Robber mistakenly carries off worthless goods and leaves valuable.
Thief hoping to gain bigger booty, loses smaller.
Thieves directed to a hornet's nest as supposed money hiding place.
Two cheats exchange articles as genuine and both find themselves cheated.
Thief rendered helpless by magic.
Stolen object magically returns to owner.
r: Irish myth: *Cross. See all references to +D1602 and its subdivisions.

d: Stolen animal returns to owner.
Thief condemned when witnesses of theft are able to find the stolen goods.
King's daughter put into brothel to catch thief.
Apparently dead woman revives when thief tries to steal from her grave.
Clever animal betrays thief.
r: Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 48; West Indies: Flowers 509.

d: Clever animal betrays thief.
a: Horse catches arm of thief and holds on until help comes.

d: Magic statue betrays a thief by indirection.
a: He has threatened to smash the head of the magic statue if it betrays him. The statue says, "Whoever would tell the truth now is likely to have his head smashed."

d: Mouse's tail in mouth of sleeping thief causes him to cough up swallowed magic ring.
Person being robbed deceives robbers and calls help.
Clever woman being robbed makes excuse for screaming and summoning help.
Clever husband being robbed induces wife to make outcry and summon help.
Owner pretends to help burglars to divide booty: handles weights so loudly that police are summoned.
Child's curiosity exposes thief.
a: Thief steals pig. Slaughters it together with one of his own and takes both to market. Puts little pig inside large one to avoid paying tax on two. Boy notices three hind legs. Thief is caught.

d: Clever girl discovers robber and cheats him.
The girl seizes the robber concealed under the bed by the beard and says: "What a coarse bundle of flax.
a: I need a finer one."

d: Disguised robber in night-lodging tries to pull up confederate on rope: princess discovers him and catches him.
Girl tells the thief money is in chest.
a: When he looks in chest, girl drops lid on him.

d: Child's song incriminates thief.
r: U.S.: Baughman; West Indies: Flowers 509f.; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 235 No. 4, 239 No. 10.

d: Husband makes rhymes about cakes wife has stolen.
Blind thief trying to steal dates from withered tree killed by slipping of rope.
Robber overcome.
Robber cheated by substitution.
a: Spending the night in company with a suspicious-looking stranger, the man does not go to sleep, but leaves his clothes in bed and waits to see what will happen. When the stranger wakes up in the night, he stabs at his sleeping companion, who shoots him down.

d: Robber with hand of glory killed.
a: A robber disguised as a beggar gets night's lodging at a farm house. Using a candle made of human fat or hand of a corpse, he tries to charm the household into a deep sleep (+D1162.2.1). One man who is suspicious and has not gone to sleep sees this and kills the robber.

d: Sausage as revolver.
a: Man scares robber with sausage; later boasts of event at inn. Robber hears this. Innkeeper secretly lends man a real revolver; robber is shot down when boldly attempting a second attack.

d: Conqueror of robber discovers his money-stick.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 962*; Russian: Andrejev No. 961 I*.
a: Thinking that he has killed the robber, the man takes his stick or knife with big handle. The robber recovers and, disguised as a beggar, inquisitively looks at the stick. The man is suspicious and by examining finds much money inside it.

d: Robbers enslaved.
a: Youth told by two robbers to go to town and sell bracelet for each. He goes and offers to sell two slaves. Goes back with buyer and cries out "Did you say both?" "Yes." Youth is paid; robbers are enslaved.

d: Thief loses his goods or is detected miscellaneous.
Betrayal through exchange of stolen goods.
Thief claims that stolen goods are his own: detected by master.
Thief tricked into robbing himself.
r: Chauvin II 83 No. 7; Bshdker Exempler 273 No. 5; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: He has placed a coat on the goods to be stolen. His associate changes the place of the coat.

d: Thief leaves food untouched when owner pretends to be poisoned by it.
r: American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 54 No. 7, Nights 297 No. 50; Bahama: *Parsons MAFLS XIII 122; West Indies: Flowers 511.
a: (Playing poison.)

d: Sheep thief pretends to buy wethers from the ram, names the price himself.
a: Owner overhears, takes the ram to the thief to collect.

d: Robbers fed poisoned food.
Robber induced to give respite and come to man's office to get promised larger sum.
a: Cheated.

d: Tortoise asks greedy man to give him first ruby it has given him to be sure second one will be perfect match: disappears into water with it.
Owner pretends to think thief is family god and binds him.
Owner feigns madness and thus raises alarm: thieves captured.
Hidden person sees robbers concealing treasure and takes it.
Thief hides in large bottle to get into room: bottle put into water to boil.
Other cheats.
Double reward successfully claimed.
The double pension.
r: Chauvin V 274 No. 155 n. 1; India: Thompson-Balys.
a: A husband and wife are jointly under a pension from the king. She reports her husband dead and gets the whole pension. He likewise reports her dead and gets the whole money.

d: The doubly-feed lawyer.
r: *Herbert III 375 No. 23; Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 125; Scala Celi 20a No. 122; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: A lawyer takes a car as fee from a widow and an ox from her adversary. He pleads for the latter saying that the ox draws the car.

d: Dishonest notary invents debt and collects from both parties.
Fee from two persons for the same monopoly.
a: Man to furnish goods exclusively to animal. Bargains at same time with another to do the same thing.

d: Trickster collects from both husband and wife.
a: Estranged couple both pay him to effect reconciliation.

d: False claim of reward.
r: Africa (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 159 No. 31, (Ekoi): Talbot 387.

d: Reward offered for stolen object (princess).
a: Thief (abductor) returns and enforces reward.

d: Money (or other things) acquired by blackmail.
r: U.S.: Baughman; India: Thompson-Balys; West Indies: Flowers 512.

d: Hidden paramour buys freedom from discoverer.
Clever wife gets money from those who attempt to seduce her.
r: *Type 890; Cosquin Itudes 457ff.; Norwegian: Christiansen Norske Eventyr 113 No. 890; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: Payment for keeping silence.

d: Clever wife gets husband appointed to position occupied by man who attempts to seduce her.
Money exacted from watchers who permit goods to be stolen.
r: Japanese: Ikeda; Korean: Zong in-Sob 196 No. 95.

d: Money exacted from watchers who permit chest to be stolen.
a: The chest is said falsely to be full of money and the watchers subject to severe punishment.

d: Money exacted from watcher who permits theft of wooden cow supposed to be real.
Trickster entices wolves out of a stable by music: exacts money from their watcher for his carelessness.
Trickster exacts promise of marriage as price of silence after having seen a princess naked.
Trickster exacts beautiful wife from curious people.
a: They look into a carriage in which it is falsely said there is a princess. Trickster's dead wife is in the carriage.

d: Trickster exacts money as price of silence after lying with princess (queen).
Fox eats his fellow-lodger: accuses another and demands damages.
a: He spends the night with a cock in a house. He eats the cock but in the morning accuses the sheep of having eaten it. In the next inn likewise he says that the ox has eaten the sheep, etc. In compensation he demands a larger animal each time.

d: Priest induced to betray secrets of confessional: money then exacted from him for silence.
a: The trickster confesses that he has had intimacies with the priest's maid and then overhears the priest scold the maid.

d: Women lead man into intrigue and then shout for help.
a: Get money.

d: Rascal extorts money for silence about companion's poverty.
Usurer blackmailed.
a: Shrewd suitor persuades usurer to charge him 100 per cent interest, then has him arrested. Thus gets daughter for wife.

d: Princess has brought ill luck to bridegroom.
a: When palace and retainers disappear after wedding and only humble hut remains, clever fox tells king his daughter's feet have brought ill luck to the groom, his master. King gives half his kingdom in compensation.

d: Rascal extorts money for silence about breach of food tabu.
Dream bread: the most wonderful dream.
r: *Type 1626; **Baum JAFL XXX 378; *BP IV 139; *Dunlop-Wilson II 201; Basset 1001 Contes I 516; Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 95; Barbeau JAFL XXXII 178; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 243 No. 540; *Oesterley No. 106; Scala Celi 73a No. 415; Ward II 240; Herbert III 246; Alphabet No. 238; Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 22 No. 98; L. Schmidt Oesterr. Zs. f. Vksk. Icelandic: Sveinsson FFC LXXXIII No. 1626*; Russian: Andrejev No. 2100*; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 21; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda.
a: Three pilgrims agree that the one who has the most wonderful dream shall eat the last loaf. One eats it and declares that he dreamed that the others were dead and would not need it.

d: Egg as reward of appropriate saying.
r: Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 153 No. 1942; Japanese: Ikeda.
a: First brother (knocking egg against wall): "Casca cascorum." Second (breaking shell and sprinkling dirt over it): "Sar, sale, sapiensa". Third (eating egg): "Consumatus es."

d: Bag of cakes said to be full of cobras.
a: Boy eats cakes.

d: The bag with the rice for the road.
a: Boy eats rice and throws empty bag on the road.

d: The emperor's new clothes.
r: *Type 1620; **Taylor MPh XXV 17; *Chauvin II 156 No. 32, VIII 130 No. 120; *Wesselski Gonnella 133 No. 33; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys.
a: An impostor feigns to make clothes for the emperor and says that they are visible only to those of legitimate birth. The emperor and courtiers are all afraid to admit that they cannot see the clothes. Finally a child seeing the naked emperor reveals the imposture.

d: God to reveal self to those of legitimate birth.
a: All afraid to admit not seeing God.

d: Whoever hears singing snake must die.
a: Killed by deaf man.

d: The heller thrown into others' money.
r: *Type 1615; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 197 No. 387; Chauvin V 254 No. 151 n. 2, VII 153; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 566.
a: A rascal sees robbers dividing their booty. He puts a red string through his only coin (a heller) and slips it into the others' money. He claims the money as his and says that he has marked it with a heller having a red string through it. The robbers divide.

d: Half a grain.
a: Trickster drops half a grain into grain cellar then demands half of the grain supply.

d: Contraband gold discovered when king offers large price for gold.
Cheater marks coveted object with his name and later claims it.
Unjust umpire as trickster's confederate.
Unjust umpire decides a religious dispute.
r: *Type 613; *BP II 468ff.; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 489; **Christiansen FFC XXIV 46ff.; Jewish: Gaster Exempla 191 No. 29, Neuman; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 395.
a: His confederate thus wins an absurd wager.

d: The wager that sheep are hogs.
r: *Type 1551; *Clouston Tales II 27; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 632; *Penzer V 104; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 213 No. 437; Chauvin II 96 No. 51, VII 150 No. 430; *Oesterley No. 132; Crane Vitry 141 No. 20; Alphabet No. 766; Hazlitt Shakespeare Jest-Books II 176; Bshdker Exempler 295 No. 56; Missouri French: Carriire; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: A trickster wagers with a sheep driver that the sheep he is driving are hogs. The next man to overtake them will act as umpire. The trickster's confederate now arrives and declares that they are hogs.

d: Concealed confederate as unjust witness.
r: Chauvin II 91 No. 34; Bshdker Exempler 287 No. 36; Penzer V 59 n. 2; Edgerton JAPS XL 271; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: A rascal who has hidden with a simple man a treasure found by them carries it away secretly, trying to have his associate condemned on the witness of a tree in which his father is concealed.

d: Trickster's confederate gives fabulous appraisal to worthless piece of glass.
a: Priest is duped into buying it as a diamond.

d: Confederate answers for corpse.
a: Man poses as returned heir to dead man; pretends to address corpse for identification.

d: Unjust umpire misappropriates disputed goods.
Dividing the discovered oyster.
a: The umpire takes the oyster itself as fee and gives each contestant half the shell.

d: Unjust umpire keeps the stakes when contest cannot be decided.
Cheating through knowledge of the law.
Deception into giving false credit.
Supper won by trick: the mutual friend.
a: A parasite makes the host believe him to be a friend of a certain guest and the guest to think him a friend of the host.

d: Supper won by disguising as an invited guest.
Old beggar disguised as gentleman: much money borrowed on his credit.
The other man to pay the bill.
r: *Bidier Fabliaux 447; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 150 No. 1848. Cf. Wesselski Bebel II 136 No. 111.
a: Three feast at an inn and each makes the host believe that one of the others will pay. None has money and the host is cheated.

d: Trickster buys chickens telling owner that priest will pay.
a: When owner comes to collect, the trickster tells the priest that a heretic has come for confession. Then he flees.

d: The priest as surety.
a: Feasters are imprisoned because of failure to pay for the food. They name the priest as surety and are released. The priest has been told that the host is possessed and agrees to come to heal him in two weeks. The host loses the money.

d: Complaint about the empty bottle.
a: While the servant in the inn is bringing a glass, the trickster drinks the wine and then complains that he has been given an empty bottle. The servant must bring another.

d: Greatest liar to get his supper free.
a: Wager. Each lie is corroborated by a confederate, who poses as a newly arrived stranger.

d: Credit based on forgery.
Forged letter used to obtain credit, consideration, and entertainment.
Forged testament used to dupe host.
Worthless chests offered to obtain credit.
Unjust banker deceived into delivering deposits by making him expect even larger.
Trickster receives huge sum on trifling credit by chain of borrowings.
a: Pays small sum in advance for first sum borrowed. Pays this borrowed sum in advance for larger, etc.

d: Trickster takes goods given in charity to his family.
The bear helps the fox's mother get berries: the fox eats them.
Monkey causes girl to cry as if from hunger: eats food given her.
Eavesdropping sexton duped into giving suppliant money.
a: The trickster prays to the Virgin for a certain sum of money and promises repayment of double at the end of the month. The sexton throws the money to him, but never receives it back.

d: Owner bids on his own goods at auction.
r: *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 204 No. 405; Chauvin VIII 107 No. 83.
a: Rival buyer pays extravagant price.

d: The substituted porridge.
r: *Type 9 C; Dh IV 249ff.; Krohn Bdr (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 97ff.
a: In cooking dinner fox's porridge is light, bear's black. At dinner fox steals spoonful of bear's porridge and lets bear taste it. Bear believes that fox's porridge is as bad as his own.

d: Sham blood and brains.
r: *Type 3; Dh IV 243; Krohn Bar (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 59ff.; Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 287; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 21 No. 5, 377 No. 68.
a: Fox covers his head with milk and says that his brains have been knocked out. Frightens bear.

d: Trickster cheats rescuers into digging his well.
a: The well that he has dug falls in. He throws his clothes into the hole and hides. People going to church think that man is drowned and dig the well out.

d: Cheating through equivocation.
r: Ktshler-Bolte I 513; Breton: Sibillot Incidents s.v. "iquivoque"; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: The stolen meat handed about.
a: The thief hands it to his confederate. He says, "I haven't it." The confederate says, "I didn't steal it."

d: "Have we leave to go?"
a: Two prisoners are made stable boys on their promise not to escape secretly. Before horse race starts they ask: "Do we have your leave to go?" They go home.

d: Why go all the way to fair?
a: Man robbed of his plate of cakes half way to fair asks another vendor, "Why go to the fair, when half way up people come demanding your plate?" Vendor goes on and meets with same fate.

d: Cheating by substitution of worthless articles.
Entrails substituted for meat.
a: Prometheus divides slain ox so that bones and entrails seem to be choicest part. (Zeus is not deceived.)

d: Rock substituted for ham by trickster.
Tortoise cheats leopard by substituting bundle of resin for bundle of meat.
False articles used to produce credit.
Nugget of supposed gold (lead) given to help build church: money then borrowed.
Reward for the bag of lead.
a: A man sews up lead in a bag and feigns to have found it. A merchant claims it and thinking it filled with gold pays him a large reward.

d: Water sold as wine.
a: Wine-casks partitioned: one half wine, other half water.

d: Innkeeper serves sweetened water for wine, cat for rabbit, mule for beef.
False set of rings to offset genuine.
a: Jewels bought with counterfeit money.

d: Priests substitute gilded images of calves for those of solid gold.
While swimming with the lizard, toad exchanges own ugly daughter for lizard's pretty one.
Lean geese substituted for fat by trickster.
Woman gives friend dried comb while she herself eats the honey.
Cheating by substitution of common cow for magic one.
Attention secured by trickery.
Audience secured with the pope by rudeness.
a: A woman bribes a man to get her an audience with the pope. By turning his back to the sacrament and saying that the woman had instructed him to do so, he brings it about that she is summoned into the presence.

d: Deception into listening to speaker.
r: Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 74 No. 64; Wienert FFC LVI 38; Halm Aesop Nos 177, 339.
a: He secures the audience's attention by beginning a tale. He then launches into his speech.

d: Entry into enemy's presence by pretending to be a messenger from a relative.
Butter weighed with the bread.
a: The peasant weighs the butter which he is selling to the baker along with the bread which he is buying.

d: Demi-coq by means of his magic animals and magic water collects money.
Blackbird to avenge capture of his wife carries rope, club, cat, ants and river in ears.
Money received to bury sham-dead person.
Husband and wife each receive money (from different persons) to bury the other, who is supposed to be dead.
Trickster reports treasure's owner dead: receives it from children.
Color of devil's cows changed while he sleeps so that he does not know them.
r: Dh I 188; Lithuanian: Balys Legends No. 134.
a: Only those not changed (all black, all red, etc.) belong to the devil.

d: Cheating by raising an alarm.
Trickster gets money from a bank by raising an alarm and demanding "what is owing to him."
Host with overstock of sour wine spreads rumor of dragon at his house.
a: A crowd gathers and he sells all his wine.

d: False alarm of robbery causes cheated man to be imprisoned.
r: Boccaccio Decameron IX No. 4; Italian Novella: Rotunda; Persian: Lorimer Persian Tales (London, 1919) 321 No. 52.

d: The devil gets into the ark.
r: *Type 825; *Dh I 258; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3100, Legends Nos. 192 195.
a: The devil wants to know what Noah is doing when he is building the ark. He forbids Noah's wife to enter the ark until Noah has also invited him.

d: The double-cheating miller.
a: He confesses that he has an oversized measure and agrees to get a smaller one. He measures back the grain in the smaller measure.

d: Counselor accuses conspirators in order to confiscate their estates.
Lawyer's dog steals meat.
a: The lawyer tells the butcher that the dog's owner (himself) is liable for damages. He ask double the amount of the damages as fee.

d: Trickster paid to educate an ass.
a: He gets paid in advance. He gradually starves the ass.

d: Trickster paid to teach monkey to talk.
Horse to be taught to speak.
Girl serves her father with piece of her own flesh in place of chicken.
r: Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 125 No. 1374B; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Woman serves beggar with coals instead of food.
Dupe betrayed by asking him ambiguous questions.
a: They are phrased in such a way that he understands them differently from the way they are intended.

d: Wolf announces dawn prematurely to collect debt.
r: Cape Verde Islands: *Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 6 n. 1.
a: The contract is to be fulfilled at daybreak. The wolf imitates the cock and crows, but is caught.

d: Trickster shams sickness so that partner does all the work.
Foxes persuade man to plant cooked plants.
a: They eat them at night.

d: Persons deceived into eating meat in Lent, the meat being disguised as butter.
Additional cheats.
Trickster sells mother's wine to merchant without asking her permission.
a: Mother saves part of wine because purchaser is dilatory in removing casks.

d: Object with a hollow as instrument of cheats.
Saint who desires broth containing no butter receives broth into which butter has been poured surreptitiously through hollow mixing-stick.
Saint who desires pottage of nettles containing no milk receives pottage into which milk has been poured surreptitiously through pipe.
a: The secret is revealed, and the saint blesses the cook's successors.

d: Old man cheats crocodile by playing on its ignorance of agriculture.
Trickster breaks cat of taste for milk by overheating its milk.
Embarrassing gift.
a: Trickster unwilling to pay for burial fee of aged cow, gives cow to unwitting Brahmin as gift. Cow dies soon and Brahmin must pay.

d: God cheats birds by giving false description of tamarind fruit.
Gullible king gives large sums to minister for construction of imaginary weapon and then more to have it destroyed.
Trickster dupes rival by exchanging beds: receives his food.
a: Overhears maiden tell rival she will bring food at night, waits until rival is asleep and carries him to another bed, takes his place, and is fed by maiden.

d: Treacherous friend drinks out of other's flask to save the water in his own.
Fox pretends to go to work, but goes out to sleep.
r: S. A. Indian (Chiriguano): Mitraux RMLP XXXIII 175.

d: Escape from death or danger by deception.
r: *Chauvin VIII 136 No. 132; Wienert FFC LVI 52 (ET 113 118); Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carriire; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries's list Nos. 1 8.

d: Death order evaded.
Uriah letter changed.
r: *Types 428, 930; *Aarne FFC XXIII 69ff., 91; *BP I 282; *Fb "brev" IV 61ab; *Chauvin VIII 143ff. Icelandic: Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 326 nn.
a: Falsified order of execution. A messenger is sent with a letter ordering the recipient to kill the bearer. On the way the letter is changed so that the bearer is honored.

d: Death evaded by persuading executioner that another victim was ordered.
r: Africa (Nyika): Bachmann ZsKS VI 84f., Meinhof Afrikanische Mdrchen 95ff.
a: (E.g., boy has been ordered to kill hare. Hare persuades the boy that the father said, "Kill the rooster for the hare.")

d: Ogam inscription on shield orders that bearer (who does not know meaning) shall be killed.
a: Poet (who recognizes the meaning) reports to king that inscription means a request for honorable treatment.

d: Compassionate executioner.
r: Icelandic: *Boberg; English: Wells 96 (Chevalere Assigne); Irish: MacCulloch Celtic 74; Italian: Boccaccio Decameron II No. 9 (Lee 56), Basile Pentamerone II No. 6, III No. 2; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 95 No. 53.
a: A servant charged with killing the hero (heroine) arranges the escape of the latter.

d: Compassionate executioners.
a: Slaves charged with killing (drowning) the infant heroine are touched by her "laughing smile" and put her in a calfshed (hollow tree), where she is found by cowherds, who rear her.

d: "Prince will soon want me back."
a: Executioner persuaded to let hero go.

d: Compassionate executioner: bloody coat.
a: A servant charged with killing the hero smears the latter's coat with the blood of an animal as proof of the execution and lets the hero escape.

d: Compassionate executioner: bloody knife (sword) from slain animal substitute.
Compassionate executioner: substituted heart.
r: *Types 671, 709; *Btsklen Sneewittchenstudien 79ff.; *BP I 450ff., 463; *Aarne FFC XXIII 57, MSFO XXV 181; *Prato RTP IV 178; Chauvin V 208 No. 120; *Cox 474; *Saintyves Perrault 68; Fb "hjaerte" I 631a, "lever" II 404b, "tunge" III 894a. Icelandic: Boberg; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC No. 706C*; Missouri French: Carriire; French Canadian: Sister Marie Ursule; India: Thompson-Balys; Jewish: Neuman (+S350); Chinese: Graham; Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian (Shuswap): Teit JE II 730 No. 50; S. A. Indian (Quiche): Alexander Lat. Am.
a: A servant charged with killing the hero (heroine) substitutes an animal, whose heart he takes to his master as proof of the execution.

d: Compassionate executioner: substituted brains (other animal for helpful animal).
Eyes of animal substituted as proof for eyes of children.
Eyes, ears, fingers of corpse substituted for those demanded of victim.
Animal substituted for child served at meal.
r: BP III 137 (Grimm No. 141); English: Wells 96 (Chevalere Assigne), Alphabet No. 593; Italian: Basile Pentamerone V No. 5; S. A. Indian (Yuracare): Mitraux BBAE CXLIII (3) 503.

d: Compassionate executioner: substituted child.
a: The servant charged with sending the hero to executioners sends his own child instead.

d: Executioner makes substitution when victim escapes.
Compassionate executioner: substituted puppet drowned.
Compassionate executioner: substituted head (made of clay) as proof of execution.
Compassionate executioner: mutilation substituted for death.
Boy's sixth toe cut off by compassionate executioner as proof he had been killed.
Compassionate executioner: feigns to torture victim.
Compassionate executioner: sleeping potion supplied instead of poison.
Bribed executioner releases culprit.
Disguise as girl to avoid execution.
r: *Oesterley No. 156; *Herbert III 133 No. 117; Icelandic: Anssaga Bogsveigis (FAS II) 359; Greek: Roscher Lexikon s.v. "Achilleus"; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 313 n. 128; Africa (Ba Ronga): Einstein 260, (Zulu): Callaway 40.

d: Girl substituted for boy to avoid slaughter by father.
Escape by hiding.
Children hidden to avoid their execution (death).
r: Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: Hrulfssaga Kraka 3, 22, Hblfdanarsaga Brtsnufustra (FAS III) 565; Greek: Fox 155 (Zeus and Kronus), Grote I 6; Jewish: *Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys; Eskimo (West Hudson Bay): Boas BAM XV 189, (Kodiak): Golder JAFL XVI 28; Africa (Ekoi): Talbot 355, (Pangwe): Tessman 366, (Fang): Tessman 108; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 275 No. 88.

d: Girl escapes by hiding in huge harp.
Sleeping persons covered with oxhide and so saved.
Escape by hiding in kettle.
Escape by hiding in rice-bin.
Escape by hiding in the earth.
Death escaped through disguise, shamming, or substitution.
Escape by disguise.
Escape by dressing in animal (bird, human) skin.
r: *Types 311, 510B, 1137; *BP I 399ff., III 375 (incident +B2); *Hackman Polyphemsage 160ff.; *Fb "hest" I 599b; English: Wells 20 (William of Palerne); Africa (Fang): Einstein 76, Trilles Proverbs 203.

d: Man sewed in animal's hide carried off by birds.
r: Penzer I 141 n. 2; Frobenius Das Zeitalter des Sonnengottes (Berlin, 1904) I 199ff; Jewish: Gr'nbaum Neue Beitrdge zur semitischen Sagenkunde (Leyden, 1893) 234f.

d: Escape by dressing in bear's skin.
r: Iuirriks saga I 261 72 (cf. 339 40); Asbjshrnsen and Moe No. 58 (type 590); Gonzenbach No. 68 and Ktshler's notes.

d: Escape in monkey-skin.
Escape by putting on old woman's skin.
Change of bodily appearance so as to escape.
Disguise by shaving off beard so as to escape.
Disguise by mutilation so as to escape.
a: Ears cut off, eyes put out, etc.

d: Disguise as king with mask in order to hide from enemy who has ruined warrior's face and torn his beard off.
Disguise as farmer so as to escape.
Disguise as carpenter so as to escape.
Disguise by painting (covering with soot, etc.) so as to escape.
Covering self with clay so as to escape.
Clothes changed so as to escape.
r: India: Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 8.

d: Disguise in clothes of other sex so as to escape.
Girl escapes in male disguise.
r: *Chauvin V 96 No. 31 n. 1; Boccaccio Decameron II No. 9 (Lee 54); Icelandic: Boberg; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Man in danger of life dressed by hostess as woman and set to baking.
Man in danger of life dressed by hostess as woman and set to grinding corn.
Man in danger of life takes his wife's place in the bed with her night-cap on.
Disguise as musician in order to escape.
r: Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 396 No. 18.

d: Musician in danger puts on his musician's attire as if about to play; escapes.
Escape in humble disguise.
r: *Type 510B; *Cox Cinderella; *BP II 45; *Saintyves Contes de Perrault 187, 196ff.; Icelandic: *Boberg; Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 385ff., (Ojibwa): Laidlaw Ontario Arch.
a: (Cap o' Rushes.)

d: Escape by disguising as a washerman.
Disguise as waiter in inn to escape.
Adulteress escapes prison disguised as an old woman.
Escape by making sheaths of bark for fingers: hero leaves without awakening nymph wives who make him sleep with fingers in mouth.
Escape in huge pumpkin shell.
a: (Attempted.)

d: Girl hidden in huge harp.
Abbot escapes from his paramour's husband in disguise of priest.
One animal escapes by shamming as another (jackal as goat).
Goat escapes from jackal by being covered with flowers.
Women escape from enemy's camp disguised as ascetics.
Hare escapes lion by being bundled in brushwood.
Hare and bride travel in pot to escape tiger, answer "Ruined pot" when challenged.
Escape by shamming death.
r: *Type 33; *BP II 120, III 345; *Chauvin VIII 136 No. 132; Liebrecht Zur Volkskunde 112 No. 23; *Penzer V 79 n. 3; Icelandic: *Boberg; India: *Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 1013, 1019; Korean: Zong in-Sob 18 No. 9; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 106, *Dixon 191 n. 13; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 384; Eskimo (Central): Boas RBAE VI 584, (Greenland): Rasmussen III 75; Africa (Yoruba): Ellis 273 No. 6, (Basuto): Jacottet 120 No. 27, (Benga): Nassau 228 No. 34, (Bushman): Bleek and Lloyd 175, (Fang): Trilles 205.

d: Death feigned to escape unwelcome marriage.
Escape by shamming death: blood and brains.
r: *Type 3; Dh IV 243; Krohn JSFO VI 55ff.; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 329 n 191a; Africa (Kaffir): Kidd 242 No. 9.
a: The trickster covers himself with paint (or the like) so that he will be thought to have bled to death (or with milk so that it will be thought that his brains have been knocked out).

d: Woman covers fleeing man with placenta of goat and with blood to convince pursuers she has just given birth and thus prevents their capturing him.
Ogre carries sham-dead man.
a: "He smells already."

d: Death feigned to escape from husband's death plot.
Captive parrots in net play dead and are thrown out: escape.
Trout pretends to be dead.
r: Bshdker Exempler 283 No. 28; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: Fisherman ignores him.

d: Escape by shammed burial.
Escape by shammed drowning;  wrecked boat or coffin lands.
Sham murder:  trickster attacked by angry mother causes her to spear ox guts and believe she has murdered him.
Escape by shammed hanging.
Escape by shamming illness.
r: Maori: Clark 167; Africa (Zulu): Callaway 78, (Angola): Chatelain 99 No. 6.

d: Illness (madness, dumbness, etc.) feigned to escape unwelcome marriage.
Illness feigned to escape rendezvous with undesired mistress.
Illness feigned to escape unwelcome meeting.
Escape by shamming madness.
r: (Cf. +K523.0.1.) Malone PMLA XLIII 400; Icelandic: Herrmann Saxo II 258ff., *Boberg; Jewish: Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Escape by shamming leprosy.
Escape by use of substituted object.
r: *Types 160*, 311; *BP I 398ff.; Irish myth: *Cross; Missouri French: Carriire, Italian Novella: Rotunda; Greek: *Frazer Apollodorus I 8 n. 2 (Zeus and Kronus); India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 37, Dixon 200, *201 n. 38; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 51; Chinese: Graham; Eskimo (Greenland): Rasmussen III 65, Rink 107, (West Hudson Bay): Boas BAM XV 194; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 355 n. 282; Africa (Basuto): Jacottet 226 No. 33.
a: The object is attacked rather than the intended victim.

d: Substituted object left in bed while intended victim escapes.
r: *Type 1115; *BP I 148ff., 164; U.S.: Baughman; Icelandic: FSS 38, Boberg; Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges (+K437.1.1.)

d: Woman puts figures of paramour and herself in bed.
a: Husband attacks them. Woman uses it as a lesson to "reform" husband.

d: Bride substitutes wooden picture while she herself escapes sleeping groom.
In order to save child from death, maid substitutes block dressed to resemble it.
a: Enemy strikes block.

d: Man steps aside so that only his shadow is caught.
Object substituted for murdered person so as to allay suspicion.
Animal jumps out of skin so that only skin is caught.
Man leaves mantle so that only mantle is hit.
Escape, leaving dog as substitute.
Dog buried instead of foster son, who is falsely reported killed so that he can safely be taken away.
Girl escapes from ogress by substituting pig.
Destructive magic object tried out on something inanimate.
Destructive magic belt tried on tree.
a: Destroys tree.

d: Cock's blood given spirits instead of human blood.
Escape by leaving behind false images made of spittle.
Captor's bag filled with animals or objects while captives escape.
r: *Type 327C; Icelandic: Sveinsson FFC LXXXIII No. 327C; Norwegian: Christiansen Norske Eventyr 44; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 44 No. 311B*; India: *Thompson-Balys; Koryak: Jochelson JE VI 181, 212; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 351 n. 268a; S. A. Indian (Aymara): Tschapik BBAE CXLIII (1) 571; Africa (Kaffir): Theal 120, 136, (Basuto): Jacottet 66 No. 10, (Zulu): Callaway 6, 74, 345, (Congo): Grenfell 824; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 386 No. 70, (Virginia): Parsons JAFL XXXV 262.

d: Escape by substituting another person in place of the intended victim.
r: *Type 953; Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Korean: Zong in-Sob 126 No. 60; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 149; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G.

d: Poisoned food (drink) fed to animal instead of to intended victim.
r: *Boje 72ff.; India: *Thompson-Balys; Easter Island: Mitraux Ethnology 365; Africa (Nyang): Ittman 58.
a: Animal perishes.

d: Escape by substituting brother for intended victim, namely self.
