d: Importunate lover is induced to undergo series of humiliations.
a: (1) Disguise as bakery woman. (2) Disguise as priest. (3) Disguise as corpse. (4) Hiding in wine skin. Humiliated each time.

d: Aristotle and Phyllis: philosopher as riding horse for woman.
r: *Type 1501; **Moth Aristoteles-sagnet; **Borgeld Aristoteles en Phyllis (Groningen, 1902); **Sarton Isis XIV (1930) 8ff.; *Basset 1001 Contes II 140; *G. Paris Romania XI 138; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 203 No. 402; Bidier Fabliaux 204, 386, 448; *Herbert Catalogue III 87; Chavannes III 236; *RTP XV 110; von der Hagen I xxv, 17; Hertz Spielmannsbuch 57, 420; Campion MPh XIII 347; Speyer Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsche Taal- en Letterkunde XXVI 268; Scala Celi 86a No. 501. Italian Novella: Rotunda; Indonesia: Voorhoeve 164 No. 170, Bezemer Javaansche en Maleische Fabelen en Legenden 170f.
a: The philosopher warns the king against uxoriousness. In revenge the queen beguiles the philosopher into letting her ride him on all-fours. The king comes and sees.

d: Hidden paramour taken to his own wife.
a: He hides in a chest. The chest is taken by a creditor who unwittingly delivers it to the paramour's wife.

d: Tale of the basin.
r: *BP II 40 n. 2; *Wesselski Mdrchen 216 No. 27; *Kittredge Witchcraft 201 nn.
a: Lover caught on magic basin and left in embarrassing position.

d: Importunate lovers led astray.
The entrapped suitors.
r: *Type 1730; *Penzer I 33ff., 42ff., 160ff.; *Baumgarten Arch. Icelandic: Boberg; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1730A*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1730 II*; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: (Lai l'ipervier.) The chaste wife has them one at a time undress and hide. The husband and guests come and chase them off.

d: The entrapped suitors: the chaste wife tricks them into casks.
a: The husband takes the casks to the marketplace where he opens them.

d: The entrapped suitors: the chaste wife has them caught.
a: Forces them to work for her.

d: The entrapped suitor: tricked into room where he is left to himself.
Importunate lover imprisoned and starved: later given choice of lady or food.
a: Chooses food.

d: Lover hidden by wife in room made to fall into deep pit of treacle.
Importunate lover (priest) is forced to hide in chest.
a: Husband takes the chest to the waiting congregation. Clever priest comes out enacting the resurrection of Lazarus.

d: Four importunate lovers are forced to hide in four-compartmented chest which is sold.
Importunate suitor enticed into sack and beaten by husband.
Priest caught in lasso by rival lover.
a: Mistress tells knight of priest's demands. Knight has her give assignation, and arranges around her a string lasso which he pulls, and catches priest.

d: Importunate suitor has his head shaved and tarred and is put into a sack and returned to his men.
To get "nothing" and to show it.
a: Wife pushes lecherous king first into glue and then in the closet with feathers. That is "nothing"   neither bird nor man.

d: Suitor locked in pigsty.
Suitors one by one enticed into graveyard and left together.
r: Type 940; Sibillot RTP IX 344, Literature orale de la Haute-Bretagne 142.
a: They later get revenge.

d: Suitors as corpse, angel, and devil.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 220; Boccaccio Decameron IX No. 1 (Lee 271); Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: First induced to lie in coffin, second to sit up with the "corpse", and the third to carry a firebrand. " Corpse" thinks others are angel and devil. All come to blows.

d: Three women humiliate importunate lover.
a: First has him hide on thorns, second has him fall into a hole, third has him fall asleep in the street. In revenge he shows them naked, except for face, to his friends.

d: Girl asks importunate lover for weapon to use against her father.
a: Instead, she uses it to defend herself against the suitor.

d: Importunate lover beaten and sent on street bearing humiliating placard.
Importunate lover tied to tree.
Importunate lover beaten with canes filled with straw.
a: He thinks he is severely wounded.

d: Obscene tricks are played on repugnant simpleton who wishes to marry.
Importunate lover is given a rendezvous.
a: Obscene tricks played on him.

d: Wife takes lover beneath tree where she has told husband to hide.
a: When he begins to kiss her, husband shouts "Keep a little for me. " Lover, shamefaced, runs away.

d: Woman tricks importunate lover with the head of a pike.
a: Thereafter he thinks the vagina is toothed.

d: Mistress deceives lover with a substitute.
Bride escapes from foolish husband and leaves goat as substitute in bed.
Mistress sends man's own wife as substitute without his knowledge.
Chaste woman sends man's own wife as substitute (without his knowledge).
a: Then the first woman's husband is substituted for the importunate lover, who has his own wife seduced.

d: Wife (mistress) substitutes for mistress (wife).
a: The woman has been asked for a rendezvous. She tells the suitor's wife and they exchange places.

d: Chaste woman substitutes corpse for herself in the bed of an insistent suitor.
King's daughter deceives king by substituting her maid.
Lover given rump to kiss.
r: *Type 1361; *F. N. Robinson Complete Works of Geoffrey Chaucer (Boston, 1933) 786b; *Bolte Frey 251 No. 89; *Barnouw "The Millers Tale van Chaucer" Handlingen van het 6.
a: Sometimes the trick is played by a rival lover. (Chaucer's Miller's Tale).

d: Lover put off by deceptive respite.
Lover put off till girl bathes and dresses.
r: Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas I 257.
a: She escapes.

d: Suitors put off till web is woven.
r: *W. Crooke FL IX 97; Greek: *Frazer Apollodorus II 299 n. 2.
a: Unwoven each night. (Penelope.)

d: Respite from wooer while he brings clothes all night.
r: BP I 221; *Roberts 175; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 120 No. 31; Lithuanian: Balys Legends Nos. 345f., 363, 398.
a: The girl wastes time trying them on.

d: Girl refuses to dance with a devil until she is well dressed.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3251, Legends No. 353f., 356 362.
a: The devil brings things till the cock crows. Another girl asks for all the things at once and must dance until she dies.

d: Girl asks undesired lover to take off his boots.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 24; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: She pulls off one partway and escapes.

d: Girl tells physician-seducer she cannot meet his wishes until after he bathes.
a: Prepares the bath herself and pours acid into it.

d: Woman leaves importunate lover waiting in her room.
a: Feigns illness and then escapes.

d: Girl puts off consummation of marriage to undesirable suitor by saying her "stomach is sick".
Girl asks undesired lover to follow her but not to step on her shadow.
Girl says she has made vow not to marry until pilgrimage is made.
Girl as umpire in suitor test (shooting arrows) escapes.
Importunate lover kept overlong at supper: must leave.
Escape from undesired lover by alleging menstrual period.
Abducted princess tells her abductor to wait for her menstrual period of 12 years to terminate.
Woman humiliates would-be lover.
a: Knowing that he has deceived another by paying her with gilded coin she answers: "You will have to pay in better coin than is your wont!

d: Chaste woman refers lover to her husband for permission.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 749; Heptameron No. 27; Irish myth: Cross; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Chaste woman refers lover to his wife.
Lover deceived by false suicide agreement.
a: The woman persuades her lover to jump from a cliff; she will follow. She does not jump.

d: Lover's anger softened by sham suicide attempt.
a: Is later scorned.

d: Lover humiliated by his impotence.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 28; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: King tricked into sleeping with hag.
Disguise as man to escape importunate lover.
Girl plays at dice with her suitors: locks them up when they are defeated.
Deception into humiliating position miscellaneous.
Trickster rides dupe horseback.
r: *Types 4, 72; *BP II 117; Krohn Bdr (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 59ff.; *Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 66; Missouri French: Carriire; Spanish Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa: Frobenius Atlantis IX 115, (Nigeria): Tramearne 322, (Yoruba): Ellis 265, (Angola): Chatelain 203 No. 28; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 24 No. 6, Jones Negro Tales from the Georgia Coast Nos 7, 13, (Virginia): Bacon and Parsons JAFL XXXV 265 266, Speers JAFL XXV 285f., (North Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXX 173, (South Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXXIV 5, MAFLS XVI 54, (Louisiana): Johnston JAFL IX 195; American Negro and American Indian: *Thompson CColl II 440, 447; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 235; West Indies: Van Cappelle Mythen en Sagen van West-Indie Nos. 12, 16.
a: Usually by feigning sickness he induces the dupe to carry him and then boasts that the dupe always acts as his horse.

d: Trickster rides dupe a-courting.
r: Type 72; Africa (Nupe): Frobenius Atlantis IX 115 No. 3, (Yoruba): Frobenius ibid.
a: Feigns sickness and persuades dupe to carry him. Thus wins the girl.

d: Priest trapped in window and humiliated.
Holding up the rock.
r: (Sometimes steals the dupe's goods.) *Type 1530; *Parsons JAFL XXX 237, XXXI 227 n. 2, MAFLS XV (1) 59; N. A. Indian (Mexico): Boas JAFL XXV 206, 237; Africa (Kaffir): Theal 113, 189, (Hottentot, South of Zambezi): Theal 91, (Basuto): Jacottet 44 n. 1; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 314 No. 54.
a: Trickster makes dupe believe that he is holding up a great rock and induces him to hold it for a while.

d: Holding up the roof.
r: *Type 9A; Dh IV 249ff.; Krohn Bdr (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 97ff.; Japanese: Ikeda.
a: Fox pretends to be holding up the roof; hence cannot help the bear, who must do the threshing alone.

d: Fox pretends to be guarding the sky and watching the earth.
Holding down the hat.
r: *Type 1528; *Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 54; Java: Dixon 186 n. 2; N. A. Indian: *Thompson CColl II 420, 426. Cf. Indonesia: DeVries Volksverhalen II 396 No. 185B.
a: Dupe persuaded to guard hat supposed to cover something valuable. It covers a pile of dung. (Dupe's goods are sometimes stolen.)

d: Dupe persuaded to fight with alleged gold-dropping bear: trickster meantime steals his clothes.
The general hatches out an egg.
a: The page induces the general to take his place in sitting on the eggs. Then he calls the king to look.

d: Person hypnotized into believing himself transformed.
Man falsely reported insane.
r: *Wesselski Arlotto II 225 No. 92, Morlini 275; Alphabet No. 770; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys. Cf. Malvolio in Shakespeare's "Twelfth Night".
a: No one will believe him.

d: Man carried and dropped in mid-stream.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 582; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 340 n. 227.

d: Amorous intrigue observed and exposed.
Threat to tell of amorous intrigue used as blackmail.
The bag of lies: threat to tell of queen's adultery.
r: *Type 570; *BP III 273; Icelandic: Sveinsson FFC LXXXIII No. 570; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2904*; Russian: cf. Andrejev No. 1630*; Spanish: Espinosa II Nos. 5 8.
a: The boy, who is to tell the bag of lies, is stopped and his wishes granted.

d: Princess made to speak desired words when hero threatens to report (falsely) her amorous conduct.
r: *Type 852; *BP II 506; Icelandic: Sveinsson FFC LXXXIII No. 852.

d: Educated chickens tell of woman's adultery.
r: *Type 1750; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 843; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1676*.
a: A trickster undertakes to teach a woman's chickens to talk. When he reports that they are saying that she has slept with the priest, she pays him off.

d: Man hidden in roof sees girl and lover and falls: they flee and leave him in possession.
r: *Types 1360, 1776; Wesselski Morlini 303 No. 54; Lithuanian: Balys Legends No. 890; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Man having seen woman and lover from roof threatens to tell about it; is paid to stop.
r: *Type 1360B; Lappish: Qvigstad Lappiske Eventyr III No. 84.

d: Man hidden in roof (or elsewhere) sees girl and lover: blows horn.
a: They flee and leave him in possession.

d: Observer of intrigue insists on sharing in it (or enjoys the girl after putting the man to flight).
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 46; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Lovers observed in intrigue make absurd excuses.
a: (Afraid of ghosts, have chill, etc.) Italian Novella:

d: Amorous intrigue exposed and faithless husband humiliated.
Wife surprises husband in adultery and shames him into giving her all she desires.
Adulteress tells lover "I can see the whole world.
r: " Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2905*; Italian Novella: Rotunda (+K1532.3); Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 12; India: Thompson-Balys.
a: "  Hidden shepherd asks "Can you see my lost calves (ass)?

d: The Lord above will provide.
r: " Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2912*; Rumanian: Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 1654*.
a: A youth and maid come under tree. " Who shall provide for our child? " "He above (God) will take care of it. " The man in the tree: "I will do nothing of the kind!

d: Man abed with his wife is frightened away by an intruder who steals his clothes.
Abbess puts priest's trousers on her head.
r: Boccaccio Decameron IX No. 2 (Lee 274); Mensa Philosophica No. 200; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: Suddenly called up while abed with the priest, she thinks to put on her coif. Discomfited by nuns whom she has denounced for incontinence.

d: Discovery of abbot's (abbess's) incontinence brings permission to monks (nuns) to do likewise.
r: Boccaccio Decameron I No. 4 (Lee 14); Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Girl who cannot keep silent thereby provokes her rival to admit unchastity.
r: *Type 886; *von der Hagen II v, vi, 3, 19 Nos. 21, 22; *Bolte Montanus's Wegk'rzer 558 No. 1; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Girl refusing her lover final kiss provokes rival to admit selling kisses.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 8; Italian: Basile Pentamerone V 4.

d: Woman draws a pelt to her instead of her husband.
a: A woman asks of her husband a hair which will magically draw him to her. He gives her a hair from a pelt.

d: Priest draws a sow to him instead of a woman.
a: He asks for a pubic hair which will draw the woman to him. Sow's bristles substituted. Sow rushes to church.

d: Rascals pull off judge's breeches and leave him exposed.
r: Boccaccio Decameron VIII No. 5; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Mock initiation for dupe.
King induced to kiss horse's rump: trickster then threatens to tell.
r: *Type 570; *BP III 267ff.; Fb "rshv" III 130a, "kysse" II 350; Russian: Andrejev No. 1630*; Spanish: Espinosa II Nos. 1 8, Espinosa Jr.

d: Opposing witnesses's pockets filled with dung.
a: Discredited.

d: Hostile brother-in-law made king's inferior by being tricked to hold his sword, while the king arranges his breeches belt.
a: (Old custom).

d: Seduction.
Mortal woman seduced by a god.
r: (Cf. +K1315.1.) See references to +D658.2. Irish: MacCulloch Celtic 62, 80, *Cross; India: Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 165f.; Africa (Fang): Einstein 94, Trilles 137.

d: Woman won and lost by a ruse.
Seduction by disguise or substitution.
Seduction by masking as woman's husband.
r: *Penzer II 45 n. 4, III 126f.; Boccaccio Decameron III No. 6 (Lee 79); Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 30; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Jewish: Neuman, bin Gorion Born Judas I 364; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: Coster-Wijsman 33 No. 11; N. A. Indian (Klikitat): Jacobs U Wash II 31.

d: Seduction by masking as woman's husband: "Why you have just left!
a: " After the seduction the husband comes and the wife shows surprise.

d: Trickster kills husband and puts on his skin so as to seduce wife.
r: S. A. Indian (Toba): Mitraux MAFLS XL 151.

d: Husband's twin brother mistaken by woman for her husband.
r: *Type 303; *BP I 528ff.; Icelandic: Boberg; Italian: Basile Pentamerone I Nos. 7, 9, Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Seduction by wearing coat of invisibility.
Seduction by impostor.
Seduction by posing as a god.
r: (Cf. +K1301.) Jones PMLA XXIII 577; Penzer I 145; Icelandic: Boberg; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Jewish: Neuman, bin Gorion Born Judas I 365; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Seduction by posing as Angel Gabriel.
r: Boccaccio Decameron IV No. 2 (Lee 123); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Seduction on promise that issue will be the fifth Evangelist.
Seduction on feigned orders from angel to engender a pope.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 14; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: Girl born.

d: Seduction by posing as doctor.
r: Icelandic: Herrmann Saxo II 239, Boberg; Italian Novella: Rotunda; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 305 n. 109r.

d: Girl persuaded to sit on certain plant: seduced.
a: Man as sham doctor tells her how to heal her burnt groins.

d: Seduction by sham process of retrieving lost gem.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 3; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Seduction by sham process of repairing vagina.
Seduction by pretending to give childless man's wife medicine.
a: When husband comes at cockcrow as he was told, trickster says he came too late and they must do it again.

d: Seduction by posing as magician.
a: (Sham incantation, etc.) Italian Novella:

d: Seduction by feigning enchantment.
Seduction attempted on promise of magic transformation: woman to mare.
a: Finishing the tail.

d: Seduction by posing as a relative.
Seduction by posing as nobleman.
Prostitute poses as noble woman.
Seduction by posing as holy man (churchman).
Tricksters persuade women that they must share their marital intimacies with them.
Seduction attempted on threat of performing miracle.
Girl disguised as friar gets into priest's bed.
Seduction by posing as saint.
Seduction by posing as teacher or instructor.
Seduction by pretending to instruct (or to need instruction) in marital duties.
Seduction under pretence of teaching a game.
Seduction upon false promise of marriage.
Seduction by offering protection against non-existing danger.
Seduction by posing as beggar.
Seduction by posing as leper.
Seduction by posing as merchant.
Seduction by masking as soldier.
Seduction: weaver posing as king.
Lover's place in bed usurped by another.
r: *Child I 137-41; Nouvelles Ricriations No. 54; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Serving-man in his master's place.
r: Chauvin II 92 No. 38; Bshdker Exempler 289 No. 41; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Master in serving-man's place in woman's bed.
Leper intercepts letter and takes paramour's place with princess.
r: Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 237 No. 79.

d: Old woman intercepts letter and takes girl's place in man's bed.
Letter delivered to wrong man.
a: He substitutes for the lover.

d: Vengeful paramours send syphilitic man to substitute in woman's bed.
Man caught running by guards has to tell his destination.
a: One of the guards substitutes for him with his sweetheart.

d: Woman substitutes for her daughter in the dark.
Use of drugs to usurp lover's place.
Woman drugs sister and substitutes for her with lover.
Woman mistakes passer-by for lover.
a: Substitution in the dark.

d: Moorish (black) girl substituted for mistress (in the dark).
Man intercepts love letter and takes lover's place in elopement.
Devil comes to rendezvous instead of woman's lover.
Trickster shifts married couples in bed.
r: *BP III 394 (3); Anderson FFC XLII 364; Ktshler-Bolte II 305ff.
a: Old man married to young woman and young man married to old woman. The shift is satisfactory to the young couple.

d: Seduction by man disguising as woman.
r: Nouvelles de Sens No. 8; Irish myth: *Cross; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Man disguised as woman admitted to women's quarters: seduction.
r: *Types 516, 1542; Rtssch FFC LXXVII 109; *Fischer-Bolte 215; *Krappe Balor 12 n. 42; Penzer I 47n., 48n.; Herrmann Saxo II 239, 493, 641; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Greek: Frazer Apollodorus II 73 n. 2 (Achilles); India: *Thompson-Balys, Ruben FFC CXXXIII 41.

d: Man disguised as pregnant woman admitted to girl's bed.
Seducer successfully disguised as washerwoman for fifteen years.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 45; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: Finally exposed.

d: Man wishes to learn and gains entrance to learned girl's presence in woman's disguise.
Man disguised as woman abducts princess.
Man disguised as woman courted (married) by another man.
r: Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 104 No. 857; India: *Thompson-Balys; Eskimo (West Hudson Bay): Boas BAM XV 248; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 304 n. 109n.

d: Man disguised as woman beguiles hostile chief.
r: *Wesselski Archiv Orientblnn II 430; Icelandic: MacCulloch Eddic 88; India: Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Anesaki 303f.
a: Infatuates him and then kills him in drunken sleep.

d: Men disguised as women enter convent and seduce impious nuns.
Girl masked as man wins princess's love.
r: Type 514; BP II 87, III 84; Spanish: Espinosa III No. 155; Italian: Basile Pentamerone IV No. 6; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: The lovely ascetic (girl in man's clothes) wins love of a rich woman.
Man disguised as gardener enters convent and seduces nuns.
r: (Cf. +K1321.4.) Boccaccio Decameron III No. 1 (Lee 59); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Messenger from lover to girl-captive in harem poses as a singer who amuses the harem ladies in their apartments.
Seduction by feigned death.
a: The girl comes to the man's wake or funeral.

d: Death feigned to woo maiden.
a: She shows remorse when she hears of his death.

d: Hero feigns death and is copulated with by divine maidens.
Seduction by feigned sleep.
a: The guest in the conjugal bed feigns sleep as he effects seduction.

d: Seduction by feigned illness.
r: S. A. Indian (Toba): Mitraux MAFLS XL 147; West Indies: Flowers 536f.

d: Seduction by asking for sham cure for sham illness.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 95; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Seduction by feigned stupidity.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2907*; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 1544*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1544A*.
a: Cautious farmer seeks laborer who knows nothing about sex. Trickster makes silly explanation of copulation of animals. When admitted into service, seduces both farmer's wife and daughter.

d: Disguise as animal to seduce woman.
Girl tricked into man's room (or power).
No!
r: *Types 851, 853; BP I 192; **Kristoffer Nyrop Nej: et motivs historie (Kshbenhavn, 1891); Dania V 1ff., 164ff., 166; *Toldo Zs. f. Vksk.
a: "  The princess must answer all questions by "No". By clever framing of his question the hero wins her to his desires.

d: Seduction by taking aboard ship to inspect wares.
r: *Type 516; **Rosch FFC LXXVII 103; Ktshler-Bolte I 464; *Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 551a nn. Cf. bin Gorion Born Judas I 187.

d: Seduction by scattering jewels.
a: Girl seized when she tries to take jewels.

d: Seduction by enticing woman to inspect wares in tent.
Seduction by promise of jewels.
Seduction by having maiden placed in floating chest.
Seduction (or wooing) on an aerial journey.
Seduction (or wooing) by stealing clothes of bathing girl (swan maiden).
r: *Types 313, 400; Penzer VIII 58 n. 2, 213ff., IX 20 n. 1; Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 433b. See all notes to +D361.1.

d: Magic helper brings girl to hero's bed.
Girl tricked into man's room (power)  miscellaneous.
Fresh hides spread on grass; girl slips up and is deflowered.
Woman enticed to upper world on a stretching tree.
Seduction by luring woman to platform to look for distant ship.
Woman enticed into man's room by feigned illness.
Seduction by sham beauty test.
a: Trickster dupes two girls into submitting to test. Both seduced.

d: Girl tricked by use of drugs.
a: Subsequent pregnancy used to force her into marrying seducer.

d: Seduction by priest who insists on woman having confession in his own house.
Trickster agrees to carry old woman and girl across stream: carries girl across and rides off with her leaving old woman on other side.
Leak in roof over woman's bed: in rain must go to bed with trickster.
r: N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 305 n. 109s; S. A. Indian (Tenibi): Mitraux RMLP XXXIII 140.

d: Entrance into girl's (man's) room (bed) by trick.
Entrance to woman's room in hollow artificial animal.
Entrance to woman's room in golden ram.

d: Entrance into woman's (man's) room by hiding in chest.
r: *Type 882; Ktshler-Bolte I 211f.; Fb "kiste" II 134; Boccaccio Decameron II No. 9 (Lee 57); Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys. Cf. Shakespeare's Cymbeline.

d: Man carried into woman's room hidden in basket.
r: (Cf. +K1343.1.) *Spargo Virgil the Necromancer 139, 370 n. 7; English: Wells 140 (Floris and Blauncheflur); Icelandic: Boberg.

d: Entrance into woman's room in lamp stand.
Heroine in hiding-box which is bought by prince.
Man in magic hiding box bought by girl's father.
Man drawn up into female apartments on rope.
r: *Spargo Virgil the Necromancer 139, 369 n. 6; Penzer V 24.

d: Man drawn up into female apartments in basket.
r: (Cf. +K1342.0.1.) *Spargo Virgil the Necromancer 136ff., 368ff.; Penzer V 147 n. 1; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys; all references to +K1211.

d: Man disguised as woman carried into princess's room: marries her.
Tunnel entrance to guarded maiden's chamber.
r: Icelandic: Boberg; Italian: Basile Pentamerone II No. 2; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; S. A. Indian (Chiriguano): Mitraux RMLP XXXIII 142, MAFLS XL 159.

d: Girl seduced from beneath ground.

d: The feigned wedding-feast.
a: The husband returns unexpectedly to find his wife entertaining the paramour with a sumptuous feast. He is made to believe the feast is in honor of some newly-weds.

d: Wife confesses to disguised husband.
a: She suspects the fraud and persuades him that she knew the ruse and was testing him. He begs forgiveness.

d: Husband transformed to goat must witness wife's adultery.
r: Type 824*; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 824*; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 824*; Russian: Andrejev No. 824*.
a: The devil has let him see his wife's unfaithfulness in this way.

d: Gullible husband under the bed.
Adulteress tells her lover how she loves her husband.
r: Penzer V 108 n. 2; Bshdker Exempler 269 No. 59; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: She thus deceives the spying husband under the bed.

d: Adulteress tells how she may save her husband's life.
a: Discovering him under the bed, she tells lover that at temple she has learned that her husband is to die soon unless she prevents death by sleeping with a strange man. The husband is satisfied.

d: Gullible husband behind the tree.
a: (Tristan and Isolt.) Husband goes to wife's love tryst and hides behind a tree. The wife, having learned of his presence, tells lover that he should not allow their innocent relations to lead to gossip. Husband is appeased.

d: Adulteress transforms her husband into an animal to get rid of him.
r: Type 449*; Malone PMLA XLIII 418, 421, 441; Chauvin V 3, 5f., 198, *VI 198, VII 129f.; Penzer III 194; Kittredge Arthur 246ff.; Anderson Roman apuleja i narodnaja skazka I 376-487, 612-633; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3655; Russian: Andrejev No. 499A*; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: (The Tsar's Dog.)

d: Adulteress transforms man to stone up to the waist.
Woman has husband made monk while he is drunk, so as to get rid of him.
r: Scala Celi 87a No. 506; Crane Vitry No. 231; Liebrecht 124; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 38; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Death feigned to meet paramour.
r: *Wesselski Mdrchen 197; *Child V 3f., 6, 280; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 876; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 305 n. 109t.
a: Meetings in the grave (grave box).

d: Wife feigns death and slips out to lover.
Death feigned so man can live with mistress.
Sexton's own wife brings her offering.
a: The priest grants to the sexton the offerings brought by all women whom the priest has loved. The priest always calls out "Take" when these women offer. The sexton's own wife comes. The priest calls out "Take!

d: Husband frightened by wife's paramour in hog pen.
r: (Cf. +K1515, +K1555, +K1566, +K1574.) Wesselski Bebel I 206 No. 92; Spanish: Espinosa III No. 193.
a: The husband sees the paramour who has hidden in the pen and says, "Who are you? " "I am a miserable hog. " The husband thinks that his hogs are possessed.

d: The marked coat in the wife's room.
r: *Bidier Fabliaux 443; **Eberling Auberie, altfranztssische fabel etc. (Berlin, 1891); Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: A procuress obtains a woman for her client by leaving a marked coat in her room. The husband drives the wife away and she joins her lover. The procuress then goes to the husband and alleges that she lost a coat with certain marks. The husband is deceived and takes the wife back.

d: Husband unwittingly instrumental in wife's adultery.
r: Heptameron No. 8; Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 9; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: (Usually shares his bedmate with others, not knowing that she is his wife.)

d: Husband rescues wife's paramour.
a: Not knowing lover's identity, husband takes him to his wife and entrusts him to her care. He then leaves on a trip.

d: Wives wager as to who can best fool her husband.
r: *Type 1406; *Liebrecht 124; Bidier Fabliaux 265ff.; *Crane Vitry 227 No. 231, cf. 238 No. 248; Boccaccio Decameron VII No. 9 (Lee 231); Christensen DF XLVII 229; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Woman warns lover of husband by parody incantation.
r: (Cf. +K1961.1.2.1, +V66.1, +X441.) Boccaccio Decameron VII No. 1 (Lee 185); Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Woman warns lover of husband by singing song.
Woman encourages paramour by song.
Adulteress makes believe that her suspicious husband is insane.
a: He is taken away.

d: Adulteress outwits husband miscellaneous motifs.
Woman has paramour steal her husband's clothes.
a: Paramour gains entrance disguised as the husband. The husband without his clothes is driven away from his home.

d: Wife surprised in adultery feigns death.
a: Comes "back to life" on hearing husband say he has seen nothing.

d: Lover carried away on mistress's shoulders so that his footprints will not be visible in the snow.
Lover leaves horse outside house as husband comes up: wife tells husband their cow has foaled a horse.
r: India: Thompson-Balys. Cf. English, Scottish: *Child No. 274.

d: Unfaithful wife communicates with lover by pouring milk into stream.
Wife's attendants on trip chase wrong man as suspected lover and miss real lover.
Husband deceived as to noise made by hidden paramour.
Woman cooks food for paramour.
Adulteress detected by food she prepares for paramour.
Husband outwits adulteress and paramour.
Husband discovers wife's adultery.
Adulteress detected: husband secretly drops dye on her dress.
Adulteress detected by food she prepares for paramour.
r: India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 341.

d: Husband returns home secretly and spies on adulteress and lovers.
Husband returns secretly and kills unwelcome suitor.
Husband feigns blindness and avenges himself on his wife and her paramour.
r: *Type 1380; *BP III 124; *Taylor MPh XV 227 n. 1; Stiefel Zs. f. Vksk.

d: Husband feigns illness to surprise wife with paramour.
The husband sets house afire and ousts hidden paramour.
r: Type 1406*; von der Hagen II *xxxvi No. 41.

d: Trickster sets fire to barrel of tow in which paramour is hidden.
a: The paramour, naked, runs out carrying wisps of burning tow. The trickster tells the husband that he has raised the devil.

d: Husband carries off box containing hidden paramour.
r: *Type 1535; **A. Stepphun Das Fabel vom Prestre comporti und seine Versionen (Ktsnigsberg, 1913); *BP II 18; *Basset 1001 Contes II 45; *Toldo Zs. f. Vksk.
a: Latter exposed (otherwise discomfited).

d: Dying woman lures paramour into chest.
a: Asks husband to bury chest with her.

d: Chest containing paramour unwittingly taken away by husband.
Lover hidden in hen-coop discovered by husband.
r: Boccaccio Decameron V No. 10 (Lee 173); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: The devil in the barrel.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2900*; Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges.
a: The naked lover hides himself in a sooty barrel. The husband receives from a curious gentleman a good sum of money for showing him the "devil".

d: Old Hildebrand.
r: *Type 1360C; **Anderson Der Schwank vom alten Hildebrand (Dorpat, 1931); *BP II 373; Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 188a nn.
a: Hidden cuckold reveals his presence by rhymes. He responds to the rhymes made by the wife and paramour concerning their entertainment.

d: Adulteress binds husband's eyes and causes him to sing incantations concerning the adultery.
Husband discovers wife's adultery by riddling conversation.
a: In this indirect manner the wife confesses and promises reform.

d: Husband discovers paramour's love letter in his wife's purse after having made her drunk.
The husband prepares to castrate the crucifix.
r: *Ktshler-Bolte II 469; Spanish: Espinosa II No. 42; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys.
a: The artist's wife's paramour poses as a crucifix when caught. When he sees the husband's preparations, he flees naked.

d: Husband castrates paramour.
The husband meets the paramour in the wife's place.
r: *Wesselski Bebel II 149 No. 161; Nouvelles Ricriations No. 60; N. A. Indian (Malecite): Mechling GSCan VI 83 No. 21, (Fox): Jones PAES I 145.
a: Beats him (or cuts off privates).

d: Husband hides in wife's room and kills paramour.
Husband catches paramour in pitfall.
r: *Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 9 No. 4; Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 56; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: The wife sends her maid to investigate. The maid falls in and finally the wife herself. The husband calls the neighborhood to see them.

d: Husband (god) traps wife and paramour with magic armor.
a: (Vulcan, Mars, Venus.)

d: Husband proves intrigue by secretly blacking paramour's mouth.
a: When he returns, his wife's face is black.

d: Blades (broken glass) to wound and detect wife's lover.
r: Type 432; *Krappe Balor 35ff.; *Schoepperle I 218ff.; Irish myth: Cross.
a: (Often on window.)

d: Cuckolded man shuts wife's paramour in chest and lies on the chest with latter's wife.
r: Boccaccio Decameron VIII No. 8 (Lee 261); Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Cuckold unwittingly lies with wife on chest containing her hidden paramour.
Husband tricks wife into riding a mule which has been denied water.
r: (Sometimes also paramour.) Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 47; Nouvelles Ricriations No. 90; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: On fording a stream the mule plunges into the water. Wife drowns.

d: Husband in disguise begs food of his wife's suitors.
Husband outwits wife and paramour miscellaneous motifs.
Husband collects fee from paramour.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 43; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: Surprised paramour pays.

d: Husband surprises wife and paramour.
r: Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 71.
a: Rebukes them for not shutting the door.

d: Illness feigned to go to mistress.
a: Husband leaves bed to go to serving maid.

d: Husband takes place of paramour.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 65; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: Beats or otherwise discomfits wife.

d: Husband catches paramour by using wife's pre-arranged signal.
Husband persuades wife to light wicks and carry knife in hand before committing adultery: lovers frightened away.
Alleged speaking privates.
a: Husband pretends that his wife's privates tell him of her adultery.

d: Husband discomfits paramour and wife by clever remark showing that he knows all.
Husband kills surprised paramour.
a: Wife persuades him he has killed thief.

d: Trickster outwits adulteress and paramour.
Trickster discovers adultery: food goes to husband instead of paramour.
r: *Types 1535, 1725; *BP II 18; von der Hagen III *xxix; Wesselski Mdrchen 216 No. 27; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1360A*, 2901*, 2902*; Rumanian: Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 1380 VIII*; Russian: Andrejev 1360A*, 1730 IV; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Trickster discovers adultery: gets food prepared for paramour.
Trickster as sham magician makes adulteress produce hidden food for her husband.
r: *Type 1535; BP II 18; Scala Celi 37a No. 206; Japanese: Ikeda.

d: Trickster makes woman believe that her husband is coming to punish her adultery.
a: She confesses.

d: Trickster sends his master running after the paramour.
a: Though the master does not know of the adultery, the lover is thoroughly frightened.

d: Trickster as sham magician buys chest containing hidden paramour.
Sham magician has paramour fall in a trap.
a: Has trained bird to cling to him.

d: Trickster discovers woman's paramour and hides him in outhouse: rewarded by husband.
Second lover burns paramour at window with hot iron.
r: *Type 1361; Chaucer's Miller's Tale; *Thompson The Miller's Tale (Bryan and Dempster 106ff.) See references for +K1225.

d: God Vishnu in shape of nephew scares and torments his aunt's lover.
Other deceits connected with adultery.
The lover's gift regained.
r: **J. W. Spargo FFC XCI; *F. N. Robinson Complete Works of Geoffrey Chaucer 838a.

d: Lover's gift regained: the broken (removed) article.
a: The lover breaks (or removes) an article of household equipment and convinces the husband that for that reason the wife has confiscated that which he gave her as a present.

d: Lover's gift regained: horse and wagon as gift.
a: The lover regains gift of horse and wagon by pretending to the husband that the wife has confiscated them because he brought wood of uneven quality.

d: Lover's gift regained: borrowing from the husband and returning to the wife.
r: **Spargo FFC XCI; Boccaccio Decameron VIII Nos. 1, 2 (*Lee 247ff.)
a: The lover borrows money from the husband with which to corrupt the wife, later telling the husband that the money was returned to the wife during the husband's absence.

d: Lover's gift regained: accidental discovery of identity.
r: *Spargo FFC XCI; *Euling Studien 'ber Heinrich Kaufringer (Breslau, 1900) 65ff.; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: The lover, ignorant of the identity of the husband, tells him of his experience with the wife. The husband persuades the lover to lead him to the scene, where the wife is compelled to restore all but a small part of the money.

d: Lover's gift regained: piece of cloth as gift.
a: The lover regains by a ruse and thievery the borrowed piece of cloth which he has presented to his mistress.

d: Lover claims payment for cloth in the presence of the husband.
a: The woman returns the cloth but puts a live coal in it. Destroys his whole supply.

d: Lover demands return of cloth on threat to await the husband's return.
Lover's gift regained: jewelry as gift.
r: **Spargo FFC XCI; *Wesselski Bebel II 115f. No. 49; *Bolte Frey 242 No. 76.
a: The lover presents the wife with a valuable piece of jewelry, which he regains by pretending to the husband that he has left it as a pledge.

d: Lover's gift regained: anser venalis (goose as gift).
r: **Spargo FFC XCI; *Semerau Die Schwdke und Schnurren des Poggio (Leipzig, 1905) No. 69; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: The lover regains his gift by a ruse (obscene).

d: Lover delays the gift of the goose hoping to obtain greater favors.
a: Finally has to flee.

d: Lover's gift regained: refusal to leave bed.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 178; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: Woman fearing exposure returns money.

d: Lover's gift regained: spending money to purchase lover's worthless goods.
Lover's gift regained: payment with worthless money.
a: Lover bargains with the husband. Pays him with worthless money.

d: Prostitute paid with counterfeit money.
Husband gets gift which paramour has given to wife.
Lover blackmails adulteress.
After seducing priest's wife, peasant demands earrings as price of silence.
a: He thus avenges himself on priest who has cheated peasant's wife of her earrings.

d: Husband duped by paramour into taking his wife to him.
a: She is veiled.

d: Innocent confessor duped into being go-between for adulteress and lover.
r: Boccaccio Decameron III No. 3 (Lee 71); *Borgeld Vrouwenlist: verbreiding en oorsprong van een novelle uit den Decamerone (Neuphilologische Bibliotheek No. 7, Den Haag, 1926); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: By following suggestions in her false accusations to confessor the lover reaches her side.

d: Wife takes servant's place and discovers husband's adultery.
a: The husband says that he is going into a state of meditation with a cloth over his face. He substitutes a servant and goes to his mistress. The wife finds the deceit and takes the servant's place. On his return the husband tells the supposed servant of his adultery.

d: Paramour feigns loss of genitals in order to obtain the husband's confidence.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 13; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Adulteress uses the public baths as a meeting-place with her lover.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 66; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: A naive remark by her child exposes the deception to the husband.

d: Woman excites peasant (secretary), who draws line on floor and dares her to cross it.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 23; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: When she does, adultery is committed.

d: Seventy tales of a parrot prevent a wife's adultery.
r: *Schmidt Cukasaptati (Kiel, 1894, Stuttgart, 1896); Ktshler-Bolte I 47, 336, 513; Clouston Tales II 196ff.; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 59 No. *435.
a: The parrot keeps her interested until her husband's return.

d: Faithless wife kills magic parrot which has betrayed her.
Peacock left as spy on adulterous wife.
Dog guards chastity of master's wife during his absence.
Paramour sends prostitutes in disguise to take mistress to "convent".
a: Husband is deceived by the ruse.

d: Adulteress disguised as boy elopes with paramour.
Student extends his course so as to enjoy the professor's wife.
The "loyal" adulteress.
r: Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 48; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: Complacent in all except kissing. Explains that her mouth is the only part of her body which has promised fidelity to her husband.

d: Faithful wife in disguise saves husband from punishment for adultery.
Deceiver falls into own trap.
r: Indonesia: DeVries's list Nos. 59-79; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 264f.

d: Deceiver falls into his own trap (literally).
r: Type 1117; Africa: Werner African 214, (Hottentot): Bleek 78; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 254 No. 33; West Indies: Flowers 539.
a: Arranges a trap or pitfall but is himself caught.

d: Pitfall arranged but victim escapes it.
Man falls into sacrificial grave prepared for others.
a: Rich man orders poor people to dig a grave in order to bury all in it as sacrifice to avert famine. But a Christian frees them and promises those who become Christian a living. The rich man himself falls in the grave and dies.

d: Thief-catcher caught by his own magic club.
Deceiver falls into his own trap miscellaneous incidents.
Substituted caps cause ogre to kill his own children.
r: *Types 327, 1119; *BP I 124 n. 1; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 22; India: *Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 358ff.; (Northern Paiute [Paviotso]): Lowie JAFL XXXVII 226 No. 10; Cape Verde Islands: *Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 73 n. 3; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 267 No. 77.
a: The hero and heroine change places in bed with the ogre's children and put on them their caps so that the ogre is deceived.

d: Substituted string causes ogre to be killed.
a: Intended victim of cannibal is marked by thread around ankle. Changed in night to host.

d: Guest to be killed suspects plot and forces host to sleep in his bed.
a: Brothers come home and kill their father.

d: Girl takes place of impostor in marriage bed; impostor's mother beats her, thinking she is heroine.
Noose changed so that ogre's daughter is dragged to death.
Kid puts one of tigress's cubs in his place: she eats the cub.
Message of death fatal to sender.
r: *Type 930; **J. Schick Das Gl'ckskind mit dem Todesbrief (1932); *Aarne FFC XXIII 73ff.; *Penzer II 113; **Cosquin Itudes 73ff., 129ff.; *Chauvin VIII 145; *Fb "teglovn"; *Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 40 No. 34; *Oesterley No. 283; Scala Celi 130b No. 713; *Herbert III 198, 589; *Gaster Exempla 239f., 246f. d. Mdrchens I 509; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 17 No. 8. Icelandic: Sveinsson FFC LXXXIII xxiv, Boberg; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 229, Voorhoeve No. 151, 142.
a: (Gang nach dem Eisenhammer.) A man is sent by the king to burners of a kiln who have been instructed to throw the first arrival into the fire. The intended victim goes elsewhere and the king's son (or the man's accuser), who next arrives, is burned instead.

d: Person sends wrong man to sleep with king's daughter.
a: In revenge villain orders whoever first enters temple to be killed. Villain accidentally enters and is slain.

d: Shoot any thief who comes.
a: "  King unwittingly shot.

d: Poisoner poisoned with his own poison.
Would-be poisoner forced to drink poisoned cup.
Person trying to blow poison on another is himself poisoned.
Wife poisons husband who in turn poisons her.
a: Before he dies he forces her to drink from the same cup.

d: Person gives his wife a poisoned drink; she pours the two drinks together.
a: They both die.

d: Poisoner's own son takes the beverage intended for step-brother.
Son who intends to poison father drinks the poison by mistake.
Snake killed by incantation he has taught clever woman.
Father delivering daughter to be eaten by cannibal is himself eaten.
Ogre's own moccasins burned.
a: The ogre plans to burn the hero's moccasins while they are camping together, but the hero exchanges the moccasins.

d: Marooned man reaches home and outwits marooner.
Marooned egg-gatherer.
r: N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 326 n. 175. Cf. Spanish: Espinosa II No. 49.
a: The father-in-law has the youth hunt eggs on an island and deserts him, but the youth outwits him.

d: Marooned man hides himself in ogre's clothes and outwits him.
Substituted arrows.
a: Hero given arrows with soft points and sent after dangerous enemies. The deception discovered and the enemy discomfited.

d: Deceiver in swinging contest killed.
a: Old woman planning to kill hero in swinging game by cutting rope is killed when hero cuts the rope first.

d: Tiger in sheep's clothing stolen by sheep-thief.
r: Comparetti PFLS IX 144; *Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 236 No. 5.

d: Thief climbing rope discovered and rope cut.
a: He has tricked the guardian of the food-supply in the tree (by imitation of the owner's voice or the discovered pass-word) to let down the rope.

d: Lawyer agrees to pay debt on winning his first case.
a: He refuses to plead so as not to pay. Debtor sues him for double the amount due him. If he wins he has to pay and if he loses he has to pay double. He settles debt.

d: Woman who engages false bridegroom for her daughter has plans go astray.
a: Daughter is seduced.

d: Monkey instead of girl in floating basket: hermit made laughing-stock.
a: He has persuaded girl's foolish father to place her in the basket. Prince takes girl and leaves monkey in her place.

d: Would-be killers killed.
Earl killed in combat with man he has undertaken to kill.
Treacherous counselor killed in treacherous ballgame he himself has arranged.
Boiling water meant for cooking hero used for man who has prepared it.
r: S. Am. Indian (Amuesha): Mitraux RMLP XXXIII 150.

d: Sons have servant impersonate dead father and falsify his will.
a: Servant deceives them by favoring himself.

d: The bribed boy sings the wrong song.
r: England, U.S.: Baughman; Danish: Kristensen Vore Fzhdres Kirketjeneste 88ff.; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 144 No. 1735A*; West Indies: Flowers 541f.
a: The sexton steals the priest's cow. The next day the sexton's son sings, "My father stole the priest's cow. " The priest pays the boy to sing the song in church. But the sexton teaches the boy a new song, "The priest has lain with my mother," and this is sung in church.

d: Fox leads ass to lion's den but is himself eaten.
r: Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 29 No. 50, Espinosa III Nos. 210f.; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: When he gets there the ass kicks him so that he falls on the lion's bed.

d: Cock's advice proves disastrous to himself.
a: He causes the ox and the ass to rebel but the master learns the cause of the trouble and kills him.

d: Partnership of Honesty and Fraud: Fraud loses.
r: Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 99 No. 837, Keller.
a: Fraud has cheated his partner, Honesty. They hire a housekeeper. Fraud is to have use of her right side, Honesty of her left. The left side is of little use. Fraud falls in love with her and pays Honesty double all his losses to relinquish his rights.

d: Maids must rise even earlier.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 64 (ET 279), 116 (ST 262); Halm Aesop No. 10.
a: They have killed the cock for waking them too early, but their mistress punishes them.

d: Flattering foreman tricked by his master.
a: He always answers his master's remarks, "I have thought of the same thing too. " He falls into the trap when his master says, "I am going to sow salt.

d: Ambushed trickster killed by intended victim.
r: *Penzer V 59 n. 2; Irish myth: Cross; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Ekoi): Talbot 69; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 247 No. 23.

d: Husband intending to push wife down mountain is pushed over by her.
Mole as trickster killed in his own tunnel.
a: He tricks the fox by going through the tunnel and eating the common food, but the fox sees the molehill and kills him.

d: Animal strangled by victim which he tries to eat.
r: B[ts]dker Exempler 281 No. 26; Chauvin II 88 No. 24.

d: Woman ordered to strip has lover turn his back; pushes him into water (pit).
r: (Cf. +K551.4.3, +K926, +K1210.) U.S.: Baughman. Cf. Child Ballad No. 4.

d: Woman bitten by own fierce watchdog.
Woman who tries to push husband into river falls in when he steps aside.
a: She drowns because she has tied his hands and he is unable to aid her. (She also thinks he is blind because she has fed him rich food to induce blindness.)

d: The lawyer's mad client.
r: *Type 1585; *Prato RTP IX 537; *Dubsky RTP XXIII 427; Ktshler-Bolte I 362; **Oliver JAFL XXII 395; *Bolte Wickram's Rollwagenb'chlein 371 No. 36; Scala Celi 8a No. 51. Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 139 No. 26; West Indies: Flowers 542.
a: (Pathelin.) On the advice of a lawyer, the client feigns insanity when arraigned in court. When the fee is demanded, he still feigns insanity.

d: No argument good without a witness.
a: "  Lawyer's client therefore refuses payment of fee.

d: Sham dumb man wins suit.
a: The trickster meets a man in a narrow place in the road and calls out to him to make room. The man refuses and the trickster turns over the cart. In court the trickster plays dumb. The plaintiff says, "He is not dumb; he called out to me several times to get out of the way. " Damages are assessed against the plaintiff for negligence.

d: Unjust official outwitted by peasant who quarrels with him and thus turns the attention of the ruler to the abuses.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 847; Nouvelles de Sens. No. 1; Lithuanian: Balys Historical.

d: The order for six loads of snow.
a: The order is given by the king in winter. The courtier waits until summer to present the order. Gets money as substitute.

d: Spying parent jolted in basket.
r: von der Hagen III 36 No. 55; English: Child No. 281.
a: A lover is let down into a girl's room at night in a basket. The spying parent stumbles into the basket and is jolted about by the lover's confederate. The parent thinks the devil has got him and leaves the lovers in peace.

d: Trickster eats his own dog.
a: Trickster sells dog for mutton or for opossum. He later eats the dog which has been given to a friend of his by the purchaser.

d: Unjust banker deceived into delivering deposits by making him expect even larger.
r: Penzer III 118ff.; Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 96a; *Chauvin IX 24 No. 13; Boccaccio Decameron VIII No. 10 (Lee 266); *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 27; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 135 No. 1617*, Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Jewish: *Neuman, *bin Gorion Born Judas II 131, 346, IV 132, 281; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: In order to make the impression of honesty he delivers the one chest of money. The ten chests which he then receives are filled with stones.

d: Blind man gets back his stolen treasure by making thief expect a larger one.
Retrieving the buried treasure.
a: Buried money is stolen. Blind owner pretends that he is going to bury more. Thief returns the money hoping to get all. Blind man recovers original treasure.

d: Blind man asks thief to invest a larger sum for him.
a: The greedy thief puts back the stolen money hoping to get more. The blind man recovers his money.

d: Dwarf himself falls in love with girl he has seduced by magic love, and loses her as he is forced to remove his magic.
Sage's advice followed: he is killed so that sacrifice can be mixed with his blood.
Bear (tiger) substituted for woman in floating box;  kills villain who tries to steal the woman.
Swindlers allowed to hide money: proves to be basket of stones.
Pretended sick man aroused by beating.
Woman, who pretends to faint, comes to life when beaten by magician in order to drive out alleged evil spirit.
Magician challenged to make good his false claim.
a: Says he can take black and white dogs and make them gray and then reverse process. Trickster furnishes gray dog and challenges magician to show his power.

d: Originator of death first sufferer.
r: N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 285 n. 52, (California): Gayton and Newman 59, 64; Africa: Werner African 162.
a: After the culture hero has instituted death, his own child dies and he repents in vain.

d: Inventor of death machine is first to use it.
r: Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Disguised trickster beaten by man he is trying to frighten.
r: Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 47 No. 326, Espinosa II Nos. 136 138.
a: Disguise as ghost.

d: Big 'Fraid and Little 'Fraid.
a: "  Man decides to frighten another (or his son or servant). He dresses in a sheet; his pet monkey puts on a sheet and follows him. The person who is doing the scaring hears the victim say, "Run Big Fraid, run; Little Fraid'll get you. " The scarer sees the monkey in the sheet, runs home.

d: Tables turned on procuress by chaste wife.
a: The old woman is enticed into the wife's room, beaten, and driven forth naked.

d: Seller of pardons robbed by man whom he has pardoned beforehand.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 301; Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 63; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: The defence declared good by the judge.

d: The treasure-finders who murder one another.
r: *Type 763; Chaucer's "Pardoner's Tale"; *F. N. Robinson Complete Works of Geoffrey Chaucer (Boston, 1933) 834; *BP II 154; *Basset 1001 Contes III 181ff.; *Chauvin VIII 100 No. 73; *Wesselski Morlini 293 No. 42; *Bolte Montanus 564; *Basset RTP XIV 440; *Hart MPh IX 17; *Wells MPh XXV 163. Italian Novella: Rotunda; Jewish: *bin Gorion Born Judas IV 41, 276; India: Cowell J[a]taka I 124, *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Chavannes 500 Contes I 386 No. 115; Eberhard FFC CXX 201f.; Korean: Zong in-Sob 186 No. 81.
a: Two (three) men find a treasure. One of them secretly puts poison in the other's wine, but the other kills him, drinks the wine and dies.

d: Tail sticking from ground betrays killing of calf.
a: So arranged by servant in revenge on his master.

d: The easier job.
a: Men exchange jobs because each is made to believe that the other's is easier. It is not.

d: The woman as cuckoo on the tree shot down.
r: *Type 1029; Ktshler-Bolte I 151; W'nsche 29, 33, 36ff., 47, 51ff., 61, 106; Fb "tjzhre" III 811a; Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carriire; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 163 7; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 115.
a: The anger bargain is to cease when the cuckoo crows. The ogre's wife climbs the tree and imitates the cuckoo. She is shot down.

d: A man in place of a cuckoo.
a: A cruel master commands his serf to climb a tree and imitate the cry of the cuckoo; he shoots the "cuckoo.

d: Woman killed.
a: Disliking early rising, the servant kills devil's mother or grandmother, who crows in place of the cock.

d: Teacher instructs pupil in the art of love: cuckolded.
a: Student, ignoring woman's identity, seduces the teacher's wife, and reports success to him. The teacher makes futile attempts to surprise wife with pupil.

d: Trickster's eggs become an omelet.
a: Tries to avoid paying tax by hiding eggs in his breeches. The collectors make him sit down.

d: Trickster makes believe he has found a purse (which he had filled with lead).
a: Merchant claims it and pays ten crowns for it. Trickster wins ensuing suit.

d: Deception through bluffing.
Ogre (large animal) overawed.
r: Missouri French: Carriire; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 5; India: Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 14 Nos. 3, 4; Africa (Wachaga): Gutmann 191f.; West Indies: Flowers 542.

d: Ogre made to believe small hero is large: overawed.
r: India: Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 245; Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 359 No. 12.

d: Tiger made to believe porcupine bristle is his enemy's hair: overawed.
r: India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 90; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 53.

d: Boys threaten to harness tiger.
a: They have jumped on him from behind and he cannot see. He buys them off.

d: Weak animal (man) makes large one (ogre) believe that he has eaten many of the large one's companions.
r: Types 126*, 1149; *BP I 160 n. 1; *Krappe Neophilologus XV 274ff.; Russian: Andrejev No. 126; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 249f.; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: *Dixon 191 nn.
a: The latter is frightened.

d: Weak animal shows strong his own reflection and frightens him.
r: *Penzer V 49 n. 1; Chauvin II 88 No. 25; India: *Thompson-Balys; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 134 No. 18, (Virginia): Parsons JAFL XXXV 264 No. 12.
a: Tells him that this animal is threatening to kill him. (Usually hare and lion.)

d: Weak animal shows strong his own reflection and makes him believe that it is the head of the last animal slain by the weak.
r: B[ts]dker Exempler 282 No. 27; Indonesia, Malay, Hindu: Dixon 191 n. 16, *DeVries Volksverhalen I 362 No. 14.

d: Man shows ghost its own reflection and frightens it.
Man shows demon reflection and frightens him.
Bluff: only one tiger; you promised ten.
r: *Type 1149; Aarne FFC XI 154; Dh IV 278; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 322.
a: Child (or shepherd) calls out to the small hero (ape, hare) and makes the tiger (ogre) think that he is lucky to escape alive.

d: The wolf flees from the wolf-head.
r: *Type 125; BP I 237ff., 254; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 249f., 255f., 266; India: *Thompson-Balys; Africa (Wakweli): Bender 54.
a: The sheep have found a sack and a wolf-head. They make the wolf believe that they have killed a wolf, and he flees in terror.

d: Enemies frightened away by making them think they will be eaten.
r: Chauvin V 23 No. 13 n. 1; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 255f., 266.

d: Spirits frightened away by making them think they will be eaten.
Leopard frightened away by report of lizard's presence.
a: Lizard has bitten leopard before.

d: Trickster pretends to hunt certain tree with which his ancestors have killed tigers.
a: Tiger frightened away.

d: Bluff: small (lame) hero makes demon believe he is a god and threatens to eat him.
a: Demon terrorized.

d: Bluff: hero to brother, "You take one and I can manage the rest.
Trickster purports to be deity's messenger to procure demon-skins for his drum.
a: Demons bribe him instead of devouring him.

d: Ass claims to have killed cow: frightens tiger.
Lion frightened away by stabbing at it from inside iron cage.
Large animal frightened by smaller showing him well rope (for his tail), curds (for spit), winnowing fans (for ears).
Tiger made to believe that his captor has eaten many crabs.
a: Tiger fears crabs and releases him.

d: Fox overawes lion cubs by his boasting and eats their food.
Hare as ambassador of the moon.
r: *Penzer V 101 n. 1; Chauvin II 96 No. 49; Panchatantra III 2 (tr Ryder 308); B[ts]dker Exempler 294 No. 54; Spanish Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys.
a: Hare claiming to be ambassador of moon shows elephant the moon irritated in a spring. Elephant is persuaded that the moon is angry.

d: Big shoes in front of the barn.
a: Man makes giant shoes and places them so that ogre thinks a giant lives there.

d: Ogre overawed by hero's boasts about marvelous relatives.
Bluff: thunder said to be the rolling of hero's brother's wagon.
a: Ogre overawed.

d: Bluff: millstones said to be pearls of hero's mother.
a: Ogre overawed.

d: Bluff: huge cauldron of tar said to be kitchen-pot of hero's mother.
Bluff: harrow said to be comb of hero's mother.
Bluff: plow said to be hoe of hero's mother.
Hero proves himself a cannibal by trick vomit-exchange.
r: Dh III 142; India: Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 301 n. 102; Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 381 No. 7.

d: Hero frightens dog into giving up eating men by pretending to eat own entrails.
Ant-eater deceives jaguar by excrement-exchange.
r: S. A. Indian (Caingeng, Bacairi): Horton BBAE CXLIII (3) 294.

d: Monkey pretends that his house always answers him.
Goat pretends to be chewing rock.
a: Frightens wolf.

d: St. George's Dogs"  (wolves).
r: Type 1150; Lithuanian: Balys Legends No. 148; West Indies: Flowers 543f.
a: The man says, "St. George's dogs are coming! " The ogre flees.

d: Dogs are chasing you," says ox to jackal.
a: Really water gurgling in the ox's stomach.

d: Tiger thinks sound of water dropping is sound of dreadful monster: flees.
Giantess frightened of leaving cave because of hero's statue in entrance.
Tiger frightened at hearing unknown wind.
The bear trainer and his bear.
a: (Schrdtel und Wasserbdr.) Ogre is driven out by hero's bear. The next year the ogre asks, "Is the big cat still living? " Hero says that it now has many kittens. Ogre is overawed.

d: Wages: as much as he can carry.
a: To get rid of the boy the troll offers him as large wages as he is able to carry. Boy says that this will be too much, that he will be contented merely with what the troll can carry.

d: Ogre made to believe hero has withstood fire.
a: Hero escapes and after the room he has been in is burned he returns and is found sitting in the ashes. " It was a bit hot," he says.

d: Giant persuaded that hero has pushed hole in wall with bare hand.
a: Hole bored before.

d: Dog pretends to be calling dog in the moon when he barks.
Troll bluffed away from christening.
r: *Type 1165; Swedish, Norwegian, Danish, German, Finnish, Estonian, Livonian, Latvian, Lithuanian: *Balys Tautosakos Darbai VI 137 161.
a: He is invited but told that guests will include the Virgin Mary, Thor the Thunderer, etc. He stays away but sends the finest present.

d: Bluff: hero professes to be able to perform much larger task than that assigned.
Felling the whole forest.
r: *Type 1049; *BP III 333; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 163 167; India: Thompson-Balys.
a: Told to bring in a tree, the hero asks, "Why not the whole forest? " The ogre is frightened.

d: Bluff: told to bring home a tree, hero prepares to bring home six.
A thousand at one shot.
a: Told to shoot one or two wild boars, hero asks, "Why not a thousand at one shot? " The ogre is frightened.

d: Bluff: told to bring home an ox, hero prepares to bring home ten.
Bringing the whole well.
r: Type 1049; *BP III 333; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 163 167.
a: Told to get water, hero demands bucket large enough to bring in the whole well. The ogre is frightened.

d: Bluff: told to bring water in an ox skin, hero prepares to dig a canal.
Wrestler claims to be able even to carry away a mountain.
Hero threatens to pull the lake together with a rope.
r: *Types 1045, 1650; Spanish: Espinosa Nos. 163 167; Missouri French: Carriire.
a: The ogre is intimidated.

d: Hero threatens to haul away the warehouse with a rope.
a: The ogre is intimidated.

d: Trickster threatens to throw weight into a cloud: ogre intimidated.
Ogre terrified by woman's legs.
r: *Type 1159; *BP II 530 n. 3. Cf. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1154*, 1164C*.
a: He has formerly been caught in a vise. On his approach, the man's wife stands on her head and ogre thinks her legs are a vise. He flees.

d: Bear frightened away by man threatening to cleave its skull with his penis.
a: He meets a woman who, upon being told what man had threatened, shows him a vestige of the cleaving she once got. Only partly healed.

d: Ogre terrified by an iron man.
a: In order to save the king's daughter from the ogre an iron man is forged.

d: Other bluffs.
Bluff: provisions for the swimming match.
r: *Type 1612; N. A. Indian (Maliseet): Speck JAFL XXX 482 No. 7; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 190.
a: In a swimming match from a ship the hero takes a knapsack of provisions on his back. His rival is afraid and gives up.

d: Bluff: climbing the mast.
r: *Type 1611; N. A. Indian (Maliseet): Speck JAFL XXX 482 No. 7; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 190.
a: In a contest in climbing the mast the hero falls into the rigging. " You do the same thing," he challenges. The sailors are persuaded of his expertness.

d: Bluff in court: the stone in the purse.
a: A poor man has a stone in his purse to throw at the judge if he is sentenced. The judge thinks that he has money to use as a bribe and acquits him.

d: Trickster's boasting scares his powerful opponent from contest.
False boasting of having killed his foster-brother makes his men follow the boaster.
Goat singing a threatening song bought off with food and jewels.
Bluffing threat.
Sham threat: "In earnest or in jest?
a: " A man asks another who has brushed against him: "Did you do that in earnest or in jest? " "In earnest. "  "I am glad, for I don't like that kind of jesting.

d: Sham threat: either .
Sham threat: something he has never done before.
a: Beggar says, "If you do not give me alms I shall have to do something I have never done before. " The alms are given and he is asked what he would have had to do. " Work.

d: Sham threat: the faked duel.
a: Two who had challenged each other agree to hold a sham duel.

d: Sham threat: if I were not a philosopher I should break your head for you.
Girl's sham threat in order to evade husband till lover returns.
Sham threat of war holds ships back so that there suddenly are enough men to man defending ship.
Sham dream prophesying shipwreck makes people leave ship so that there is room enough for man who wants to go.
King menaced into giving his daughter by means of borrowed fleet.
Pretended anger.
King persuades men to follow him, pretending that he is going to make peace with his brothers, instead battle.
Bluff: insult repeated as harmless remark.
r: Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 130; Africa (Basuto): Jacottet 12 No. 1, (Benga): Nassau 153ff. Cf. Chaucer Nun's Priest's Tale lines 343ff.
a: The trickster makes an insulting remark, but when called on to repeat what he said he changes it so as to turn aside wrath.

d: Boast where the master cannot hear.
a: The servant boasts that he has scolded his master.

d: When he is looked at too threateningly hero feigns failing ability to go on horseback.
Threat to build a church in hell.
r: Type 804*; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 811A*; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 804*; Russian: Andrejev No. 804*.
a: When the man makes this threat, he is let out of hell.

d: Bluff: wealth gained by seeming to be in the king's confidence.
r: *Penzer V 186 n. 1; *Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 127 No. 110, Morlini 266 No. 4; Clouston Tales II 360ff.; *Herbert III 421 No. 82; Scala Celi 136b No. 762.
a: Courtier asks the king for a reward that will cost nothing. He gets permission to listen to the king's devotions. He now receives bribes because of his apparent influence.

d: Shoemaker offers to trim the peasant's feet to fit the shoes.
a: The peasant prefers to accept the ill-fitting shoes.

d: Herdsman threatens invasion with enormous herds: bought off.
a: He hires himself as herdsman of all his master's flocks for ten years. He then sends notice to surrounding peoples that he is coming with his master's flocks to graze. They bribe him to stay away.

d: Trickster falsely reports impending invasion from his own people.
a: Receives money to buy them off.

d: Adventurer on otherworld island sees great hornless oxen guarded by giant: tries to frighten them.  "
a: Why dost thou frighten the stilly calves? " says the huge herdsman. " Where are the dams of these calves? " asks the adventurer. " They are on the other side of yonder mountain," said he. So he went thence.

d: Miracle must wait till one man is sacrificed.
a: No one volunteers and it does not need to be performed.

d: Bluff: the rare vintages.
a: Host serves many rare vintages and gets a reputation for his wine cellar. But there is only a small jug of each vintage.

d: Man falsely claims to have killed elephant with his flat hand.
a: Rewarded.

d: Fox threatens to catch bird, who feeds him her young as appeasement.
a: He threatens to push down tree or to fly.

d: Sham duel in order to bring about recognition.
Feigned ignorance about person's identity in order to tell one's frank opinion of him.
Feigned ignorance of person's identity in order not to reveal king.
Feigned ignorance about the whereabouts of hero's weapons and horse in order to keep him as monk.
Illiterate man pretends to be weeping because he cannot make others understand the book he is reading.
Woman frightens robber away by telling him parrot's cry is husband's voice.
Deception by disguise or illusion.
Deception by disguise.
Disguise by putting on clothes (carrying accoutrements) of certain person.
Fool wears king's crown.
Lover disguised in slain enemy's clothes.
Taking king's place by changing dresses.
Dog procures disguise from magician to frighten tiger.
Lover disguised as other knight in order to reach sweetheart.
Gods (saints) in disguise visit mortals.
r: *Types 330A, 750A, 751, 752A, 753, 768, 785, 791; *BP II 210, III 198, 451; *Dh II 129; *Rohde Der Griechische Roman 451 n.; Fb "Sankt Peder" III 164a; United States (Mormon): **Lee, Hector, "The Three Nephites: the Substance and Significance of the Legend in Folklore" (Albuquerque, 1949), "The Three Nephites: a Disappearing Legend" Am.

d: Mortal entertained by disguised god.
Goddess in disguise visits earth and is waylaid by thieves.
a: They set her free after she promises to tell them the fate of the new-born prince.

d: Gods (spirits) disguised as beggars.
a: Test hospitality.

d: Deity disguised as old man (woman) visits mortals.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 776; Jewish: Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: God disguised as doctor cures mortal.
Deity takes form of particular person to visit mortals.
Fate takes form of Brahmin's pupil in order to lure him to his prophesied death.
Angel takes form of certain person.
Deity takes form of animal to visit mortals.
King in disguise.
r: *Chauvin VI 45 No. 209; Icelandic: *Boberg; Jewish: Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 95.

d: King disguised beaten by his own men.
Incognito king helped by humble man.
r: Type 952; *BP III 450; Child V 67; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: Gives reward.

d: Incognito king is asked by humble man to aid him.
Incognito king joins robbers.
Incognito king joins robbers: to take only six shillings.
a: The robber tells him that he must take no more, since the king has so many robbers.

d: Incognito prince joins gamblers.
a: He is beaten for showing courtesy. Realizes his folly and returns home.

d: Prince disguises as another prince to woo princess.
Incognito king is given hospitality by fisherman.
a: Rewards him with a city.

d: Incognito king in victor's court.
a: Asks forgiveness.

d: Ruler disguises as goblin to frighten uxorious priest.
King disguises as common soldier and is killed.
a: Fulfills prophecy that insures victory.

d: Incognito queen (princess).
Queen flees husband's persecution disguised as knight.
Incognito princess travels as bishop (monk).
Disguised queen visits her husband and begets child with him as assigned.
r: (Cf. +H1187.) Ktshler-Bolte II 647ff.; Liungman Tve Folkminnesunderstskningar 25 n. 1.

d: Incognito king rewards farmer for gift.
King disguised as peasant flees battle.
Incognito prince (king) sold into slavery.
a: Disguised as sailor.

d: Incognito king comes to the aid of an enemy who has refused to vilify him.
Incognito king rewards strangers who treat him as companion.
Lecherous prince disguises as merchant in order to kill his grand-children.
King in disguise of merchant is given hospitality by enemy.
King disguised as own messenger.
King disguised as mountaineer.
King in disguise to spy out his kingdom.
r: Chauvin VI 45 No. 209; Nouvelles Ricriations No. 6.

d: Fallen king in disguise recognized by former ally and helped.
King in disguise as one of his own men rescued in fighting alone against four.
Count in disguise.
Disguised husband visits his wife.
r: English: Wells 17 (Guy of Warwick); Irish myth: *Cross; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Disguised husband wins his faithless wife's love.
Disguised husband shows his wife that he is not repulsive, as she thinks him.
Disguised husband shows his wife that he is not a good-for-nothing as she thinks him.
Disguised husband spies on his faithless wife.
Woman in disguise wooed by her faithless husband.
r: *Bidier Fabliaux 448; *BP IV 254 n. 1, Italian: Basile Pentamerone V No. 6, *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Prince disguised as merchant seduces a queen.
Wife substitutes for princess, who has been jailed with husband.
a: Before judge says: "What harm is there in a man being with his own wife?

d: Wife disguised as fakir makes her husband, the king, fulfill her will.
Husband twits wife regarding "bought kiss"; she makes him buy one from her by disguising herself.
Humble disguise.
r: (Cf. +K521.4.3, +K1812, +K1816.) Type 510B; BP II 45ff.; **Cox passim; Cosquin Etudes 4f.; Icelandic: Boberg; Irish myth: *Cross; English: Wells 9 (King Horn); Italian Novella: Rotunda; Greek: *Frazer Apollodorus II 226 n. 2; Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian (Ojibwa): Laidlaw Ontario Archeological Report (1918) 36 No. 111, (California): Gayton and Newman 95.
a: (Cap o' Rushes, Peau d'vne Allerleirauh.) Usually in rough clothing.

d: Disguise with hood dropping low over the face.
Return home in humble disguise.
Pious pilgrim dies unknown in his father's house.
a: (Miraculous manifestations.)

d: Ugly disguise.
Disguise as menial.
r: *Types 314, 870; Irish myth: *Cross; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 14; Italian: Basile Pentamerone II No. 7, IV No. 10; Arabian: Burton Arabian Nights S II 203; India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 21.

d: God disguised as menial.
r: Icelandic: MacCulloch Eddic 85; Greek: *Frazer Apollodorus I 390 n. 1.

d: Girl in menial disguise at lover's court.
Menial disguise of princess's lover.
r: *Types 301, 314, 900; *BP I 446; Child V 109ff., 116ff., 305a; Wells 14 (The Lay of Havelok) 19 (Sir Beves of Hamtoun), 147 (Ipomadon); Icelandic: *Boberg; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G.

d: Hero in menial disguise at heroine's wedding.
r: Types 300, 301, 303; Irish myth: *Cross; Welsh: MacCulloch Celtic 94. See nearly all references to +N681.

d: Scholar disguised as a rustic along road answers questions of school inspector in Greek, Latin, and Hebrew.
Gardener disguise.
Pope disguised as caulker.
Disguise as woodcutter.
Disguise as potter.
Disguise as goose-girl (turkey-girl).
r: *Type 533; *BP II 273ff.; Ktshler-Bolte I 347; Breton: Sibillot Incidents s.v. "gardeuse", "dindons".

d: Disguise as tender of birds.
Disguise as herdsman (shepherd, swineherd, etc.)  DeVries FFC LXXIII 324; Schoepperle II 583 s.v. "disguises"; Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: Boberg.
Disguise as porter.
Disguise as stable-boy.
Disguise as peasant.
Wise men disguise as peasants.
Disguise as cobbler (shoemaker).
Nobleman disguises as cobbler to woo woodcutter's daughter.
Disguise as carpenter.
Disguise as smith.
Disguise as slave.
Disguise as wanderer.
r: Italian Novella: Rotunda; Icelandic: *Boberg; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Disguise as beggar (pauper).
r: *Type 900; *BP I 443ff.; Schoepperle II 583 s.v. "disguises"; *Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 250b; Child I 189, 191f., 202 207, III 157, 179, 191ff., 271ff., V 2ff., 279f. Irish: O'Suilleabhain 24, 42, 45, Beal XXI 307, 315f., *Cross; English: Wells 11 (Horn Childe and Maiden Rimnild); Icelandic: *Boberg; Spanish: Espinosa II Nos. 133 135, III No. 192, Espinosa Jr.

d: Disguise as fakir.
Disguise as palmer (pilgrim).
r: Thien Motive 16; *Boje XIX 70f.; English: Wells 9 (King Horn); Icelandic: FSS 230 32, 252, Boberg; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Disguise as harper (minstrel).
r: *Type 900; *BP I 446; *Boje XIX 70f., Thien Motive 16; *Hibbard 93 n. 9; English: Wells 9 (King Horn); Icelandic: *Boberg.

d: Disguise as poet.
Disguise as merchant.
r: Schoepperle II 583 s.v. "disguises"; Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. Nos. 142 145; Italian Novella: Rotunda; Jewish: *Neuman.

d: Disguise as peddler.
Queen disguised as peddler.
Queen disguised as peddler sells children poisoned cheese.
Disguise as gypsy.
Disguise as sick man.
r: *Type 3; Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: Boberg; Jewish: *Neuman; Arabian: Burton Nights S V 285; Japanese: Ikeda; West Indies: Flowers 546.

d: Disguise as leper.
r: Irish myth: *Cross; English: Wells 143 (Generydes); Tonga: Gifford 193.

d: Scald-head disguise.
r: *Types 314, 502; *BP III 109; *Chauvin VI 51 No. 217 n. 3; Missouri French: Carriire.
a: To avoid having his gold hair seen, the hero covers his head with a cloth and says that he has the scaldhead.

d: Disguise as madman (fool).
r: *Type 900; *BP I 446; Schoepperle II 583 s.v. "disguises"; *Liebrecht 141ff.; *Hibbard 227; Malone PMLA XLIII 400; Greek: *Frazer Apollodorus II 176 n. 2; Irish myth: Cross; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Jewish: Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Wise man disguised as buffoon.
Lover approaches mistress disguised as fool.
Sharp man pretends to be stupid so as to be included in plans and conversation of plotters.
Disguise as deformed men to secure entertainment.
Animal feigns lameness.
Deception by pretended faint.
