a: Saint has tribute remitted for a day and a night, i.e. forever, because there is but one day and one night in time.

d: One day and one night: object borrowed for a day and a night retained.
King induced by saint to remit tribute till Luan.  "
a: Luan" means both "Monday" and "Doomsday.

d: Water-monster allows saint to place cauldron over its head until Luan.
Peasant betrays fox by pointing.
r: **Krohn Mann und Fuchs 61ff.; Wienert FFC LVI 68 (ET 324), 102 (ST 150); Halm Aesop No. 35; *Ktshler-Bolte I l; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 35 No. *161, Espinosa Jr.
a: The peasant has hidden the fox in a basket and promised not to tell. When the hunters come, he says, "The fox just went over the hill," but points to the basket.

d: Thieves dig field and drain tank when miser says gold is hidden there.
Deception by equivocation miscellaneous.
One foot in Ireland, one in Scotland.
a: Man carries sods of two countries with him that his whereabouts will be so defined.

d: Warrior proposes to fight in single combat.
a: Fights with aid of sons and grandsons. They belong to him.

d: Saint hides fugitive from king underground.
a: When king demand fugitive, saint (who never lies) replies, "Verily, I know not where he is, if he is not under thee even where thou art. " The king is satisfied and departs. Later suspects trick and arrests fugitive.

d: Deception by frightening.
r: Missouri French: Carriire; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 5; West Indies: Flowers 536.

d: Corpse set up to frighten people.
r: *Type 1536; *Taylor MPh XV 225 n. 1; Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 73, 360; Icelandic: *Boberg; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Man who killed mother uses her corpse to get presents.
Dummy set up as corpse to frighten people.
r: Italian Novella: Rotunda; N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 69.

d: The three hunchback brothers drowned.
r: *Type 1536B; *BP III 485; **Pillet Das Fablaiu von les trois bossus menestrals (1901); *Taylor MPh XV 223 n. 3; *Chauvin VIII 72; *Herbert III 203; Spanish: Espinosa II Nos. 31f.; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda.
a: A drunken man is employed, by the woman who has accidently slain three hunchback brothers, to throw one into the river. He does so. Then she puts another out and finally the third. The man thinks they keep coming to life. Finally he sees the woman's hunchback husband and drowns him.

d: The cowardly duelers.
r: *Type 104; *BP I 425; Dh IV 209; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 246 248.
a: In the war between the wild and the domestic animals, the cat raises her tail; the wild animals think that it is a gun and flee.

d: Fox's tail drops and frightens animals.
a: In war between birds and quadrupeds the fox's lifted tail is to be the signal for the attack. Gnats sting the fox under the tail. He drops it and the quadrupeds flee.

d: He-goat bleats and frightens animals assembled for fight.
r: Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 246 248; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 89.

d: Old woman and tiger flee in terror from each other.
Hiding from the strange animal.
a: A cat shrieks and the frightened bear falls out of the tree and hurts himself.

d: Ferocious animal frightened by ass braying.
Devil frightened by threatening to bring mother-in-law.
Wolf-captor scared by fiddle-playing of captive ram, who escapes.
Parson is tricked into giving up his room.
a: Is told there is a snake in it.

d: Tiger frightened away from man's tree refuge by man's stick and rope.
Wife, to drive away parasite priest, tells him husband has gone to get drunk and will kill him with rice mortar on his return.
a: He leaves in haste.

d: Ogre frightened at rustling.
a: Man sets juniper afire.

d: Tiger frightened at sound of clashing knives: thinks it is leak in house of which he is afraid.
Bear frightened by wife's sneezing.
Wooden image frightens away invaders.
Military strategy.
Animals help in military victory.
Sparrows of Cirencester.
r: **Krappe MPh XXIII 7ff.; **DeVries Arkiv ftsr Nordisk Filologi XLVII 66ff.; Stender-Petersen Edda Nordisk Tidsskrift f. Litteraturforskning 1929, 145 64; Herrmann Saxo II 93; *Liebrecht 109f.; Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: Boberg.
a: Fire is attached to birds who fly in and set fire to a besieged city.

d: Fire tied to foxes' tails: destroys enemy's cities and fields.
Bees thrown into redoubt drive out enemies.
r: *Fb "bi" IV 36b; Deutschbein I 256; Hdwb. d. Abergl.

d: Bees carried in drum attack and defeat attacking army.
Ashes transformed into bees, wasps, scorpions and snakes drive invading army away for hero.
Mice and hogs let loose put elephant cavalry to flight.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 528; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 246 248; Jewish: Neuman.

d: Elephant drunk with toddy sent to attack enemy.
Horses frightened by instruments of war are backed into enemy's ranks.
Birds frighten enemy's horses so that they throw their riders down.
Wild horses with bags containing stones tied to their tails, driven into enemy's camp to cause stampede.
Horse with basket of powdered peppers sent into hostile camp: enemy overcome.
Hot pepper mixed with flour supplying enemy camp.
a: Thinking they have been poisoned, they beat a retreat.

d: Wild fawn sent by saint into hostile army, so that all follow it and leader (enemy of saint) is slain.
Strategy to get into enemy city: huge rat makes a burrow.
Women spread shawls on enemy's path and entangle them.
a: They are easily defeated.

d: Fresh hides spread so that enemy slips and falls.
Treasure cast down crushes besiegers.
Treacherous priests prolong mass to let enemy destroy city.
Women throw ashes in eyes of attacking soldiers, so that they are defeated.
Man blinded by throwing dust in his eyes: he is robbed.
Disguise to enter enemy's camp (castle).
r: Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Spanish Exempla: Keller; India: Panchatantra III 5 (tr. .

d: Disguise to spy on enemy.
Owner admitted into his own castle, captured in his absence, in guise of a monk.
a: He has given news to conqueror of his purported death.

d: Disguise as musician to enter enemy's camp.
r: Herrmann Saxo II 210; Irish myth: Cross; Collingwood Sagabook of the Viking Society X (1) 134.

d: Disguise as pilgrim to enter enemy's camp (castle).
Disguise as old man to enter enemies' camp.
Rabbi feigns death to be carried out of the besieged city and to approach enemy.
Weapons disguised permit entry to enemies' camp.
Woman disguises as man to enter enemy's camp.
a: Slays enemy king.

d: Disguise in killed enemy's clothes to enter enemy's castle.
Disguise as woman to enter enemy's camp (castle).
Disguise as beggar (pauper) to enter enemy's camp (castle) or to spy.
r: Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Greek: Grote I 276.

d: Disguise as merchant to enter enemy's castle.
Disguise as leper to enter enemy's camp.
Disguise as carpenter (tradesman) to enter enemy's camp.
Disguise as juggler to enter enemy's camp.
Disguise as churl (bachlach) to enter enemy's hall.
Capture by hiding warriors in baskets on back of oxen driven into enemy's camp on pretence that food is being brought.
Man disguised as animal sent among enemy that first blood be spilled by other side.
Woman saves herself from soldiers by receiving them joyfully rather than fearfully.
Capture of castle by feigning death.
r: *DeVries Arkiv f. Nordisk Filologi XLVII 56ff., 67ff.; Wilken Geschichte der Kreuzz'ge II 321ff.; Herrmann Saxo II 126; Icelandic: Boberg.

d: Spies' false report of enemies' weakness brings on premature attack.
Enemy's ships fired by use of fireship.
r: English: Malory X 32; Greek: Iliad XVI 84.

d: Enemies defeated by setting forest afire.
Enemy induced to give up siege.
Enemy induced to give up siege by pretending to have plenty of food.
r: Grimm Deutsche Sagen 460, 470, 504; Von der Leyen Sagenbuch III 1 No. 75, 2 No. 278; L'bbing Friesische Sagen 65; Laport FFC LXXXIV 182; Herodotus I ch.

d: Enemy induced to surrender city by show of wealth on part of besiegers, who shoot golden apples over walls.
Enemy soldiers persuaded by show of great wealth and generosity of king to desert to his side.
City is falsely promised to enemy.
a: When they enter they are attacked and defeated.

d: Trickster admits defeat: enemy and friends invited to fort for ceremony and then attacked.
Besieger scatters beads in protecting hedge: besieged destroy hedge to find beads.
Enemy deceived into overestimating opponents: retreat.
Sound of artillery is simulated to overawe enemy.
Persons run wagon back and forth over a corduroy bridge to simulate sound of artillery.
Sounds of mock battle scare away attacking force.
Sounds of battle in playhouse scare away attacking soldiers.
Sham doctor prescribes medicine for king's army;  they fall ill; invading army, seeing multitudes being carried away in litters, flee, thinking there is a plague.
Enemy induced to give up siege by making it look as if the besieged have got reinforcement.
Military strategy miscellaneous.
Marauder pretends beggary that king will underestimate his power.
Division of warriors hidden in pit on battlefield.
a: Emerge during battle.

d: Largest part of fleet does not emerge until late in battle.
Treacherous king participates in battle only when he sees who is likely to win.
Treacherous ruler of city under siege sends sons to deliver city to enemy.
Postponing of payment asked in order to get time to gather reinforcements.
Besiegers drowned by diversion of river.
Military strategy: city won by turning river from its course through city.
a: Enemy soldiers march through empty bed into city.

d: Shammed discussing of peace while getting reinforcements.
Cauldron containing lighted torch brought into enemy's camp ostensibly to be used for serving food: torch uncovered as signal for attack.
Fairy mist mistaken for smoke of enemy's burning ships.
Hero causes confusion in enemy camp in dead of night: army men fall upon one another, convinced the enemy has infiltrated their camp.
Poisoned food sent to enemy camp.
Enemy leaders invited to banquet and poisoned.
Brambles heaped in ford to halt enemies.
Miscellaneous deceptions.
Deceiving the higher powers (God, the saints, the gods, fate).
Heaven entered by a trick.
r: *Type 330; *BP I 343, II 189, III 303; Spanish: Espinosa Jr.

d: Heaven entered by trick: permission to pick up cap.
a: Trickster throws a cap or leather apron inside the gate.

d: Heaven entered by trick: demanding back the charity gift.
a: The trickster demands of Peter an article which he has given in charity. He then sits on it as his own property within the gates.

d: Heaven entered by trick: "wishing sack" thrown in.
a: Trickster wishes himself in the sack.

d: Heaven entered by trick: sitting on Peter's chair.
Heaven entered by trick: slipping in along with holy person.
Heaven entered by trick: angel tricked by drink into telling woman how to enter.
Gods tricked into help in escaping one's fate.
Ingeniously worded boon asked of God combines riches, issue, and restoration of eyesight: "Oh God!
a: I want to see from above the seventh story of my mansion my great-grandsons playing in the streets and eating their cakes from golden vessels.

d: Dog sent ahead so as to avoid seeing husband transformed.
Enemies reconciled by gifts which the one's son tells are sent from the other.
The returned box on the ears.
r: Anderson FFC XLII 360; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 924B*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1637*.
a: At table each gives his neighbor a box on the ears. The soldier is to give it to the king, but he returns it to the courtier from whom he has received it.

d: Entering a garden by swimming down a stream that flows into it.
Temporary advantage gained by pretending to yield in a combat.
Person allowed to win first game so that he will play for higher stakes.
Warrior consents to flee for the sake of future victory.
Enemies deceived through shammed flight.
Ammunition saved till enemy has used his.
Hero sleeps during the first part of battle and emerges only later.
Ruler diverts attention from misgovernment by beginning a war.
One animal injures another by deception.
r: B[ts]dker Exempler 281 No. 25; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Bird plucks another bird's feathers out.
Dwarf-deer pastes other animal's eyes shut and pretends that hunters are coming.
Tying cat to balky horse's tail to make him move.
Man tricked to be one's sworn brother in order to secure his help against his mother.
Demon enters person and refuses to leave until wishes have been fulfilled.
r: Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas II 193ff., 352f.; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Attempt to kill by throwing knife.
